Thank you to all the doctors and healthcare professionals who work night and day to care for those in need, especially during the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak. CDC has resources and information specifically for healthcare professionals – find them at: https://bit.ly/3dCIw7P

Older people and people with long-term health problems are at higher risk of getting very sick from COVID-19. CDC recommends that during a local COVID-19 outbreak, skilled nursing facilities take proactive steps to prevent introduction of coronavirus into the facility, including restricting visitors and excluding ill staff from work. If a case of COVID-19 is detected in a facility, CDC recommends even stronger measures to prevent further spread. Learn more: https://bit.ly/MMWR_COVID19SNF

CDC Tobacco Free’s Tips From Former Smokers® campaign shares the stories of real people and their loved ones who have been affected by smoking. Today, the campaign is back for its 9th year to share new stories: CDC.gov/tips

A lot is still being studied about how coronavirus spreads. If you have COVID-19 and are breastfeeding your baby, talk to your doctor and take everyday steps to keep your child safe:
• Wash your hands before touching your baby.
• If possible, wear a facemask while breastfeeding.
• Wash your hands before touching bottle or breast pump parts.
Learn more: https://bit.ly/397jOsE

Much is unknown about how coronavirus (COVID-19) spreads. We believe it spreads mostly from person to person through respiratory droplets produced when someone who is sick coughs or sneezes.
You can help prevent the spread of respiratory illnesses like COVID-19 by following simple daily precautions.
Learn how to protect yourself from coronavirus (COVID-19): https://bit.ly/37Ay6Cm

The best way to prevent COVID-19 is to avoid being exposed. You can help prevent the spread of COVID-19 with these actions:
• Practice social distancing by putting space between yourself and others.
• Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
• Wash hands often for at least 20 seconds.
• Avoid touching your face.
Stay safe and healthy during the COVID-19 outbreak: https://bit.ly/38Wbhsw

Is your child or teen feeling stressed about COVID-19? There are many things you can do to support your child during this time:
• Take time to talk with them about COVID-19.
• Reassure your child and that it‘s normal to be upset.
• Try to keep up with a regular routine, including sleep and structured learning.
• Connect with friends and family through phone, text, or email.
See more tips to support your child or teen: https://bit.ly/39UVoEj

While social distancing for COVID-19, take the time to check in on friends and family to see how they are doing. Set up a daily phone or video call to touch base and share the best and most challenging parts of the day. https://bit.ly/2Qj4ing

CDC Issues Domestic Travel Advisory for New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut.
Due to extensive community transmission of COVID -19 in the area, CDC urges residents of New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut to refrain from non-essential domestic travel for 14 days effective immediately.
This Domestic Travel Advisory does not apply to employees of critical infrastructure industries, including but not limited to trucking, public health professionals, financial services, and food supply. These employees of critical infrastructure, as defined by the Department of Homeland Security, have a special responsibility to maintain normal work schedule. The Governors of New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut will have full discretion to implement this Domestic Travel Advisory.
https://bit.ly/3bzmFwh

While staying home to prevent COVID-19, do that thing around the house you have been putting off! Repair, paint, or clean, and then share your before and after pics online. Your friends will have plenty of time to “like” and “comment.” https://bit.ly/38Wbhsw

Parents: Closing schools is one way to slow the spread of COVID-19, but – as you know – being home all the time can be hard. Find tips to support the health and well-being of yourself and your children while you’re home together: https://bit.ly/33LN1se

During the COVID-19 outbreak, keep physical distance but stay connected to others. To capture this moment in history, do a home photoshoot and share with others. Share your best cleaning & disinfecting pose after reviewing these tips: https://bit.ly/33vrmod

If you’re over 65, your risks of getting seriously ill or dying from coronavirus (COVID-19) are much higher than the risks other people face. If you have a serious underlying condition, you’re also at higher risk even if you’re younger. Learn more at https://bit.ly/3dtqipr.

CDC Travel Notice Level 3: COVID-19 Global Pandemic Notice. Avoid all nonessential international travel. If you travel, your plans may be disrupted due to travel restrictions and flight cancellations. https://bit.ly/2wz98Gm
If you must travel:
• Avoid contact with sick people
• Do not touch your face (especially eyes, nose, or mouth) with unwashed hands
• Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If soap and water are not readily available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol.
• Stay home for 14 days after your return to the United States. Monitor your health and practice social distancing.

Don’t put family at risk for COVID-19 by visiting them in person. Call grandparents or invite them to a video chat. Keep your loved ones safe by staying connected while physically distant: https://bit.ly/38Wbhsw

Slow the spread of COVID-19 by staying home and watching the latest new releases or your favorite reruns from the comfort of your own couch. Recreate the movie theater experience by making some stovetop popcorn or other healthy snacks. https://bit.ly/38Wbhsw

Spring break coming up? Instead of heading to a crowded place, like the beach, plan a staycation, virtual movie night, or online hangout. Don’t forget to disinfect your phone and wash your hands! https://bit.ly/33vrmod

Bored and stressed while at home because of COVID-19 outbreak? Work out that stress while keeping physical distance from others – go for a walk or stream your favorite workout online.

Getting rid of germs like coronavirus takes a one-two punch. Make sure to clean surfaces with soap and water, and then disinfect with a household disinfectant or another recommended product. Remember, do not mix chemicals! See COVID-19 disinfection recommendations: https://bit.ly/33vrmod

As of March 25, 41 U.S. states and 1 U.S. territory report some community spread of coronavirus (COVID-19). Of those, thirteen states report COVID-19 cases are “widespread.” See CDC’s map to stay up to date on what is happening in your state. https://bit.ly/39gqyEH

Are you a healthcare professional or responding to the COVID-19 outbreak? To take care of others, healthcare professionals and other responders must be feeling well and thinking clearly. Take steps to care for yourself:
• Take breaks, eat healthily, exercise, and get adequate sleep.
• Find a friend at work to support and monitor stress, workload, and safety.
• Ask for help if you feel overwhelmed or concerned that COVID-19 is affecting your ability to care for others, yourself, or your family.
• If you are worried about how you feel, get support 24/7 by calling 1-800-985-5990 or text TalkWithUs to 66746.
Learn more about stress and coping during the COVID-19 outbreak: https://bit.ly/39UVoEj

If you have COVID-19 and will not have a test to see if you are still contagious, you should only leave your “sick room” and home when ALL of the following are true:
• No fever for at least 72 hours (3 days)
• Other symptoms have improved
• It has been at least 7 days since you started feeling sick
Heads up: People who will get a test to see if they are still contagious should follow different guidance. Also, people with weakened immune systems might have special guidance. Learn more: https://bit.ly/2wf7sS7

While local governments, businesses, schools, and healthcare facilities are preparing for the possibility of a COVID-19 outbreak in your community, you can too. Develop a plan for home-based actions. CDC Travel Notice Level 2: Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) globally: https://bit.ly/2IDv2KQ
Older adults and all people with chronic medical conditions are at greater risk of severe illness and should consider postponing nonessential travel.
If you are already traveling or will be traveling:
• Avoid contact with sick people
• Do not touch your face (especially eyes, nose, or mouth) with unwashed hands
• Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds or use a hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol
If you feel ill when you return, seek medical advice. Call ahead before you go to a doctor’s office or emergency room. Tell them about your recent travel and your symptoms.

• Avoid contact with sick people
• Do not touch your face (especially eyes, nose, or mouth) with unwashed hands
• Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds or use a hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol
If you feel ill when you return, seek medical advice. Call ahead before you go to a doctor’s office or emergency room. Tell them about your recent travel and your symptoms.

Caregivers: Help older adults and people with severe chronic health conditions protect themselves from COVID-19. This is especially important if you live in an area with ongoing spread of COVID-19. Learn what actions you should take to protect and prepare your loved ones: https://bit.ly/38ofRQc

Binge drinking increases the risk of injuries, fetal alcohol spectrum disorders, and some chronic diseases like breast cancer. Providers and patients can work together to address excessive alcohol use. Learn more in a new MMWR report: bit.ly/MMWRVA35

Travelers, especially older adults and those with underlying health issues, should defer all cruise ship travel worldwide. Cruise ship passengers are at increased risk of person-to-person spread of infectious diseases, including COVID-19. Like many other viruses, COVID-19 appears to spread more easily between people in close quarters such as aboard ships. Learn more: https://bit.ly/2TWsw7H

K-12 schools and childcare administrators: Support your school community by encouraging students and staff to take everyday preventive actions that prevent the spread of respiratory illnesses like COVID-19. Encourage students and staff to stay home when sick, appropriately cover coughs and sneezes, clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces and objects, and wash hands often. https://bit.ly/2TQdRLs

Practice everyday preventive actions to help keep yourself healthy, reduce exposures to COVID-19, and slow the spread of the disease. Preventive actions include:
• Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
• Stay home when you are sick.
• If you are sick call ahead to your medical provider before seeking medical care.
• Cover your coughs and sneezes with a tissue.
• Clean & disinfect frequently touched surfaces and objects daily.
• Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds.
Get more COVID-19 prevention tips: https://bit.ly/2TrXBRE.

Plan for potential changes at your workplace due to a COVID-19 outbreak in your community. Learn about your employer’s emergency operations plan and discuss sick-leave policies and telework options. Get more information: https://bit.ly/2TrXBRE.

Be prepared if your child’s school or childcare facility is temporarily dismissed due to a COVID-19 outbreak in your community. Learn about the emergency operations plan at your child’s school or childcare facility. Get more information: https://bit.ly/2TrXBRE.

Older adults & people with severe chronic medical conditions like heart, lung, or kidney disease seem to be at higher risk for more serious COVID-19 illness. If you are at high risk of serious illness, monitor your health and know the symptoms of COVID-19. Pay attention for potential COVID-19 symptoms including:
• fever,
• cough, and
• shortness of breath.
If you feel like you are developing symptoms, call your doctor.
If you develop emergency warning signs:
• difficulty breathing or shortness of breath
• persistent pain or pressure in the chest
• new confusion or inability to arouse
• bluish lips or face
Get medical attention immediately!
For information on people at high risk for serious illness from COVID-19, see https://bit.ly/38ofRQc

Older adults appear to be twice as likely to have serious COVID-19 illness. If you or those you care for are at higher risk and live in an area with ongoing community spread of COVID-19, you should:
• Stay at home as much as possible
• Keep away from others who are sick
• Limit close contact with others
• Wash your hands often

Shown here under a microscope, measles is a highly contagious virus that can lead to serious complications for young children.
Before the measles vaccination program began in 1963, an estimated 3 to 4 million people got the disease each year in the United States. Since then, cases have dropped by more than 99 percent – but outbreaks still occur.
You can protect your child against measles through on-time vaccination. Learn about measles and all 14 diseases that childhood vaccines prevent: https://bit.ly/2SZzOYY

Frostbite is a type of injury caused by freezing. It leads to a loss of feeling and color in the areas it affects, usually extremities such as the nose, ears, cheeks, chin, fingers, and toes. Frostbite can permanently damage the body, and severe cases can lead to amputation. http://bit.ly/37PLL85

For CDC medical officer Satish Pillai (right), speaking with DRC bus and taxi drivers, learning about the most popular markets, and tracing traffic patterns is all part of the effort to predict where Ebola is likely to spread next.
Because of the frequent travel between DRC and Uganda communities, Satish and the CDC Global Border Health Team take these steps to learn about patterns of migration and movement into, through, and out of these communities. Consequently, the team’s findings help Ugandan authorities make decisions about where to focus their efforts and resources to prevent spread of Ebola into Uganda.
Learn more about Satish: http://bit.ly/CDC-Pillai.

Anyone can get an infection, and almost any infection can lead to sepsis. This Sepsis Survivor Week, learn about steps you can take to prevent infections and get ahead of sepsis. http://bit.ly/2puh6ZY

Parents: As your children grow, they need help fighting diseases their immune systems cannot handle alone.
CDC’s easy-to-read immunization schedule can help you track which vaccines they need and when.
Check it out here: https://bit.ly/31Hy35E.

While CDC considers 2019-nCoV a serious situation and is taking preparedness measures, the immediate health risk in the U.S. from the new coronavirus (2019-nCoV) is thought to be low at this time, based on what we know. It’s still good to know the symptoms of 2019-nCoV, especially if you’ve recently returned from China. These include:
• Fever
• Cough
• Shortness of breath
For more information: https://bit.ly/38zjnYo

Prevention Specialists: Our Dating Matters® Toolkit provides strategies to promote respectful, healthy, nonviolent relationships among teens in your community. An evaluation found that Dating Matters Toolkit strategies are effective at preventing teen dating violence in middle school, when most kids start dating. Get everything you need to start your own prevention efforts: go.usa.gov/xyc7d

The latest FluView report shows New York City, Puerto Rico and 45 states experiencing high #flu activity. Adults older than 65 are experiencing the highest rates of hospitalization this flu season, followed by children younger than 5. CDC recommends prompt treatment with antivirals for people who have suspected flu infection and who are at high risk of serious flu complications. https://bit.ly/2TB7BIO

Black women under age 35 are twice as likely to be diagnosed with breast cancer as White women of the same age. Learn your risk so you can make proactive choices about your health: https://bit.ly/2ulk7BA

U.S. Department of Health and Human Services was live.
7 February at 17:47 ·
Secretary Alex Azar holds a press briefing with other members of President Donald J. Trump’s Coronavirus Task Force.

In January 2020, CDC and public health experts evaluated more than 600 persons thought to be at risk for 2019 novel coronavirus infection. Learn how they identified the first 11 people in the US with lab-confirmed novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV.) Learn more in CDC’s MMWR: http://bit.ly/2ugWRFo
Want to learn more about the novel (new) coronavirus (2019-nCoV)? Watch this series of videos for answers to frequently asked questions about 2019-nCoV. https://bit.ly/nCoV-Playlist

Getting high blood pressure under control isn’t always easy, but keep working on it—a healthier heart is worth the effort. Find tips and resources to help you stay on your journey to control. http://bit.ly/2iFB6U5
An antibiotic is the wrong tool to treat a virus, like those that cause a cold or flu. Ask your doctor about the best way to feel better while your body fights off a virus. http://bit.ly/2P5PNS5

Following a diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), flu fighter Jim Piette’s life changed dramatically when he was diagnosed with flu. Now, he works with American Lung Association to share his story in hopes of educating those around him about the risks of flu for those who have chronic health conditions.
Read more: https://bit.ly/2t8XsrU

Do you smoke? The U.S. Surgeon General wants you to know that quitting smoking can benefit your health at any age. If you’re ready to quit smoking, talk to your healthcare provider or call 1-800-QUIT-NOW. CDC.gov/CessationSGR #CessationSGR

A new CDC report provides details about the first cases of novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) identified in the U.S., as well as public health actions being taken to reduce the impact of this virus. http://bit.ly/2OpXAL4

The risk of shingles increases as you get older, and the illness can be severe and prolonged. Adults 50 and older should get the new shingles vaccines to protect against the disease. Learn more about when to get the new shingles vaccine and any possible side effects: https://bit.ly/2H71XsL

Coronaviruses are named for the crown-like spikes on the surface of the viruses. Human coronaviruses were first identified in the mid-1960s. The 2019 novel #coronavirus (2019-nCoV) is a new virus never before seen in people. It is different than other human coronaviruses that can cause the common cold.
For current information on the 2019-nCoV situation, visit https://bit.ly/2GT3MXQ

“People are real, they’re raw, and sometimes people are pretty confused and frustrated about how this outbreak is happening in their communities,” says CDC Ebola outbreak responder Christine Prue. Christine is part of CDC’s Social and Behavioral Sciences group, which plays an important role in the DRC Ebola response by listening to the opinions of DRC locals and making changes to support the needs of those affected by the disease.
Read about the changes they’ve made during the current response: http://bit.ly/BehaviorScience
Pictured: CDC’s Vivienne Walz, left, works with members of the DRC Red Cross to enter comments about the Ebola response from people in communities in and around Goma.

Always choose pasteurized milk over raw milk. Drinking raw milk comes with risks, especially for kids, older adults and people with weakened immune systems. Learn more about raw milk and why it’s risky: https://go.usa.gov/xdaW2

When you get flu and whooping cough (Tdap) vaccines during pregnancy, you give yourself and your baby protection against diseases that could lead to serious complications.
Yet, only 1 in 3 pregnant women receive both of these vaccines.
Talk to your healthcare professional to learn when you should receive these vaccines before your baby is born. http://bit.ly/2HMBDTW

Wondering if a mask would protect you from 2019-nCoV? CDC does not currently recommend the general American public use a facemask to protect against novel coronavirus. Only healthcare professionals caring for 2019-nCoV patients, people who are sick with 2019-nCoV, or in some cases people caring for patients who are sick with 2019-nCoV need precautions like a facemask to help limit their risk of spreading 2019-nCoV.
CDC always recommends everyday preventive actions, like staying home when you are sick and washing hands with soap and water, to help prevent the spread of respiratory illness.
https://bit.ly/37Ay6Cm

“When I began my CDC journey in 1990, I had no idea my love for communications and my interest in biology would merge in such a wonderful way,” says CDC health communication specialist Diana Toomer.
Today, Diana works with CDC’s national contact center, CDC-INFO, to provide accurate information on public health issues. Learn more about Diana: https://youtu.be/e-NXeXfPhI8
YOUTUBE.COM
I Am CDC - Diana Toomer

New in MMWR: Emergency department visits for suicidal thoughts or self-harm increased 25.5% from Jan 2017 - Dec 2018. Syndromic surveillance of this kind at state or local levels can help states and jurisdictions detect and respond to spikes or clusters of suicide-related emergency visits in near real-time. Learn more: bit.ly/2RVnQhj

CDC estimates that between Oct. 1 and Jan. 25, there were at least 19 million illnesses, 180,000 hospitalizations and 10,000 deaths caused by flu.
Learn more about the burden of flu: https://bit.ly/2AJe9L4.

2019-nCoV is a virus identified as the cause of the respiratory outbreak first detected in Wuhan, China. The virus is not spreading in the U.S., but you can help prevent the spread of respiratory illness by following everyday healthy habits. https://bit.ly/37Ay6Cm

Much is unknown about how 2019-nCoV, a new coronavirus, spreads. Currently there is no evidence to support spread of 2019-nCoV from packages or products imported from China. See what is known about the spread of coronaviruses: https://bit.ly/37KxL07

Outbreak response in action: CDC staff support the 2019-nCoV response in CDC’s Emergency Operations Center (EOC).
CDC activated its EOC to assist public health partners in responding to the novel (new) coronavirus outbreak first identified in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China. CDC works 24/7 to keep Americans safe from public health threats. For coronavirus updates and to learn more visit: http://www.cdc.gov/ncov
Don’t sideline your health! Keep hot foods hot and cold foods cold on the buffet to reduce the chance of food poisoning. Learn more game day food safety tips: https://go.usa.gov/xpNum.

Authorities in China identified the novel (new) coronavirus, which has resulted in several thousand confirmed cases in China. Additional cases have been identified in other international locations, including the U.S. Learn more about 2019-nCoV: www.cdc.gov/nCoV.

The novel coronavirus, 2019-nCoV, is not spreading in communities in the United States at this time. CDC is still working to contain the spread of the virus. See what is known about how 2019-nCoV spreads: https://bit.ly/37KxL07

In response to novel (new) coronavirus (2019-nCoV), the CDC issued federal quarantine orders to all 195 United States citizens who repatriated to the U.S. on January 29, 2020, under statutory authority of the Health and Human Services (HHS) Secretary. The quarantine will last 14 days from when the plane left Wuhan, China. This action is a precautionary and preventive step to maximize the containment of the virus in the interest of the health of the American public.
These individuals will continue to be housed at the March Air Reserve Base in Ontario, California. Medical staff will continue to monitor the health of each traveler. If an individual presents symptoms, medical care will be readily available.
While CDC continues to believe the immediate risk to the larger American public is low at this time, this legal order has been put in place as a necessary step to fully assess and care for these repatriated Americans, protecting them, their loved ones, and their communities. http://www.cdc.gov/ncov
34 million adults in the U.S. still smoke and are at risk of developing smoking-related diseases. Learn more in the new #CessationSGR from U.S. Surgeon General: www.CDC.gov/CessationSGR

The 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-NCoV) is causing an outbreak of respiratory illness with Wuhan City, China as the epicenter. Five cases in travelers from Wuhan have been detected in the U.S.; a 6th case has been reported in a close contact with travel history, suggesting person-to-person spread.
Genetic sequencing suggests the 2019-nCoV has its origins in bats, but now is able to spread from person to person. Experts believe this spread is happening mainly via respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs or sneezes, the same way flu and other respiratory viruses spread.
You can help stop the spread of viruses and prevent respiratory illnesses by practicing good health habits, like avoiding close contact with people who are sick and washing your hands often.
See answers to frequently asked questions about novel coronavirus: https://bit.ly/2Gpyrvx

In DRC, Ebola isn’t the only looming threat over the city of Goma. In the shadow of Mount Nyiragongo, one of the world’s most active volcanoes, Molly Patrick (right) and her team specialize in infection prevention and control (IPC) to tackle the current Ebola outbreak.
In many cases, IPC goes beyond basic tools like soap, water, and disinfectants—it means changing protocols and procedures to keep the virus out of healthcare facilities from the start.
Read more about how Molly uses her environmental engineering skills to help DRC fight Ebola: http://bit.ly/CDC-Patrick

Today CDC and the Illinois Department of Public Health confirmed diagnosis of 2019-nCoV infection in a person who did not travel from China, but who had close contact with a previously confirmed patient who did.
This is the first instance of person-to-person spread of 2019-nCoV in the United States, something which was expected to occur. This is an isolated occurrence at this time.
The 2019-nCoV virus is NOT spreading in the community. No additional precautions are recommended for the U.S. public at this time.
It’s likely that more U.S. cases of 2019-nCoV will be reported in the coming days and weeks as CDC and public health partners are on the look-out for these cases.
Learn more about 2019-nCoV at www.cdc.gov/nCoV.

By 1 year of age, most children try to mimic words you say. Why not try reading CDC’s free, new 1-year-old book “Baby’s Busy Day” to your baby and see if your little one can follow along? www.cdc.gov/AmazingBooks
True or false? Cervical Cancer is almost always caused by a virus.

Is health a taboo topic in your family? If so, there are still ways to start the conversation about your family health history—like finding that one relative who loves to chat. Find more tips for unlocking your family history: https://bit.ly/2RV2bHA

Did you know that sickle cell disease (SCD) affects millions of people throughout the world? It's important for healthcare providers, community workers, policy makers, and other SCD supporters to remember the many faces of this disease to help patients with SCD get timely and proper treatment. Watch the Many Faces Of Sickle Cell: http://bit.ly/2S0n02K

Infections are a leading cause of hospitalization and death among patients on dialysis, but they can be prevented. CDC’s new video highlights the patient perspective and why it is important to speak up and prevent infections. Watch and share this video to start the conversation in your clinic: https://bit.ly/2RZX9Z7

While CDC considers 2019-nCoV a serious situation and is taking preparedness measures, the immediate risk in the U.S. is considered low, based on what we know. Everyone should always take simple daily precautions to help prevent the spread of respiratory illnesses.
To learn more about prevention, see https://bit.ly/37Ay6Cm.

Sick with flu? Flu antiviral drugs work best when they are started as soon as possible after flu symptoms begin. Don't delay because your usual pharmacy doesn't have your medication. Use MedFinder to locate a pharmacy with your prescription in stock. https://bit.ly/2RkWEbq

CDC recommends travelers avoid all nonessential travel to China due to the ongoing 2019nCoV (coronavirus) outbreak. The outbreak is growing and there is limited access to adequate medical care in affected areas. https://bit.ly/2vpCbLn

In the Democratic Republic of Congo, the disease detectives of CDC’s Epidemic Intelligence Service (EIS) are proving their worth as they work to stop the second-largest Ebola outbreak in history.
“I don’t think I ever could have imagined a more incredible or more meaningful public health experience,” says CDC disease detective and Ebola responder Nirma Bustamante.
More on how EIS officers are helping out in DRC: http://bit.ly/Ebola-EIS
Pictured: EIS Officer Dean Sayre finds an alternative workspace outside the CDC office in Goma.

Elevated flu activity is expected to continue for weeks. According to the latest CDC FluView report, fifteen more pediatric flu deaths were reported to CDC this week, for a season total of 54. Learn the emergency warning signs of severe flu infection in children, and seek immediate medical attention if your child shows any of these symptoms: https://bit.ly/2ZPBiGY

CDC confirms 3 new cases of novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection in the U.S., 1 in Arizona & 2 in California, bring total U.S. cases to 5 in four states. All 5 U.S. cases to date had travelled from Wuhan, China. Precautions are being taken to prevent any further exposures. For more information, see https://bit.ly/2sYjXje

Did you know that radon is the second leading cause of lung cancer after cigarette smoking? Having your home tested is the only effective way to determine whether you and your family are at risk. Protect yourself and your family from radon. Learn more: http://bit.ly/2tsjgOV

When Carletta learned she had breast cancer at age 41, she brought the same strength and determination from her triathlon training to her cancer treatment. Listen to CDC’s podcast to find out how the power of positivity pulled her through: https://bit.ly/2PkSCQS
There’s more than one screening test for cervical cancer. Talk to your doctor about screening options and which one is right for you. https://bit.ly/2hwyjwh

While CDC considers 2019-nCoV a serious situation and is taking preparedness measures, the immediate risk to people in the U.S. is considered low, based on what we know. There are simple daily precautions to prevent the spread of respiratory illnesses that everyone should always take.
· Avoid touching eyes, nose, and mouth
· Avoid close contact with people who are sick
· Wash hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds
Learn more: https://bit.ly/38zjnYo

When antibiotics aren’t needed, they won’t help you, and the side effects could cause harm. Common side effects of antibiotics can include rash, dizziness, nausea, diarrhea, and yeast infections. Ask your doctor about the best treatment for your illness. http://bit.ly/35VoMI8
What are the symptoms of 2019 Novel Coronavirus? How does the virus spread? What is CDC doing about 2019-nCoV? Learn the answers to frequently asked questions here: https://bit.ly/2RnJxHK

Anyone can get strep throat. Doctors may do a quick test to see if a sore throat is strep throat. If so, antibiotics can help you feel better faster and prevent spreading it to others. Learn more. https://bit.ly/2BTSrF8

SALMONELLA OUTBREAK: 34 people in 9 states are sick after contact with small pet turtles. Even turtles that look healthy and clean can have germs that can make people sick. So it’s important to always wash your hands after touching your turtle or anything where it lives and roams. Do not buy turtles <4 inches long—they are illegal to sell. Learn more: https://go.usa.gov/xdgC2

CDC has confirmed the second human infection with the new 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) in the United States in a patient in Illinois who had recently traveled to Wuhan, China. Precautions are being taken to prevent any further exposures. However, CDC expects more cases are likely to be identified in the coming days.
While CDC considers this is a very serious public health threat, based on current information, the immediate health risk from 2019-nCoV to the general American public is considered low at this time. https://bit.ly/3apDji6

The myth that sickle cell disease (SCD) only affects African Americans may lead to delays in treatment for some patients with SCD. Healthcare providers can help prevent these delays by remembering that SCD has many faces. Get to know the many faces of sickle cell disease: https://bit.ly/37l9zRz

When was your last tetanus shot? All adults need a booster every 10 years. Now you can get either Tdap or Td for protection against harmful tetanus bacteria that live in the environment. http://bit.ly/TdapUpdate

It’s never too late to quit smoking. No matter how long you’ve been smoking or how old you are, quitting smoking can improve your health. A new report from U.S. Surgeon General highlights tools and resources to help you quit: www.CDC.gov/CessationSGR #CessationSGR

Each year, thousands of people are diagnosed with cancers, including cervical cancer, caused by HPV infections.
HPV infections can cause 6 types of cancer. HPV vaccination could protect your child from these cancers before they ever have a chance to develop.

Check out CDC’s new infographics about how Antibiotic Resistance can spread across settings. It is a One Health problem & can affect our progress in health care, food production, & life expectancy. Learn more: https://bit.ly/2toduOS

A new video from NIOSH National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health illustrates how black lung, caused by the inhalation of too much coal dust, is occurring in younger miners. We continue to raise awareness of the personal costs of the disease and hope to motivate miners to participate in free and confidential health screenings. View our new video here: https://go.usa.gov/xdrhc.

According to new data, too many people in the United States are not physically active. Inactivity differs by state, race, and ethnicity. Join CDC’s Active People, Healthy Nation℠ initiative to help 27 million Americans become more active by 2027. bit.ly/activepeople

Dr. Henry Lin has made it his mission as a healthcare professional to educate others about the dangers of flu following the loss of his healthy 7-year-old son. By sharing his story, he hopes to help others realize that even healthy children and adults can be severely impacted by a vaccine-preventable disease like flu.
Read more: https://bit.ly/2NyBhCv

CDC has confirmed the first human infection with 2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) in the United States has been detected in the State of Washington in a person who had recently traveled to Wuhan, China. A lab test developed at CDC was used to confirm this patient’s illness was caused by the recently discovered 2019 novel coronavirus first identified in Wuhan City, China. Precautions are being taken to prevent any further exposures.
While person-to-person spread with this new coronavirus in Asia raises CDC’s level of concern, the agency continues to believe the risk of #2019-nCoV to the American public at large remains low at this time. Learn more about what CDC is doing to respond: https://bit.ly/3apDji6

Public health professionals and students: We are LIVE now with today’s Public Health Grand Rounds broadcast on the Emerging Role of Pathogen Genomics in Public Health. Leave your questions for our presenters in the comments below.

According to the latest CDC in-season flu burden estimates, there were at least 13 million illnesses, 120,000 hospitalizations and 6,600 deaths caused by flu between Oct. 1 and Jan. 11. With flu activity expected to continue for weeks, it’s not too late to protect yourself and your family from the potentially life-threatening consequences of a flu infection with a flu vaccine. Learn more: https://bit.ly/2AJe9L4

Public health professionals and students: Join our Public Health Grand Rounds Facebook Live today at 1pm ET to hear experts discuss how advanced molecular detection technologies are being applied in public health, and their future uses. https://bit.ly/2Rlur4i

Did you know that January is One Health Awareness Month? One Health recognizes that human health is connected to the health of animals and the environment. CDC uses a One Health approach to public health by bringing together experts in many areas to protect health for people, animals, and our shared environment. http://bit.ly/OHFeature

For NIOSH National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health research psychologist Jessica Streit, the field of public health wasn’t in her line of sight until she became a research assistant for a team of stress researchers. “Helping those NIOSH experts opened my eyes to the serious ways work can affect our physical and psychological health,” says Jessica.
Learn more about Jessica’s work at CDC to advance the global stress solution: https://youtu.be/BZTrn6CghQ0

Spending time outdoors this winter? Ticks that bite people can come out on warm winter days. Protect yourself: Use insect repellents, do tick checks, and take showers after being outside. bit.ly/Avoid_Ticks
Did you know cervical cancer is preventable? Learn how to protect yourself and share your knowledge with the women you love. https://bit.ly/2hwyjwh
Many adults report not participating in any physical activities over the last month. New maps show that inactivity differs by state, race, and ethnicity. Learn more: bit.ly/inactivitymaps

Birth defects are common, costly, and critical conditions that can have a profound effect on families. Not all birth defects can be prevented, but there are things you can do to get ready for pregnancy and help give your baby a healthy start in life: http://bit.ly/2NC8xc1.

Did you know? The HPV vaccine protects against the types of HPV that most commonly cause cancer. You can help protect your child from certain types of cancer later in life by getting them vaccinated against HPV. Learn more. http://bit.ly/2iupQ1C

In response to an outbreak in China caused by a novel (new) coronavirus, CDC will begin health screenings of travelers arriving on direct or connecting flights from Wuhan, China at 3 US airports: JFK, SFO, & LAX. Health screenings of travelers arriving from Wuhan is part of a layered approach used with other public health measures already in place to slow and reduce possible spread of #2019nCOV into the United States. https://bit.ly/2v13H1J

OUTBREAK UPDATE: As of 1/14, 2,668 cases of hospitalized e-cigarette, or vaping, product use-associated lung injury (EVALI) or deaths have been reported from all 50 states, DC, & 2 US territories (Puerto Rico & USVI). 60 deaths were confirmed in 27 states & DC. www.cdc.gov/lunginjury

Start the year off strong by saying YES to something outside your comfort zone—like learning your breast cancer risk. Discover the risk factors and talk to your doctor if any apply to you: https://bit.ly/2YUJINb

Advanced molecular detection (AMD) integrates the latest next-generation genomic sequencing technologies with bioinformatics and epidemiology expertise to help us find, track, and stop disease-causing pathogens faster than ever before. Watch Public Health Grand Rounds, Live on Facebook, Jan 21, at 1pm ET to learn more. http://bit.ly/35XTm3e

Fever, aches, and chills. Do you have a cold or flu? While both are contagious respiratory illnesses, flu can be very serious.
Learn the difference: https://bit.ly/2xi9Qo8

ROMAINE OUTBREAK UPDATE: The outbreak of E. coli infections linked to romaine lettuce grown in Salinas, Calif., is over – 167 people got sick from 27 states.
We are lifting our advice to avoid romaine lettuce from Salinas, Calif. Romaine from this region is now past its shelf life, and the growing region has finished harvesting for the season. Romaine lettuce currently being sold and served in stores and restaurants was grown in other regions. Read the latest information: https://go.usa.gov/xpXg8

Worried your sore throat may be strep? Viruses, bacteria, and allergens can all cause a sore throat. Strep throat is an infection in the throat and tonsils caused by group A Streptococcus bacteria. A quick test by a doctor can determine if your sore throat is strep. http://bit.ly/2eer7FZ

As a CDC disease detective, Alexis Peterson has traveled the globe surveilling motor vehicle crashes, opioid overdoses, and Zika virus infections.
“I learned early on that the best scientists are often those who don’t limit their interests to a narrow field of research, but rather look for multiple approaches and areas to work in,” Alexis says.
Learn more about how Alexis helps to keep the world safe and healthy: https://youtu.be/Zp1gwrZjcRw

I Am CDC - Alexis Peterson

Preliminary estimates for the number of flu illnesses prevented by vaccination during the 2018-2019 flu season were released last week. CDC estimates that 4.4 million flu illnesses, 58,000 flu hospitalizations and 3,500 flu deaths were prevented by the flu vaccine during 2018-2019. Learn more: https://bit.ly/3abYrbG

CDC recommends that you should not use e-cigarette, or vaping, products that contain THC, particularly from informal sources. Data suggest these products play a major role in the current lung injury outbreak. Learn more: www.cdc.gov/lunginjury

The National ALS Registry collects and analyzes information from people living with ALS in the United States, helping researchers understand who gets ALS and why. By joining the Registry, you can help us answer these important questions. Visit: cdc.gov/als.

New Year’s challenge: Learn your family history of cancer. Find out 1️⃣ if any close relatives have had cancer, 2️⃣ what kind of cancer, and 3️⃣ at what age they were diagnosed. Learn why: https://bit.ly/2Ph2jzI.

Flu fighter Chris Miller came close to losing his daughter to flu. Now, he’s sharing his story with people who are hesitant about getting flu vaccine to illustrate the seriousness of flu and help prevent other families from experiencing a similar experience.

Risk factors for youth violence can be invisible or in plain sight. Together, we can address risks and stop this problem before it starts. Get more info: http://bit.ly/2wYt2JV
Flu is one type of infection that can lead to sepsis. This flu season, protect yourself and your family by getting your annual flu vaccine. http://bit.ly/2puh6ZY

Adults 50 and older should get two doses of the new shingles vaccine, as it provides strong protection against the disease. Here’s what to expect when you get the new shingles vaccine: https://bit.ly/34QtkiY

A new coronavirus may be the cause of a pneumonia outbreak being investigated in China. CDC is closely monitoring the situation & has stood up emergency response system in case it’s needed. Learn more: https://bit.ly/2FIrzJn

Laboratory professionals: Submit an abstract for the 16th CDC International Symposium on Biosafety! This year’s theme is The Power of Risk Assessment: Laboratory Safety and Security for Clinical, Public Health, Research, and Animal Care. Last day to submit is January 15, 2020. More information: http://bit.ly/2xHRSLI

Hepatitis C is a liver infection caused by the hepatitis C virus (HCV). Rates of hepatitis C have increased over the past decade and most people have become infected by sharing needles or other equipment to inject drugs. Since many of those infected may not be aware of their infection, getting tested is the only way to know if you have hepatitis C. Learn more about hepatitis C. http://bit.ly/2FAXXh3

This flu season, Louisiana saw unusually early flu activity in children caused mostly by flu B viruses, which now predominate nationally. From an investigation, CDC and Louisiana health officials found out that illnesses were mostly mild, but severe complications and one pediatric death caused by an influenza B infection did occur. Read more in MMWR: bit.ly/FluLA2020
During National Cervical Cancer Awareness Month, let’s raise awareness and remind all the women in our lives that cervical cancer is preventable. https://bit.ly/2hwyjwh

CDC is committed to providing guidance to healthcare professionals on best practices for optimal STD care. A new report, Recommendations for Providing Quality STD Clinical Services, provides a roadmap: https://go.usa.gov/xpAYT.

Be aware cold temperatures can lead to illness and injury. Be prepared by wearing warm clothing and limiting your time outside. Find more information to keep you safe this winter on the NIOSH National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health website. https://go.usa.gov/xpRzz

During the winter, you make sure your sons and daughters are bundled up to keep warm in the cold weather.
You can also make sure they’re protected against 6 types of cancer. Check with their doctor to make sure your 11-12-year-olds are up to date on the HPV vaccine. https://bit.ly/2hvcXEf

While it appears that vitamin E acetate is associated with e-cigarette, or vaping, product use-associated lung injury (EVALI), many different substances & product sources are being investigated, and there may be more than one cause. Check CDC’s website for the latest EVALI information. www.cdc.gov/lunginjury

While teaching math in Guinea for Peace Corps, Dana Schneider noticed serious health issues in her village, leading her to go back to school for public health. Since then, Dana became a CDC health scientist and has dispatched multiple times to help respond to Ebola and plague outbreaks in Africa. Read about Dana’s most recent experience responding to the current DRC Ebola outbreak: http://bit.ly/CDC-Schneider

Women: Folic acid is an important vitamin that can help with the development of your future baby’s brain.
This Folic Acid Awareness Week, make sure consuming 400 mcg of folic acid each day is high on your to-do list, along with getting vaccinated.
Talk with your doctor to make sure you are up to date on your vaccines. https://bit.ly/2tWJRmg
January is National Stalking Awareness Month. Share this definition of stalking to help recognize and prevent it. go.usa.gov/xp5CX

Quitting smoking for good is not easy, but it is possible. You can get customized help to quit smoking by phone, text, web, or with an app on your smartphone. Get inspired to quit: http://bit.ly/2F45rZL

This new year, make plans for staying healthy. That should include ensuring you are up to date on your vaccines.
Check out this tool to get a list of vaccines to discuss with your healthcare professional at your next visit: https://bit.ly/2sXxtyT

In the United States, more than 250,000 people seek care in a hospital each year because of pneumonia. Unfortunately, about 50,000 people die from the disease each year in the United States. Learn about preventing pneumonia. https://bit.ly/2REyqYe

Eating fish or shellfish from waters with a harmful algal bloom can make you sick. Check for local advisories from your state government before collecting shellfish. Learn more: https://go.usa.gov/xVh2E
New Year’s Resolution: Support your pregnant partner in avoiding alcohol use during pregnancy. There is no known safe amount of alcohol use during pregnancy. https://bit.ly/2G96U2P

Start your year off right by scheduling your annual checkup. Talk to your doctor about any new info you learned about your family health history over the holidays and how it might affect your risk for breast cancer. https://bit.ly/2qyQXxm

OUTBREAK UPDATE: As of 12/27, 2,561 hospitalized cases of lung injury associated with use of e-cigarette, or vaping, products or deaths have been reported from all 50 states, DC, & 2 US territories (Puerto Rico & USVI). 55 deaths were confirmed in 27 states & DC. www.cdc.gov/lunginjury

At least 1.7 million adults in the United States develop sepsis each year, and nearly 270,000 die as a result. Keep yourself and your loved ones healthy by preventing infections that can lead to this life-threatening condition. http://bit.ly/2puh6ZY
Vaccinate your son or daughter against HPV when they are 11 or 12 to help protect them against six types of cancer later in life. Learn more: https://bit.ly/2DRzqEm
CDC wishes you and your family a happy and healthy New Year!

Whether you started smoking last year, last decade, or last century, it’s not too late to quit. New Year 2020 is the time to try again and look towards a healthier future. Find free resources and support to start your quit journey: http://bit.ly/2F45rZL

Data show that cases of emergency department visits associated with possible e-cigarette, or vaping, product use-associated lung injury (EVALI) are declining. Despite progress in the investigation and response, the outbreak has not ended, and clinicians and the public must remain vigilant.
Adults who continue to use e-cigarette, or vaping, products should carefully monitor themselves and see a healthcare provider immediately if they develop EVALI-related symptoms including cough, shortness of breath, chest/stomach pain, nausea, or vomiting. Learn more: www.cdc.gov/lunginjury

Flu can come on suddenly, causing fever, coughing, and a sore throat. Most people who get flu recover in less than two weeks, but some people develop life-threatening complications.
Learn the symptoms of flu: https://bit.ly/39nTOL6

Stretching your legs straight out in front of you and flexing your ankles toward you is a simple way to move your legs frequently on long trips to keep the blood flowing. This stretch and others can help prevent blood clots during long-distance trips. Learn more simple exercises here: https://bit.ly/36GjwIs

Make it a New Year’s resolution to protect your family against serious, preventable diseases.
Use CDC’s interactive guide to find out which vaccines they may need: https://bit.ly/2H0TDdT
How can you take steps to prevent breast cancer in 2⃣0⃣2⃣0⃣? Start by learning your family health history. Here’s how: https://bit.ly/37tQkWi

Spending time outdoors over the holidays? Ticks that bite people can come out on warm winter days. Protect yourself: Use insect repellents, do tick checks, and take showers after being outside. bit.ly/Avoid_Ticks

Did you know that young children are at a higher risk for developing serious complications from flu?
It’s not too late to get your little one the protection they need with a flu vaccine. https://bit.ly/2PLGiJH
Cooking at home? Make handwashing the first step in any meal prep. Wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds to keep you and your family healthy. https://go.usa.gov/xVNmA

Choose food and drink carefully so you don’t spend your holidays on the 🚽! Travelers’ diarrhea is the most common travel-related illness.
Only eat fully-cooked food and eat fruits and vegetables you peel yourself. Drink bottled, factory sealed beverages, and avoid ice. For more safe travel tips visit: https://bit.ly/2ATfgIN

Beware of offers for overseas animal adoptions. Victims pay shipping fees up front but never receive the animal. Often, they learn the animal never existed, or that the animal, like a monkey, is illegal to import as a pet. If a deal sounds too good to be true, it probably is. Learn more: https://bit.ly/33UMBhN

Flu fighter Angie Wehrkamp lost her healthy, 2-year-old daughter to flu. Now, she’s working to raise awareness about the importance of annual flu vaccination.
Read more: https://bit.ly/2Mo4ZcL

When you hit the road this holiday season, remember to choose safe transportation. Always wear your seat belt and make sure your kids are in age-appropriate car seats. Learn more travel tips at: https://bit.ly/2ATfgIN

Parents: Did you know that handwashing can help prevent 1 in 5 respiratory illnesses and 1 in 3 diarrheal illnesses? Teach your kids to make handwashing a healthy habit wherever they go! https://go.usa.gov/xV9Td

Do you know your breast cancer risk? Learning what cancers run in your family is a great place to start. Use family holiday gatherings to get the information you need about cancer in your family. https://bit.ly/335QpfK

Since 1980, CDC’s flagship workforce development program, the Field Epidemiology Training Program (FETP), has trained over 16,000 disease detectives in more than 70 countries. FETP graduates have been key players in major health crisis around the world including Ebola, Zika, Polio, Nipah virus, and natural disaster recovery. Check out this profile on FETP grads from around the world to learn more. https://go.usa.gov/xpmgp

Today, CDC releases four reports on the ongoing e-cigarette, or vaping, product use-associated lung injury (EVALI) outbreak. Key findings confirm that new cases in the outbreak are on the decline. However, cases continue to be reported as new data reinforce the link between Vitamin E Acetate and EVALI. CDC recommends that healthcare providers treating EVALI patients provide follow-up soon after hospital discharge. Learn more. https://bit.ly/2Mfwh58

Hey teachers! Summer is around the corner. Join us and train with CDC scientists for 5 days this summer and develop dynamic STEM curriculum for your students. Apply to CDC’s Science Ambassador Fellowship for a unique professional development opportunity! http://bit.ly/SAFapplication

About 1 in 500 babies are born deaf or hard of hearing in the United States each year. CDC’s early hearing detection and intervention program helps to make sure they receive the services they need to thrive. See the most recent data and learn how we are doing. https://bit.ly/2Z7HqKl

OUTBREAK UPDATE: As of 12/17, 2,506 hospitalized cases of lung injury associated with use of e-cigarette, or vaping, products have been reported from all 50 states, DC, & 2 US territories (Puerto Rico & USVI). 54 deaths were confirmed in 27 states & DC. www.cdc.gov/lunginjury

As 2020 approaches, CDC remains vigilant to combat urgent threats. Health threats can arise at any time – at home or abroad – and CDC’s most important mission is always to protect the health of the American public from the unexpected. Take a look back at some of the health threats that made headlines this past year. https://bit.ly/35CNahH

When you are pregnant, you are at higher risk for complications from vaccine-preventable diseases due to changes in your immune system.
As you spend time with family and friends this holiday season, make sure you and your family are up to date on their flu and Tdap vaccines to keep you and your baby protected.
Learn why vaccines are an important part of a healthy pregnancy: https://bit.ly/2tWJRmg

FOOD SAFETY ALERT: CDC is investigating an outbreak of 7 Listeria infections linked to hard-boiled eggs. CDC has advice for people at higher risk for Listeria (pregnant women, adults 65 and older, people with weakened immune systems):
Throw away any store-bought hard-boiled eggs or products containing hard-boiled eggs, such as egg salad, now in your home.
Before you buy, order, or eat any other products with hard-boiled eggs, confirm with the store or restaurant that they do not use hard-boiled eggs produced by Almark Foods.
For more information about the outbreak, visit: https://go.usa.gov/xpGfv

OUTBREAK NOTICE: CDC and partners are investigating an outbreak of multidrug-resistant Campylobacter infections linked to pet store puppies. Read our advice to protect yourself and care for your puppy: https://go.usa.gov/xpfts

Get your dog a vaccine to protect them from rabies. Dogs need a valid rabies vaccination certificate to enter the United States when coming from a rabies high-risk country. Find out which countries are high-risk: www.cdc.gov/dogtravel.

Data suggests e-cigarette, or vaping, products that contain THC are linked to most cases of lung injury. While the investigation to identify the specific compound or ingredient causing these lung injuries continues, people should consider refraining from use of all e-cigarette, or vaping, products. www.cdc.gov/lunginjury

According to the latest surveillance report from CDC’s FluView, flu activity has been elevated nationally for 5 weeks now, with several more weeks of elevated flu activity expected this season. Over the past 5 years, flu seasons have ranged from 11 to 21 weeks long, with an average of about 18 weeks. Find out if flu is spreading in your state, and keep up with the latest in flu surveillance with CDC’s FluView: https://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/

Heading to a holiday party? Try reaching for a festively flavored sparkling water instead of an alcoholic drink. Learn how avoiding or cutting back on alcohol can lower your breast cancer risk: https://bit.ly/35pU6yl

More than 3 million Americans are living with bleeding disorders. One of these disorders, von Willebrand disease, is found in 1 of every 100 people. Read stories of two women living with VWD: https://bit.ly/34fuwez

Breathing in toxins from red tides can irritate your throat and lungs. Check for local advisories on your health department’s website before you visit the beach in areas with possible or ongoing red tides, such as the Gulf of Mexico. Learn more: https://go.usa.gov/xVh4S

OUTBREAK UPDATE: As of 12/10, 2,409 cases of lung injury associated with use of e-cigarette, or vaping, products have been reported from 50 states, DC, & 2 US territories (Puerto Rico & USVI). 52 deaths were confirmed in 26 states & DC. www.cdc.gov/lunginjury

Don’t give food poisoning as a gift this holiday season! When preparing food, wash your hands properly and cook food to a safe internal temperature to kill germs. Learn other tips for avoiding food poisoning while preparing holiday meals: https://go.usa.gov/xpZ9q

Vaccination is an important part of maintaining a heart healthy lifestyle. Get your flu shot now to protect yourself from serious flu-related complications. Learn more about heart disease and flu: https://bit.ly/2nXADVq

Meet real-life laboratory hero, James Pusavat, a medical laboratory technician. He protected hospital staff and the community around him by accurately diagnosing a rare contagious disease and saving a patient’s life in his hometown. Read his story at: http://bit.ly/2XtImqK.

CDC is hiring! Apply to join CDC as our Chief Information Security Officer. As member of the Senior Executive Service (SES), you will influence the direction of innovation in the federal government and lead the next generation of public servants. Apply by January 17. https://bit.ly/2rYuD0D

About 4 in 5 people who could benefit from a medicine called PrEP that prevents HIV aren’t getting it. Learn more about how PrEP can help end the epidemic in CDC’s recent Vital Signs report. http://bit.ly/VitalSignsHIV

When Bethany Drapeau lost her daughter to flu complications, she realized the importance of an annual flu vaccination for everyone, including healthy children and adults.
Her story could help protect your family and loved ones. Read more: https://bit.ly/2t5jCen

NEW OUTBREAK: CDC and partners are investigating an outbreak of 8 E. coli infections linked to Fresh Express Sunflower Crisp Chopped Salad Kits.
Check your fridge for this salad kit and do not eat it.
How to ID affected salads: UPC 0 71279 30906 4, beginning with lot code Z, and a best-before date up to and including 07DEC19. This information is printed on the front of the bag in the top right corner.
Read the latest information: https://go.usa.gov/xpVUP

Cleaning your hands with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand sanitizer reduces the spread of germs to others. This National Handwashing Awareness Week, protect yourself and your loved ones from infections that can lead to the life-threatening condition called sepsis. http://bit.ly/2DQd4ne

Today’s report on nationwide data shows that e-cigarette, or vaping, product use–associated lung injury (EVALI) patients tend to be young adults, white men, and that 80% report using THC-containing product brands. CDC recommends not using e-cigarette, or vaping, products that contain THC. http://bit.ly/MMWREVALI

OUTBREAK UPDATE: As of 12/03, 2,291 cases of lung injury associated with use of e-cigarette, or vaping, products have been reported from 50 states, DC, & 2 US territories (Puerto Rico & USVI). 48 deaths were confirmed in 25 states & DC. www.cdc.gov/lunginjury
Two large studies show you may be able to reduce your risk for Alzheimer’s disease and other dementias by leading a healthy lifestyle. Listen to this new podcast to learn more: bit.ly/CDCalzpodcast

“I always felt that identity with the country,” says Congo-born CDC photographer Jim Gathany. Born in a town near DRC’s Atlantic coast, Jim is staunchly rooting for his home country in its battle against an Ebola outbreak that has killed more than 2,000 people.
Read more of Jim’s story: http://bit.ly/CDC-Gathany

Ending the HIV epidemic starts with HIV testing. 154,000 Americans with HIV don’t know they have it and need to be tested so they can start treatment. Find out more in CDC’s new Vital Signs report: http://bit.ly/VitalSignsHIV

Older adult drivers: you may be at an increased risk of a car crash due to certain medical conditions. Stay safe on the road by seeing your doctor regularly, reviewing your medications, and considering potential alternatives to driving. Get more safety tips: https://go.usa.gov/xpBcM.

December 3rd is International Day of Persons with Disabilities. Identifying developmental delays and disabilities as early as possible provides children with the support they need. If you are concerned about your infant or toddler’s development, contact your state or territory’s Early Intervention program at www.cdc.gov/FindEI.
Make handwashing the first step in any recipe. Washing hands with soap and water when preparing or eating food is key to staying healthy. https://go.usa.gov/xVNmA

December 1 is World AIDS Day. We are working to end the HIV epidemic, community by community. Today, we unite with others around the world to prevent HIV, support people with HIV, and remember those who have lost their lives to AIDS. Resources from CDC can be found at http://bit.ly/CDC_WAD. #WAD2019 #WorldAIDSDayUS

Diabetes doesn’t just affect your blood sugar – it affects your entire body.
Learn about the complications – and how to avoid them: https://bit.ly/2l8cLqP

Being a great cook includes handwashing! Everything you touch has germs that stay on your hands and can spread to foods or surfaces. Wash your hands while preparing food to keep you and your family healthy. https://go.usa.gov/xVNmA

Thinking about getting pregnant? Share and discuss your family’s health history with your partner. Genetic health conditions, such as sickle cell, hemophilia, and thalassemia are passed in families. Learn more about these blood disorders: https://bit.ly/2qPDC3S

While teaching math in Guinea for Peace Corps, Dana Schneider noticed serious health issues in her village, leading her to go back to school for public health. Since then, Dana became a CDC health scientist and has dispatched multiple times to help respond to Ebola and plague outbreaks in Africa. Read about Dana’s most recent experience responding to the current DRC Ebola outbreak: http://bit.ly/CDC-Schneider
Heat all Thanksgiving leftovers to 165°F before eating to make sure they’re safe to eat. Use a food thermometer to check. Learn more: https://go.usa.gov/xyuBe

CDC recommends that you do not use e-cigarette, or vaping, products that contain THC, as data suggests these products play a major role in the current lung injury outbreak. Need help quitting? Visit https://findtreatment.gov.

While spending time with family this Thanksgiving, remember to think about the health of those around you, especially those at high risk of developing serious flu complications.
Older adults, young children, and anyone with certain chronic health conditions are all at high risk of developing serious flu complications.
Protect yourself and your loved ones by getting a flu vaccine now.
Learn more about groups at high risk: https://bit.ly/2fexoUC

OUTBREAK UPDATE 11/26: CDC and partners continue to investigate an outbreak of 67 E. coli infections linked to romaine lettuce grown in Salinas, Calif., and distributed nationally. If you have romaine lettuce or products that contain romaine with labels saying “grown in Salinas,” don’t eat them. This advice includes all brands and use-by dates. Throw them away. Greenhouse grown and hydroponic lettuce are not included in the warning. If the lettuce isn’t labeled with a growing region, or if you don’t know whether your salad mix or wrap contains romaine, don’t eat them. Read the latest information: https://go.usa.gov/xpXg8

You can say “cheers” to your health this Thanksgiving by NOT drinking alcohol. Make this holiday a bit healthier by sticking to only one drink per day or having none at all. Learn how this can lower your breast cancer risk: https://bit.ly/2PqP3J2

The holidays are a time for thankfulness. Many lives have been protected against serious, preventable diseases thanks to vaccination.
Parents, make sure you know which vaccines your child needs to stay healthy: https://bit.ly/2QPg1ek

Did you know that most cancers caused by HPV don’t have a recommended screening test to detect it early?
HPV vaccine can prevent more than 32,000 cases of cancer every year.
Learn more about how getting HPV vaccine at age 11-12 can protect your child later on in life: https://bit.ly/2DRzqEm

FREE CE: Watch our latest Public Health Grand Rounds on the effects of PFAS exposure. Go Beyond the Data as CDC’s Dr. John Iskander and Dr. Rachel Rogers discuss current PFAS research needs. https://bit.ly/2O2K5jJ

Serese Marotta lost her five-year-old son to the H1N1 flu pandemic in 2009. Now Serese fights flu on a daily basis by working with Families Fighting Flu, an organization dedicated to saving lives and reducing the flu-related hospitalizations of children and their families.
“This infectious disease is not ‘just the flu’ it robs families of their loved ones every year.”
Learn more about Serese’s story and the passion and dedication she brings to the fight against flu: https://bit.ly/33oHczm

Today is the International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women and Children. Our Violence Against Children Surveys use science to fuel action and help prevent violence in countries around the world. Learn more: go.usa.gov/xVMjm

Turkey Tips:
✔Thaw safely (in the fridge, microwave, or cold water changed every 30 minutes)
✔Use a food thermometer to make sure your turkey cooks to an internal temperature of at least 165°F
✔Refrigerate leftovers within 2 hours
Get more turkey tips: https://go.usa.gov/xpqHG

E. COLI OUTBREAK: CDC’s warning not to eat romaine lettuce from the Salinas, Calif., growing region includes ALL types of romaine (whole head, hearts of romaine, salad mixes, organic, etc.). Do not eat any romaine lettuce if the label says it was grown in Salinas or does not say where the lettuce was grown. Read more about the investigation: https://go.usa.gov/xpXg8

CDC found vitamin E acetate, an additive in some THC-containing products, in lung fluid samples from patients w/ e-cigarette, or vaping, product use associated lung injury. Protect your health: avoid THC-containing products, esp from informal sources. cdc.gov/lunginjury

FOOD SAFETY ALERT: Do not eat, serve, or sell any romaine lettuce from the Salinas, Calif., growing region; it may be contaminated with E. coli O157.
Most romaine lettuce products are labeled with the growing region. If the packaging has “Salinas” on the label in any form (whether alone or with the name of another location), do not eat, sell, or serve it. If you can’t tell where the romaine lettuce was grown, don’t eat, sell, or serve it.
Read more about the E. coli outbreak investigation: https://go.usa.gov/xpXg8

It’s important to remember all year long that antibiotics are only needed for treating infections caused by bacteria, like pneumonia and UTIs. When antibiotics aren’t needed, they won’t help you, and their side effects could cause harm. Talk to your doctor about the best way to treat your illness. http://bit.ly/2AEuUHV

OUTBREAK UPDATE: As of 11/20, 2290 cases of lung injury associated with use of e-cigarette, or vaping, products have been reported from 49 states (all but Alaska), DC, & 2 US territories (Puerto Rico & USVI). 47 deaths were confirmed in 25 states & DC. www.cdc.gov/lunginjury
No matter how old you are, quitting smoking is good for your health. Join the #GreatAmericanSmokeout and commit to quitting or supporting someone you love who is trying to quit. http://bit.ly/2O8tb39
When people living with ALS join the National ALS Registry, they can make a difference. Together, we can better understand ALS, one person at a time. www.cdc.gov/als

As a fellow in the Presidential Management Fellows Program at CDC, you’ll have a unique opportunity to gain leadership experience by working with senior-level public health program managers and directors. Apply November 25 to December 15! http://bit.ly/CDCPMF
Are chitlins part of your holiday tradition? Chitlins can carry germs that cause food poisoning, so follow these tips to keep safe: https://go.usa.gov/xp923

GROUND BEEF RECALL: Recalled ground beef sold in California may be contaminated with Salmonella linked to a foodborne disease outbreak. Almost 90% of people in the outbreak have been hospitalized and 1 person died. Find out how to identify recalled products: https://go.usa.gov/xp4jz

Public health professionals and students: We are LIVE now with today’s Public Health Grand Rounds broadcast on addressing current research needs and the many unknowns about PFAS. Leave your questions for our presenters in the comments below.

Educators: Are your students interested in a career in public or animal health? CDC has released additional STEM classroom activities for K-12 teachers for use with the “Junior Disease Detectives: Operation Outbreak” graphic novel. These classroom activities introduce students to the real-life disease detective work conducted by CDC professionals. While supplies last, free print copies of the graphic novel are available for online ordering. Learn more: https://bit.ly/2KBw8Z8.

There are several important steps you can take to stay healthy while managing your diabetes.
This Diabetes Awareness Month, make sure you know the importance of vaccination: https://bit.ly/2GMFJYV.

It’s U.S. Antibiotic Awareness Week! Antibiotics save lives and are critical tools for treating infections, like those that can lead to sepsis. When antibiotics aren’t needed – like for a cold – they won’t help you, and their side effects could cause harm. Serious side effects can include C. difficile infection, which can cause deadly diarrhea. Talk to your doctor about the best way to treat your illness. http://bit.ly/2AEuUHV
Today is #WorldDayofRemembrance for traffic victims. Road traffic crashes kill more than 1.35 million people each year. Learn road safety tips for home and abroad: https://go.usa.gov/xpYvR
Living with diabetes? Did you know artificial sweeteners can spike your blood sugar? Here are nine more surprising triggers: https://bit.ly/2lcjh4j

Symptoms of lung injury associated with use of e-cigarette, or vaping, products include: cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, diarrhea, fever, chills, & weight loss. Get care if you use these products & have symptoms. www.cdc.gov/lunginjury
Changes in our climate can impact everyone’s health, but some people are at greater risk. Learn how the changing climate can affect your community’s health, and what you can do. http://bit.ly/32QUQMd

OUTBREAK UPDATE: As of 11/13, 2172 cases of lung injury associated with use of e-cigarette, or vaping, products have been reported from 49 states (all but Alaska), DC, & 2 U.S. territories (Puerto Rico & USVI). 42 deaths were confirmed in 24 states & DC. www.cdc.gov/lunginjury

In 2018, nearly 20% of adults in the United States reported using some form of tobacco product, including either cigarettes, cigars, e-cigarettes, smokeless tobacco, water pipes, hookahs, and/or pipes. Read more in the latest CDC MMWR: http://bit.ly/MMWR_Tobacco

Thank you for joining us today for a LIVE panel discussion as part of American Indian & Alaska Native Heritage Month. We’ve brought together experts to discuss what steps CDC and we, as individuals, can take to prevent violence in American Indian and Alaska Native communities.

According to the National Institute of Justice, more than 4 out of every 5 American Indians & Alaska Natives have experienced violence in their lifetimes. Watch on Facebook Live tomorrow at 12pm ET to learn about what we can do to prevent violence & protect communities. www.facebook.com/cdc

At least 5 of the top 10 leading causes of death are linked to adverse childhood experiences (ACEs). Preventing ACEs could reduce chronic diseases, risky health behaviors, and socioeconomic challenges. Learn how to prevent ACEs in CDC’s Vital Signs report: http://bit.ly/VitalSignsACEs

As part of American Indian & Alaska Native Heritage Month, we are bringing together an expert panel to discuss what steps CDC and we as individuals can take to prevent violence in American Indian and Alaska Native communities. Join us live on Facebook Live on November 13th at 12pm ET. www.facebook.com/cdc

CDC is working 24/7 to investigate the outbreak of lung injury associated with use of e-cigarette, or vaping, products. New lab testing of biologic samples from patients with these injuries identified vitamin E acetate, an additive in some THC-containing products. Avoid THC-containing products, especially from informal sources like friends, family, or dealers. http://bit.ly/MMWR_LungFluid
Are you protected? Pneumococcal and flu vaccines are just two of the vaccines that help #stoppneumonia. Find out more this World Pneumonia Day (Nov 12): https://bit.ly/2REyqYe

New Vital Signs report: Adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) impact lifelong health and opportunities. Help prevent ACEs and promote safe, stable, nurturing relationships and environments where children live, learn, and play. http://bit.ly/VitalSignsACEs

OUTBREAK UPDATE: As of 11/5, a total of 2,051 cases of lung injury associated with use of e-cigarette, or vaping, products were reported from 49 states (all but Alaska), DC, & USVI. 39 deaths were confirmed in 24 states and DC. Find out more: www.cdc.gov/lunginjury

Preventing adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) could reduce the number of adults with depression by as much as 44%. Read the new Vital Signs report to learn more about the links between ACEs and negative health outcomes. http://bit.ly/VitalSignsACEs
Family caregivers help people with disabilities stay safe and healthy. Read these tips for more ideas on how you can support the ones you love. http://bit.ly/2oPRcmh

Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is common in fall, winter, and spring. Almost all kids get it by age 2. RSV usually causes cold-like symptoms, but it can be serious, especially for infants and older adults. Wash your hands to help protect yourself and others. https://bit.ly/33hx5wY

“When you hear things like, ‘I lost all the members of my family,’ or ‘Five children have died in our family,’ it’s devastating,” says DRC Ebola outbreak responder Mary Choi, MD, MPH. Since the DRC Ebola outbreak began in August 2018, Mary has deployed to DRC and the World Health Organization (WHO) headquarters six times to help CDC respond. Read more about Mary’s experience: http://bit.ly/CDC-Choi

Getting your flu vaccine is the first and most important action you can take to protect yourself and those around you from flu.
CDC estimates that during 2018 – 2019, only 45% of adults were vaccinated against flu, leaving more than half of adults unprotected. Talk to your family and friends about the importance of flu vaccine and get vaccinated now.
Read more about vaccination last season: https://bit.ly/36zmPSF
Handwashing helps prevent 1 in 5 respiratory illnesses and 1 in 3 diarrheal illnesses. Learn when and how you should wash your hands to stay healthy: https://go.usa.gov/xV9TP

Did you know that getting a flu shot during pregnancy can reduce your chance of being hospitalized with flu by an average of 40%?
When you’re pregnant, changes in your immune system, heart, and lungs make you more prone to severe illness from flu.
Learn more about vaccines and pregnancy: https://bit.ly/2rwzxhk

Did you know that human health is connected to the health of animals and the environment? That’s called One Health. CDC uses a One Health approach to public health by bringing together experts in many areas to protect health for people, animals, and our shared environment. http://bit.ly/OHFeature

Outbreak Notice: A Salmonella outbreak linked to ground beef has sickened 10 people in 6 states. Eight have been hospitalized; 1 death reported. A single brand or supplier of ground beef has not been identified. Cook all ground beef thoroughly, to 160°F. https://go.usa.gov/xp4jz

OUTBREAK UPDATE: As of 10/29, a total of 1,888 cases of lung injury associated with use of e-cigarette, or vaping, products were reported from 49 states (all but Alaska), DC, & USVI. 37 deaths were confirmed in 24 states. Find out more: www.cdc.gov/lunginjury

As your family prepares for trick-or-treating, have you also prepared to fight flu?
Don’t let flu stop you from missing out on the fun! Get a flu vaccine now for the best protection.
Learn more: https://bit.ly/2vI4FNs

OUTBREAK UPDATE: The pig ear pet treat Salmonella outbreak is over, but you still need to take care with pet treats and food. Always wash hands after touching pet treats or food, and don’t give recalled pig ears to your dog. Many sick people in this outbreak said they never, rarely, or only sometimes washed hands after touching pet food or treats. https://go.usa.gov/xpYNa

CDC’s Climate and Health Program is celebrating 10 years of supporting state, tribal, local, and territorial public health agencies as they prepare for the health impacts of a changing climate. http://bit.ly/CDC_Climate
Don’t let a night of Halloween fun ruin your vision. Keep your eyes safe and never share your decorative lenses! go.usa.gov/xRzsk

Staying healthy as a cancer survivor can be difficult. Our new app helps cancer survivors learn about managing anxiety and stress, and the lifestyle choices that can affect their health. Learn more: http://bit.ly/31wAnuj

Antibiotics do not work on viruses such as those that cause colds, flu, bronchitis, or runny noses. Antibiotics are not needed for many sinus and some ear infections. When antibiotics aren’t needed, they won’t help you, and the side effects could still cause harm. Learn when antibiotics are and aren’t needed: https://bit.ly/2m9zmsT
Lead poisoning is 100% preventable. Get the facts, get your home tested, and get your child tested. Visit our website for more information to prevent lead poisoning: http://bit.ly/2Ix6AeE

In Afghanistan and Pakistan, two remaining countries where wild poliovirus still circulates, health-workers provide vaccination each month to tens of thousands of children for free.
