Know the symptoms of strep throat! If you have a sore throat, wash your hands often and cover your mouth when coughing and sneezing. Avoid sharing eating utensils, like forks or cups with others. See your doctor if you have any symptoms of strep throat. https://bit.ly/2vLGQ9H

People with Down syndrome may face barriers to accessing health care and health promotion programs at every age. Are you doing your part to promote inclusion? Take the first step. Learn simple steps that make a big difference. https://bit.ly/2XNK9v6

U.S. Antibiotic Awareness Week is quickly approaching. CDC’s partner toolkit has the materials you need to raise awareness of the threat of antibiotic resistance and importance of appropriate antibiotic prescribing and use. Learn more: http://bit.ly/2kCIc2w

Raw dough and batter are never safe to eat, even if they don’t contain raw eggs. Tasting just a small amount can make you sick from germs in uncooked flour or raw eggs. Bake or cook dough and batter before eating. https://go.usa.gov/xPN3d
Get familiar with how your breasts normally look and feel so you can talk to your doctor right away if you notice any of these breast cancer symptoms: https://bit.ly/2kHYuqR
Decorative contact lenses can be a fang-tastic asset to your Halloween costume, when fitted for your eyes. Avoid dealing with a nightmare eye infection and get a prescription. go.usa.gov/3htgV

Is your child eligible for Early Intervention services? Early Intervention services and support are available to babies and young children with developmental delays and disabilities and their families. Check out CDC’s list of Early Intervention contacts by state to see who to reach out to: www.cdc.gov/FindEI

As of 10/15, a total of 1,479 cases of lung injury associated with use of e-cigarette, or vaping, products were reported from 49 states (all but Alaska), DC, & 1 U.S. territory. 33 deaths were confirmed in 24 states.
Data suggests products containing THC, particularly those obtained off the street or from informal sources (like friends, family, or dealers), play a major role in the lung injury outbreak. Since the specific cause or causes of lung injury are not yet known, the best way to stay healthy & safe while we learn more is to consider refraining from use of all e-cigarette, or vaping, products. All tobacco products, including e-cigarettes, carry a risk.
If you are using e-cigarette, or vaping, products to quit smoking, do not return to smoking cigarettes. Adults addicted to nicotine using e-cigarettes should weigh all risks and benefits, and consider using FDA-approved nicotine replacement therapies. Get the latest info at: www.cdc.gov/lunginjury.

Parents, do you have questions about flu vaccination for your child?
See a summary of flu vaccine recommendations for children, with additional information on vaccinating children age 6 months through 8 years: https://bit.ly/2prDG8U

We’re live with CDC experts Sharyn Park Brown, PhD, MPH and Carri Cottengim, MA to learn how to create a safe sleep area for baby and other safe sleep practices. Thanks for joining us! www.cdc.gov/sids/

Pregnant? Flu vaccination helps protect you during pregnancy and also your baby for several months after birth. A Tdap vaccination during your 3rd trimester helps protect your newborn against whooping cough. However, only 1 in 3 pregnant women receive both flu and Tdap vaccines. Learn more: http://bit.ly/VSmaternal-vaccines

Public health students and professionals: We are LIVE now with today’s Public Health Grand Rounds broadcast on addressing the gaps in health care for people with intellectual disabilities. Leave your questions for our presenters in the comments below.

Teach your kids key moments when they should wash their hands—like after using the bathroom or playing outside, or before eating. Clean hands keep you and your family healthy! https://go.usa.gov/xV9TP
Let’s talk about safe sleep for infants. Join the Facebook Live conversation and watch a demonstration with CDC experts on Wednesday, October 16 at 2 p.m. ET. Join live at facebook.com/cdc.

CDC Vital Signs report: The Tdap vaccine is a safe and effective way to protect your baby from whooping cough and its complications. Tdap vaccination in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy lowers risk of whooping cough in babies younger than 2 months old by 78%. Learn more: http://bit.ly/VSmaternal-vaccines

Want to know more about how you can protect children from harmful substances in the environment? Children’s rapid development from before they are born through early childhood makes them more vulnerable to environmental exposures. Contact the experts at your nearest Pediatric Environmental Health Specialty Unit (PEHSU) to learn how to protect your child from exposure to health hazards in the environment. http://bit.ly/2mJCsoc

OUTBREAK NOTICE: 21 people in 13 states have gotten sick with Salmonella from contact with pet turtles. Always wash your hands after touching your pet turtle or their habitat, especially after touching tank water. Read more: https://go.usa.gov/xVeBX

Sabine’s illness started with an unusual pain in her right ankle. Her pain got worse until a doctor finally diagnosed her with Valley fever, a treatable fungal disease. Read Sabine’s story: https://go.usa.gov/xVpje.

If you are pregnant during flu season, the best way to protect yourself and your baby is to get the flu shot. The latest CDC Vital Signs report on maternal vaccination highlights the importance of maternal vaccination. Learn more: http://bit.ly/VSmaternal-vaccines

The first step in understanding your breast cancer risk: find out if any relatives have had breast cancer and at what ages they were diagnosed. Use this checklist to help you take action. https://bit.ly/2knsRm2

People with heart disease are at higher risk for flu complications.
Are you or is someone you love living with heart disease? Get your flu shot by the end of October for best protection against serious flu-related illness. #FightFlu https://bit.ly/2nXADVq

This National Protect Your Hearing Month, CDC encourages people to use hearing protection (earplugs and noise-cancelling earmuffs) to protect their hearing from loud noises. United States reports the most measles cases in 25 years. Keeping high coverage of MMR vaccination is key to prevent measles cases and outbreaks. Learn more: http://bit.ly/MMWR_Measles_Update

“Is this normal?” One of the most common questions asked by new parents. If you are having difficulty identifying whether your little one has reached a certain developmental milestone, don’t worry, this checklist can help. CDC’s free Milestone Tracker app features photos and videos of each milestone to help you learn what behaviors to look for. Check it out here: www.cdc.gov/MilestoneTracker

As of October 1, a total of 1,080 confirmed and probable cases of lung injury associated with e-cigarette use/vaping have been reported from 48 states and one U.S. territory. 18 deaths have been confirmed from 15 states. Getting a flu vaccine is the best protection from flu. If you do happen to get sick with flu after getting your vaccine, it still protects you by reducing the severity of illness.
In fact, a 2018 study showed that among adults hospitalized from flu, vaccinated patients were 59% less likely to be admitted to the ICU than those not vaccinated.
Discover more reasons to get a flu vaccine today: https://bit.ly/2yGuyOz
Are you living with ALS? Do you want to make a difference for future generations? Take part by joining the National ALS Registry: www.cdc.gov/als.

If you’re pregnant, getting a flu shot this month should be high on your to-do list.
Talk to your healthcare professional about getting vaccinated by end of October, and learn more about vaccines during pregnancy here: https://bit.ly/2tWJRmg

It’s ADHD Awareness Month, and we’re busting ADHD myths! The fact is, there are multiple treatment options for ADHD, including behavior therapy, medications, and school accommodations. Read more about them to help your child: https://bit.ly/2oaxfqj

Do you know how to properly use a fire extinguisher? How to perform CPR? There are ways to prepare your health for a disaster or emergency that have nothing to do with gathering supplies. As a baby, Mary was diagnosed with a rare combination of congenital heart defects. “I was admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU), and at 9 days old, I had my first open heart surgery. I would go on to have three more surgeries by the time I was 2 years old.” Surgeries can help repair the heart, but people living with heart defects may need additional medications, surgeries, or other procedures later in life. Learn how continuing cardiac care throughout her life has helped Mary stay healthy and shaped her future career path: http://bit.ly/CDC-MaryCHD

A working cellphone can be a lifeline in an emergency. Be prepared by fully charging your cellphone, and make sure that you have backup charging and alternative power sources, including a car charger and power banks. Learn more about preparing for a power outage: https://bit.ly/2lHqdbC

Did you know? Nine out of 10 patients who report a penicillin allergy are not truly allergic. Verifying your allergy status helps your healthcare provider prescribe antibiotics appropriately and give you the best care. Talk to your healthcare provider about what to do if you think you have a penicillin allergy.

There are now 530 confirmed and probable cases of lung injury associated with e-cigarette product use/vaping reported by 38 states and one territory as of 9/17/2019. Seven deaths are confirmed in six states.
Until we know more, CDC recommends you consider refraining from using e-cigarette/vaping products if concerned about health risks. If you have recently used an e-cigarette or vaping product and you have symptoms like those reported in this outbreak, see a healthcare provider.
Anyone who uses an e-cigarette/vaping product should not buy these products off the street (such as e-cigarette/vaping products with THC or other cannabinoids), and should not modify/add any substances not intended by the manufacturer. A large-scale disaster could make it difficult to find an open pharmacy, let alone fill a prescription. Create a 7 to 10-day emergency supply of prescription & over-the-counter medications, and keep an up-to-date list of all prescription medications, the dosages, and known allergies with your important paperwork. Don’t forget your pet’s medications, too! ALWAYS store medications out of reach and sight of children and pets, but in temperature-controlled and easily accessible places. Read more: https://bit.ly/311XJJ0

“This is really close to the heart for me,” says CDC epidemiologist and the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) native Norbert Soke about the Ebola outbreak in his home country.

CDC Disease Detective Amy Heinzerling washes up at a screening station near the Ebola outbreak epicenter in Goma, Democratic Republic of the Congo. Amy says her work to improve Ebola screenings of travelers at DRC borders has been both “an incredible opportunity” and “humbling, as a lot of experiences are in public health.”
At these screening checkpoints, staff screen tens of thousands of travelers every day by asking them to wash their hands in chlorinated water, observing them for signs of Ebola, and taking their temperatures using non-contact thermometers. If a traveler appears sick or is running a fever, he or she is pulled aside for additional screening.
Read more about Amy’s experience: https://bit.ly/2KGzskA

Did you know that five of the six HPV cancers aren’t routinely screened for?
By making sure your preteen is up to date on HPV vaccine, you can protect them from ever developing these cancers. Learn more about how HPV vaccine helps protect your child: https://bit.ly/2Z9Xiv8
From A-E: this World Hepatitis Day, learn more about hepatitis A, B, C, D and E – and the impact they have worldwide. https://bit.ly/2tPs28W

Stay safe this summer! Vibrio bacteria live in the ocean and can get into skin through cuts or open wounds. People who are 65 years or older and people with certain medical conditions have an increased chance of Vibrio infection and severe illness. Find out more: https://bit.ly/2Y9N1CX
Roosevelt smoked for 30 years and had a heart attack that led to open heart surgery. Read his story: https://bit.ly/2JSDdD6
Do you or a loved one smoke? Have you thought about calling a quitline? Quitlines offer free, confidential, and customized support to help you quit smoking for good. Learn more: http://bit.ly/2LCkjDj

Does Grandma visit with her daily pill organizer in her purse? Does Grandpa keep a collection of pill bottles on the kitchen table? Ask family and friends to help keep visits safe and store their medicines (including those in purses, bags, or pill organizers) up and away and out of sight. Learn more at www.UpandAway.org.

If you’re concerned your child may have Tourette syndrome, you’re not alone. Information is key to understanding next steps. Talk to your child’s healthcare provider, see the most current data here: https://bit.ly/2SBXJMA

This month is the 29th anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). Learn what CDC is doing to include people with disabilities in public health research and health promotion activities. https://bit.ly/2JXBWL7

There’s a lot to celebrate this summer, including your health! Stay on top of it by avoiding alcoholic beverages or drinking no more than one per day. This will benefit your overall health, and will also lower your breast cancer risk. https://bit.ly/2ImbNpH

Lifesaving reminder: Do not leave children unsupervised in parked cars in the summer heat. Cars can quickly heat up, putting a child at risk for serious heat-related illness and/or death. Learn more. https://bit.ly/2i976Vj
Cases of Alzheimer’s disease among African Americans are expected to go up significantly in the future. Learn more about Alzheimer’s disease and access resources for caregivers: http://bit.ly/2XaUyAU

Pregnant? July is Group B Strep Awareness Month. Learn about a simple test that can show if you are at increased risk for passing these bacteria to your baby during birth. If so, antibiotics during labor can protect your baby from serious illness. https://bit.ly/2LDRsyY

Visiting the lake or beach this summer? Check your local water conditions for harmful algal blooms and follow any advice posted by your state/local health department online or near the water. go.usa.gov/xyxPj

Always wash your hands after handling live poultry such as chickens, chicks, ducks, and ducklings. Remember backyard poultry belong outside in their own coop and not in your home. So far this year, 768 people in 48 states have gotten sick with Salmonella infections in outbreaks linked to contact with live poultry. https://go.usa.gov/xmpnd

As a health educator, Meagan teaches her peers about breast health. That’s why, when she noticed a lump in her breast in college, she had it checked out by a doctor. Find out what she learned and what next steps she took in this podcast: https://bit.ly/2In4pKL.
Students: Check out CDC’s new Health IQ skill to test your Health IQ. “Alexa, play CDC Health IQ”. Available now in the Amazon Alexa store: https://bit.ly/2WbguLL
Did you know? A quitline offers free, confidential, and customized support to help you or a loved one quit smoking for good. Learn more: http://bit.ly/2LCkjDj

Parents: Great news! Most children and young adults with fragile X syndrome are getting recommended dental care and immunizations. However: Few are getting the recommended amount of physical activity each day. Here’s how to get your child moving: https://bit.ly/2LvCF9G

OUTBREAK UPDATE: 2 deaths due to Salmonella infections from contact with chickens, ducks, and other poultry in backyard flocks. Remember to have dedicated shoes for your coop and not to wear them inside your home. Learn more ways to stay healthy while caring for your flock. https://go.usa.gov/xmpnE

Check your home for recalled flour products from Baker’s Corner (sold at ALDI), Brand Castle, King Arthur, and Pillsbury. HCPs: According to a new CDC study more gay and bisexual men at high risk for HIV are using pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), a daily pill for HIV prevention. However, more PrEP use is needed. By routinely testing patients for HIV, assessing HIV-negative patients for indications and prescribing PrEP appropriately, healthcare providers can play a critical role in ending the HIV epidemic in the United States. Many vaccine-preventable diseases, like rotavirus, are incredibly contagious. Some of these diseases can be potentially harmful, even deadly, for young children.
Learn more about this serious disease and how you can protect your child. https://bit.ly/2D3H28m

CDC’s AFM investigation findings: Most patients developed AFM in summer/fall, and had respiratory symptoms or fever consistent with viral infection less than a week before limb weakness onset. Outbreaks have occurred every 2 years since 2014. Read the new Vital Signs. http://bit.ly/VSAFM
Swimming at camp can be fun! But campers with norovirus should not swim while sick and for 7 days after symptoms stop so they don’t spread the virus to others. https://bit.ly/2Lk5PYe

Between 2000 and 2018, tetanus vaccine helped reduced neonatal tetanus deaths by an estimated 85%. However, maternal and neonatal tetanus remains a major global health problem. In newborns, the case fatality rate for tetanus is 80-100% - especially in areas with limited access to clean deliveries and umbilical cord care. Learn more about progress towards eliminating maternal and neonatal tetanus in MMWR: https://bit.ly/35lI9ux

In the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), a measles epidemic has killed over 6,500 children. The country faces numerous challenges to delivering life-saving measles vaccine including access, keeping the vaccine cold, and cost barriers. Now, DRC and many other countries face difficult decisions as they weigh the risk of COVID-19 spread against the need to protect vulnerable populations from dangerous, vaccine-preventable diseases like measles. Learn about the impact of COVID-19 on measles immunization in @Nature: https://go.nature.com/34ECDCY

Today is the first-ever World Chagas Disease Day. In the U.S., more than 300,000 people have the disease (most are undiagnosed) and more than 300 infected babies in the U.S. are born with the parasitic disease each year. Globally, approximately 7 million people are living with Chagas disease, and it causes about 10,000 deaths each year around the world.

NYTIMES.COM
Millions of Children Are at Risk for Measles as Coronavirus Fears Halt Vaccines
The New York Times
13 April at 23:25 ·
More than 100 million children could be at risk for measles because countries are suspending national immunization programs in order to reduce the risk of coronavirus infection, international public health leaders warned.

The New York Times
13 April at 23:25 ·
More than 100 million children could be at risk for measles because countries are suspending national immunization programs in order to reduce the risk of coronavirus infection, international public health leaders warned.

More than 117 million children in 37 countries, many of whom live in regions with ongoing measles outbreaks, may miss out on receiving life-saving measles vaccine. Measles immunization campaigns in 24 countries have already been postponed and more may be delayed to help slow spread of COVID-19. We urge leaders to continue to intensify efforts to track unvaccinated children, so that the most vulnerable populations can be provided with measles vaccines as soon as it safe to do so. Read more about the recommendations and the importance of continued vaccination against measles: https://bit.ly/2XGCvkS

“There is no wavering in the commitment for polio eradication, but we are in a place the world has never been.”
CDC Global’s Director Dr. Rebecca Martin spoke with Science about the Global Polio Eradication Initiative’s (GPEI) decision to suspend polio vaccination campaigns. This pause is necessary for the health and safety of health workers and communities, and to minimize further spread of COVID-19 by suspending door to door campaigns.
CDC, along with the rest of the members of GPEI, understand the importance of being prepared to immediately resume these campaigns once it’s safe. https://bit.ly/39NzvWu

Zoonotic diseases are caused by harmful germs like viruses, bacteria, parasites, and fungi that spread between animals and people. Zoonotic diseases are very common, both in the United States and around the world. Scientists estimate that more than 6 out of every 10 known infectious diseases in people can be spread from animals, and 3 out of every 4 new or emerging infectious diseases in people come from animals. Learn more about zoonotic diseases and what you can do to protect yourself and your family: https://bit.ly/2zN8B1R

CDC
1 April at 13:06 ·
New CDC MMWR from Singapore suggests some people who have COVID-19 without symptoms can spread disease to others. This underscores the importance of social distancing and avoiding crowds to reduce the spread of disease. https://bit.ly/MMWR_SARSCoV2

The virus that causes COVID-19 is part of a family of viruses called coronaviruses, which are commonly found in both people and animals, including camels, cattle, cats, and bats. Rarely, animal coronaviruses can infect and then spread between people such as with Middle Eastern respiratory syndrome (MERS), severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), and now the virus that causes COVID-19. Studies of DNA show that all three are a type of coronavirus known as a betacoronavirus, and have origins in bats. Read more about the emergence of COVID-19: https://bit.ly/39HDR1p

Social distancing can help slow the spread of #COVID19 in affected communities. This means avoiding crowded places and maintaining distance from others. Learn more about staying safe and healthy at http://cdc.gov/coronavirus. #FlattenTheCurve

New CDC recommendation: Starting immediately and for the next 8 weeks, CDC recommends cancelling all events of 50 or more people.
Ongoing guidance recommends that, in areas where there is even minimal COVID-19, events likely to include 10 or more people at high-risk for serious issues should be cancelled. If there is substantial spread in your area, all gatherings should be cancelled.

This week's MMWR Notes from the Field describes a possible exposure to Macacine herpesvirus 1 (B virus) in an Oregon teen who was bitten by a macaque at a public park in Phuket, Thailand. This virus, found commonly in macaques, can rarely cause severe encephalitic infection in humans if not treated promptly, with a case fatality rate approaching 80%. Wondering what you can do to protect yourself and your family and friends from novel coronavirus, aka COVID-19? Your personal actions can make a difference.
o Wash your hands, cover your coughs and sneezes and stay away from people who are sick.
o Try to avoid someone who is showing symptoms. (This is the other side of not spreading the disease, which is not catching it.)
o If you’re 65 and older and live in areas where there is ongoing community spread, you should think about what actions you can take to reduce your exposures. http://bit.ly/CDC-COVID-19-Protect

Strong vaccine safety systems protect confidence in the health system and demand for life-saving vaccines. Vaccine safety standards require health care workers to report any adverse events following immunization (AEFI). A study in Ghana found that fear of personal consequences and lack of knowledge about AEFI or reporting systems were barriers to properly reporting AEFI. Read more about these barriers as well as what made reporting more likely: http://bit.ly/2uRoF3d

In DRC, Ebola isn’t the only looming threat over the city of Goma. In the shadow of Mount Nyiragongo, one of the world’s most active volcanoes, Molly Patrick (right) and her team specialize in infection prevention and control (IPC) to tackle the current Ebola outbreak.
In many cases, IPC goes beyond basic tools like soap, water, and disinfectants—it means changing protocols and procedures to keep the virus out of healthcare facilities from the start.
Read more about how Molly uses her environmental engineering skills to help DRC fight Ebola: http://bit.ly/CDC-Patrick

CDC
31 January at 11:00 ·
The 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-NCoV) is causing an outbreak of respiratory illness with Wuhan City, China as the epicenter. Five cases in travelers from Wuhan have been detected in the U.S.; a 6th case has been reported in a close contact with travel history, suggesting person-to-person spread.
Genetic sequencing suggests the 2019-nCoV has its origins in bats, but now is able to spread from person to person. Experts believe this spread is happening mainly via respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs or sneezes, the same way flu and other respiratory viruses spread.
You can help stop the spread of viruses and prevent respiratory illnesses by practicing good health habits, like avoiding close contact with people who are sick and washing your hands often.
See answers to frequently asked questions about novel coronavirus: https://bit.ly/2Gpyrvx

Tomorrow is World Neglected Tropical Disease Day. Around the world, more than 1 billion people are at risk of neglected tropical diseases. CDC has confirmed the first human infection with 2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) in the United States has been detected in the State of Washington in a person who had recently traveled to Wuhan, China. A lab test developed at CDC was used to confirm this patient’s illness was caused by the recently discovered 2019 novel coronavirus first identified in Wuhan City, China. Precautions are being taken to prevent any further exposures.
While person-to-person spread with this new coronavirus in Asia raises CDC’s level of concern, the agency continues to believe the risk of #2019-nCoV to the American public at large remains low at this time. Learn more about what CDC is doing to respond: https://bit.ly/3apDji6

A new report describes the significant progress made toward measles elimination in China. Measles incidence per million population in China decreased from 20.4 in 2013 to 2.8 in 2018. During January-June, 2019, there were no reported deaths from measles in China.
Measles elimination in China is possible with continued improvements in immunization strengthening, laboratory-supported surveillance, and investigation and response to outbreaks. Read more about China’s measles progress https://bit.ly/2Ylrtjk

New report: More than 140,000 people died from measles in 2018. The deaths occurred as measles cases and outbreaks surged around the world. Infants are at highest risk of death from measles, while children under 5 and adults over 20 are at high risk of serious complications, including pneumonia, diarrhea, hearing loss, and brain damage. The safe and effective measles vaccine can prevent and stop outbreaks when vaccination coverage is at 95% or higher. http://bit.ly/MeaslesReport2019

Afghanistan and Pakistan are the two remaining countries with wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) transmission. In 2018, Pakistan made progress in polio eradication, reporting 12 cases. From 2000 to the present, more than 18 million cases of polio paralysis were prevented thanks to polio vaccines. During that time, there have been 1,085 reported cases of paralysis due to circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV). Stopping current outbreaks and limiting the risk of vaccine derived poliovirus (VDPV) emergence requires increasing technical assistance to affected countries, introducing a novel, stabilized type 2 vaccine that could be available as early as mid-2020, maintaining high vaccination coverage, and ending all oral polio vaccine use after certification of polio eradication.

Vaccines prevent an estimated 2-3 million deaths every year, however, if global vaccination coverage improved an additional 1.5 million deaths could be avoided. The Global Vaccine Action Plan (GVAP) calls for all countries to achieve 90% or greater vaccination coverage for all vaccines in the country’s immunization schedule by 2020.
As of 2018, global coverage for three doses of the vaccine for diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis (DTP3) and the first dose of the measles vaccine (MCV) was 86%. However, only 66% of countries met the GVAP goal for DTP3, and 61% met the GVAP goal for MCV.
Closing the gap in vaccine coverage by country and region will require strategies that address local challenges to receiving vaccines on schedule and target hard-to-reach and hard-to-vaccinate populations.
Learn more about global vaccine coverage in this week's MMWR
https://bit.ly/2qK21HK

Today we mark the eradication of wild poliovirus type-3 (WPV3), a promising step toward a polio-free world! WPV3 is only the third infectious disease-causing pathogen in history to be eradicated, following smallpox and wild poliovirus type-2. Its eradication represents a benefit to future generations and underscores our potential to wipe out all forms of the poliovirus for good.
Learn more: https://bit.ly/2pLHy4K
#endpolio #worldpolioday #MakingHistory

It Takes A Nurse
30 September 2019 at 12:00 ·
I lead a multi-disciplinary team of public health professionals who are responsible for polio eradication in the Middle East. Our team is comprised of international and national staff with expertise in epidemiology, research, statistics, demography, and analytics. We work closely with staff from the other core partners of the Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI) as well.
A large part of my job is maintaining situational awareness of the epidemiological and political issues affecting the eradication of polio and making adjustments to our eradication strategies. In addition to providing program guidance, I focus on making sure my colleagues have the resources and support they need.
I’m curious: how many of you have worked internationally? Let me know in the comments.

Vital statistics, including tracking births, deaths, and causes of deaths, provide important data for public health. They help establish the burden of diseases and the impact of programs that combat them. They also inform policymakers about health needs and coverage. Many countries are working to strengthen their civil registration and vital statistics systems. A new study examines how policies across the globe have impacted birth and death registrations.
Learn more about the study: https://journals.plos.org/plosmedicine/article?id=10.1371/journal.pmed.1002929

Measles anywhere is a threat everywhere. 2019’s U.S. measles outbreaks have been linked to international travel and gaps in vaccination coverage. Although two European countries achieved measles elimination status, four countries in the region have lost their elimination status for the disease.
With global connections through travel and trade, preventing measles around the world protects Americans at home and abroad. Read more about the World Health Organization (WHO) announcement on measles elimination progress in the European region: https://bit.ly/2Lol29h
EURO.WHO.INT
European Region loses ground in effort to eliminate measles

Last week, World Health Organization (WHO) announced Austria and Switzerland achieved elimination status for measles, and Bulgaria and Kyrgyzstan achieved elimination status for rubella. However, the United Kingdom, Albania, the Czech Republic, and Greece have lost measles elimination status.
Measles spreads quickly, and measles anywhere is a threat everywhere. To defeat measles globally, national immunization systems need political commitment, rapid case detection, high-quality outbreak preparedness and response, and sustainable investment and public support.
Learn more about Europe’s measles elimination progress: https://bit.ly/2Lol29h

The current #measles outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo is the largest the country has experienced since 2011-2012. In 2019, over 155,000 people have been infected and over 2,900 have died. Measles is highly contagious, but we have a safe and effective vaccine. Increased immunization rates are crucial to stop its spread, save lives and reduce costs.
Reaching all children with two doses of measles vaccine and increasing routine immunization to ensure 95% coverage can contain the outbreak. #vaccineswork

Vaccine inaccessibility is the biggest challenge to polio eradication in Afghanistan. To eradicate polio, efforts to regain access for house-to-house supplemental immunization campaigns must continue, with priority given to the Southern and Eastern provinces where wild polio is currently circulating. Increased efforts by immunization partners are also needed to ensure that routine immunization sessions are systematically offered through fixed, mobile, and outreach approaches, especially in the most critical areas.

After completing a Joint External Evaluation (JEE) in 2017, Uganda began working with CDC and other partners on the development of a National Action Plan for Health Security (NAPHS). These assessments help countries build momentum towards preventing, detecting, and responding to infectious disease risks, which in turn strengthens global health security for us all. https://go.usa.gov/xVCwB

Yesterday Uganda launched their National Action Plan for Health Security (NAPHS) to improve their emergency preparedness and response capabilities. In April 2019, Uganda MOH, CDC, and partners held a nationwide Ebola simulation exercise. These efforts paid off when three travel-related Ebola cases were identified and quickly contained in June 2019.
Collaborating to build global health security capacity for full-fledged, real time deployment and response is critical. These efforts show how Uganda is building its capacity to put preparedness into action. https://bit.ly/2SzjOex

DYK? Most cyclosporiasis outbreaks in the United States are related to imported fresh produce. You can help prevent this illness, caused by a microscopic parasite, by washing all fruits and vegetables before eating, cutting, or cooking them. Refrigerate your fruit and veg as soon as possible, and don’t forget to wash your hands before and after you touch your produce. Read more about what you can do to prevent cyclospora infection: https://www.cdc.gov/parasites/cyclosporiasis/prevent.html

When epidemiologists trace a potentially food-related outbreak, they have to ask patients what they ate, sometimes weeks before the interview. Patients may have a hard time remembering, which makes it harder to figure out which cases are connected.
A new study describes how CDC scientists are using mitochondrial genetic sequencing to track Cyclosporiasis outbreaks. By comparing the Cyclospora cayetanensis parasite from patient samples, scientists can connect cases to each other—and maybe to a known outbreak. Learn more about the technique: https://bit.ly/2GKWh5J

Hepatitis C is a liver disease that is a leading cause of liver cancer. Globally, an estimated 71 million people have chronic hepatitis C infection. CDC provides support to countries like Georgia to strengthen laboratory, surveillance, workforce capacity to address hepatitis C virus elimination.

Chronic #hepatitis B virus infection develops in 90% of infants infected before 1 year of age. The vaccine is most effective at preventing mother to child transmission when the first dose is given within 24 hours after birth.

FOR CLINICIANS: A new evidence-based guidance document for national and regional immunization program staff provides a framework and describes best practices for preparing and responding to clusters of adverse events after the Hepatitis B birth dose vaccination. Infants and children infected with hepatitis B virus (HBV) are at the highest risk for chronic infection, which causes 686,000 premature deaths globally from liver cancer and cirrhosis per year. HBV vaccination, especially within 24 hours of birth, is the best way to prevent mother-to-child transmission. Many countries and regions are introducing the hepatitis B birth-dose in an effort to improve health globally through science, partnerships and evidence-based public health actions. Appropriate investigation and communication after potential adverse events are crucial to maintaining confidence in the vaccine and immunization programs.
Read the guidance document: https://bit.ly/2JVkjwO
#WorldHepatitisDay

As Sierra Leone continues to improve capacity of the public health workforce in the country, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is proud to support the training of government epidemiologists to global standards through the Field Epidemiology Training Program (FETP). Last week, our Charge d ’Affaires, Tomekah Burl, joined the President and CEO of the CDC Foundation, Dr. Judy Monroe, and the CDC’s Director for the Center for Global Health, Dr. Rebecca Martin, to officially open the second building of the Public Health National Emergency Operations Center (PHNEOC), and to witness the FETP-Intermediate graduation of 14 epidemiologists, bringing the total number to epidemiologists in Sierra Leone to 25. With CDC assistance, Sierra Leone will soon achieve the ratio of 1 epidemiologist to 200,000 people.

While rat lungworm disease is most common in Southeast Asia, and most of the US cases are reported in Hawaii, the continental US has had a few sporadic cases in Texas, Tennessee and Alabama. The disease is rare, but taking precautions is important:
1) Always wash fresh produce thoroughly
2) Always wash hands and utensils well after preparing food
3) Don’t eat raw or undercooked snails or slugs, frogs or shrimp/prawns
4) If you handle snails or slugs, wear gloves and wash your hands
5) When travelling in areas where the parasite is common, avoid eating uncooked vegetables
https://nyti.ms/2xNFlXn

CDC EPIC Webinar TODAY at 1 p.m. Eastern Time: Ebola in Democratic Republic of the Congo
Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) is a large country in Central Africa with more than 85 million people. The ongoing Ebola outbreak in DRC continues to grow and threaten other countries. This outbreak is the largest to occur in DRC and is now the second largest Ebola outbreak in the history of the disease. Only by the 2014–2016 outbreak in West Africa was larger. The outbreak is occurring in a highly insecure environment, which complicates public health response activities and increases the risk of disease spread.

This special webinar will be held by CDC’s Emergency Partners Information Connection, CDC’s National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases, and CDC Global. They will discuss the current situation and how organizations sending US-based workers to areas with Ebola can ensure the health and safety of their workers before, during, and after deployment. Please join this webinar on June 19 at 1 p.m. Eastern Time. https://bit.ly/2x0PHTi

Today’s world of increasing interconnectivity and mobility only further accelerates the shared global risk to human health and well-being. Simply put, an outbreak that begins in a remote village can reach major cities on all six continents, including here in the U.S., in less than 36 hours.
CDC's Center for Global Health Director, Dr. Rebecca Martin, discussed the progress made helping other countries to control disease outbreaks, and the continued work that needs to be done to prevent diseases from reaching and spreading to the U.S.

Protected Together refers to the idea that by vaccinating a large percentage of the population, protection from disease is conferred, not only to those who receive vaccine, but also to those who cannot be vaccinated because they are too young, or for other reasons. If vaccination rates are high enough, “herd immunity” helps to protect the entire community. To achieve herd immunity and be Protected Together against measles, 95 percent of all eligible children must receive two doses of measles vaccine.
Protected Together is at the heart of our work to protect Americans and everyone around the world from preventable disease. CDC’s Dr. Martin shares insights into how we each can curb the rise in vaccine-preventable diseases: http://bit.ly/2VFCVrd

Chagas disease, and the triatomines (“kissing bugs”) that transmit it, have been in the news lately. It’s important to know transmission in the US is rare, and there have been fewer than 100 cases of known locally acquired Chagas disease since human cases were first reported in 1955.
To protect yourself and your pets from contact with triatomine bugs, CDC suggests that you:
- Seal cracks and gaps around windows, walls, roofs, and doors
- Remove wood, brush, and rock piles near your house
- Use screens on doors and windows and repair any holes or tears
- If possible, make sure yard lights are not close to your house (lights can attract the bugs)
- Seal holes and cracks leading to the attic, crawl spaces below the house, and to the outside
- Have pets sleep indoors, especially at night
- Keep your house and any outdoor pet resting areas clean, and occasionally check both areas for the presence of bugs
https://www.cdc.gov/parasites/chagas/

As of April 8, more than 3,500 cases of cholera and 6 deaths have been reported from regions affected by Cyclone Idai in Mozambique.
CDC is working with the Mozambican Ministry of Health and other partners to set up an Early Warning Alert and Response Network system, so that epidemic-prone diseases, such as cholera, are detected early and addressed effectively.

"According to a 2012 study by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, cases of typhoid fever among children in Kibera were 15 times higher than those living in a rural area west of the capital; infections in Kibera were even higher in low-lying areas where sewage tends to pool. The study also found that 75 percent of the typhoid strains found there were resistant to commonly available antibiotics."
Surveillance research from CDC Kenya highlights emerging threat of antibiotic resistance in communities like Kibera. https://nyti.ms/2Uj3Pp7

On 14 March 2019, Tropical Cyclone Idai made landfall near Beira City, Mozambique causing catastrophic flooding and resulting in one of the worst humanitarian crises in Mozambique in recent history. Damage from the cyclone has severely disrupted water and food supplies, sanitation, electricity, transportation, shelter, communications, security, medical care, and mosquito control.
Rio Búzi Health Clinic, located in the Sofala, was one of the many health infrastructures affected by Cyclone Idai.
CDC is supporting national and international partners in the response, providing surveillance and outbreak detection expertise.

Disease detectives identified inadequately processed cassava flour as the culprit in a suspected food poisoning outbreak in western Uganda. Cassava contains cyanogenic glycosides, which can result in fatal cyanide poisoning if not properly detoxified by scraping, soaking and drying before being consumed.

So far this year, there have been 387 measles cases reported in the U.S. Measles is extremely contagious as it spreads when an infected person breathes, coughs, or sneezes. It can be imported to the U.S. through travel abroad, and outbreaks can occur among those who have not been vaccinated.
Vaccination is key to fighting its spread, and two doses of measles vaccine given routinely by every national immunization program is safe and effective.

Whether it’s the impact of a natural disaster or a disease outbreak, inequalities in everyday life are magnified in times of crisis, creating greater risk for women and girls.
CDC’s Dr. Nancy Knight had the privilege of speaking at Delta Days at The United Nations as part of an important discussion on public preparedness and empowering women during times of natural disaster. She highlighted the work CDC does in building public health capacity around the world, and how it benefits women and girls.

FOR U.S. CLINICIANS:
There are approximately 1,700 cases of malaria in the U.S. each year. Of those cases, 300 people will suffer severe malaria. CDC has updated guidance for the treatment of severe malaria. Starting April 1, quinidine will no longer be available. Artesunate is the first-line, WHO-recommended treatment for severe malaria.
For detailed information on the criteria for intravenous (IV) artesunate treatment and other frequently asked questions, see CDC’s malaria notice: http://ow.ly/kumr50oowg3

While viral hemorrhagic fevers (VHFs), like Lassa fever, are very serious, they are not common in the U.S. However, it is important for healthcare providers to understand high-consequence viruses such as Lassa, so they can appropriately diagnose and care for their patients.
CDC created two training videos for healthcare providers to learn about Lassa fever risk factors, incubation period, clinical presentation, diagnoses, treatment and infection control measures for Lassa fever patients.
Watch the videos and earn free CE credit.
http://ow.ly/MhxJ50mOOOp

Healthcare Providers: Hantavirus disease is an uncommon illness in people. However, cases have occurred in most states across the country. In the U.S., Hantavirus Pulmonary Syndrome, a respiratory disease caused by infection with hantaviruses, is a Nationally Notifiable Disease.
CDC, in collaboration with Navajo Nation, Indian Health Service, and the Arizona and New Mexico departments of health created two training videos for healthcare providers to learn about the risk factors, clinical presentation and methods for identifying hantavirus disease, as well as parameters for clinical management. As cases of hantavirus persist in the U.S., it is important for medical staff to recognize hantavirus cases in their communities and provide critical care.
Watch the videos and earn free CE credit.
http://ow.ly/LNjg50mOOII

Violence against Children Surveys (VACs), led by CDC as part of the Together for Girls partnership, measure physical, emotional, and sexual violence against girls and boys. Girls who experience violence are up to three times more likely to be infected with HIV. VACs surveys in 12 countries, most supported by The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) found that an average of more than one in four young women reported their first sexual experience as forced or coerced.

In Eastern and Southern Africa, HIV/AIDS is the leading cause of death among adolescent girls and young women, ages 15-19. In sub-Saharan Africa, girls account for 71% of new annual HIV infections among adolescents, and adolescent girls are twice as likely to be living with HIV as adolescent boys of the same age.
Hezekia and Wambui Omanga, founders of a community support group, demystify myths about HIV status and advocate for the well-being of women and children in their community.
Through our partnerships, CDC is helping countries pilot innovative treatment delivery models, including community support groups, to help more people living with HIV get treatment and stay on it.

Empowering adolescent girls and young women can help control the HIV/AIDS epidemic.
Douglas Meritei, a champion for change in Kenya, worked in her community going door-to-door to raise awareness of the dangers of gender-based violence, including exposure to HIV.

What is DREAMS?
The DREAMS initiative focuses on HIV prevention among young women ages 15 to 24 through evidence-based interventions shown to successfully address risk behaviors for HIV transmission and gender-based violence.
CDC supports The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR)’s DREAMS initiative in eight countries, implementing critical elements of the initiative’s core package including programs to empower the young women to reduce their risk of HIV, mobilize communities, strengthen families and decrease HIV risk among male sex partners of participants.

Today is World Lymphedema Day, which brings greater awareness to diseases of the lymphatic system, such as lymphatic filariasis (LF). LF, more commonly known as elephantiasis, is a disfiguring parasitic disease. It can cause severe swelling and even permanent disability, and is spread from person to person by mosquitoes. Globally, LF affects over 120 million people in 72 countries throughout the tropics and sub-tropics of Asia, Africa, the Western Pacific, and parts of the Caribbean and South America.
Here, a Bangladeshi health worker demonstrates proper leg hygiene technique on the right leg of a LF patient during a disease management and disability prevention training in northern Bangladesh. Learn about the global impact of LF and how CDC is working to stop LF and other neglected tropical diseases.
https://www.cdc.gov/globalhealth/ntd/diseases/lf_burden.html
📷: Caitlin M. Worrell, MPH

The Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI) is a public-private partnership led by national governments with five partners – World Health Organization (WHO), Rotary International, CDC, UNICEF, and Gates Foundation. Its goal is to eradicate polio worldwide.
The GPEI History Project will bring the story of this partnership to a broader audience both now and after certification through oral histories, artifacts, and other records. A selection of these materials will be on display at this year’s Shot@Life event.

Sherine Guirguis, former Senior Communications Manager for UNICEF’s Global Polio Programme, recalls her work supporting polio eradication in India from 2008-2010.
Frontline workers of the Social Mobilization Network (SMNet) in India, Guirguis recalls, devised creative approaches, which were most effective when based on input from women and mothers, to build demand for polio vaccination in India long before they were seen as global best practices and adopted as formal behavior change strategies by the polio eradication program.

More than 10,000 confirmed cases of measles in Brazil, 6,300 cases in Venezuela, and reports of cases in 5 other South American countries illustrate the growing human cost and how fragile gains can be when it comes to a highly contagious disease like measles. We have a safe, effective vaccine. Health officials need to achieve 95% population vaccination coverage and continued, strong surveillance to stop these outbreaks.

Imagine where the world would be if the Global Polio Eradication Initiative was never formed 30 years ago. Back then, over 350,000 kids were afflicted with polio each year, and many were missing out on the simple joys of childhood, like playing ball or learning to ride a bike. That was the reality then—now there are only a few cases remaining. Let’s make it zero! #EndPolio

World Malaria Report 2018: The use of malaria interventions in sub-Saharan Africa has stalled. Half of at-risk people don’t sleep under insecticide-treated nets, and not enough homes are protected by indoor residual spraying. Access to preventive therapies for pregnant women is still too low.
Malaria infection during pregnancy can have adverse effects on both mother and fetus, including maternal anemia, fetal loss, premature delivery, intrauterine growth retardation, and delivery of low birth-weight infants.
Learn what CDC is doing to combat malaria: http://bit.ly/2OQyXok

Due to low vaccine coverage nationally or in pockets, multiple regions have experienced large measles outbreaks in 2017. Despite challenges, global efforts to eliminate measles continue to make progress. Since 2000, measles deaths decreased by 80%.
Measles outbreaks in all regions illustrate how fragile gains in disease elimination can be and why it’s more important than ever to be vaccinated against all vaccine-preventable disease. Routine immunization is critical to protect everyone, everywhere.
Measles is extremely contagious. CDC and global health partners urge every country to continue vaccinating to reach more than 95% coverage of children everywhere and to maintain strong surveillance and responses capacities to detect any new cases.
Read more in MMWR: bit.ly/measles2018

27 November 2018 at 12:37 ·
Today, U.S. Secretary of State Michael Pompeo announced PEPFAR’s latest annual program results. As of September 30, 2018, PEPFAR is supporting over 14.6 million people on lifesaving antiretroviral treatment (ART), up from with the 50,000 people who were on ART in Africa when PEPFAR began in 2003. PEPFAR has also enabled over 2.4 million babies to be born HIV-free to mothers living with HIV; supported over 6.8 million orphans, vulnerable children, and their caregivers; provided voluntary medical male circumcision to 18.9 million men and boys in eastern and southern Africa, providing them critical protection from HIV infection; and trained more than 270,000 health care workers. Read more here: https://t.co/G7xA9BKC5u

What is rat lungworm disease exactly?
While this parasitic disease is severe, it is rare. The best way to prevent infection is to thoroughly wash your fruits and vegetables, and avoid eating raw slugs and snails.

Neglected tropical diseases are a group of diseases that cause illness for more than one billion people globally and affect the world’s poorest people. #NTDs weaken physical and cognitive development, contribute to mother and child illness and death, make it difficult to farm or earn a living, and limit productivity in the workplace, trapping the poor in a cycle of poverty and disease. 🔎Guess the Parasite: This #parasitic disease is transmitted by the repeated bite of black flies carrying the #parasite that lives on the banks of fast-flowing rivers and streams. An infectious blackfly will typically drop larvae when biting a person. The larvae then penetrate the skin to infect the person. Because the worms reproduce only in humans but need to complete some of their development inside the blackfly, the intensity of human infection (number of worms in an individual) is related to the number of infectious bites sustained by an individual. Blindness is usually seen in longstanding and intense infections. #GuessTheParasite

In 2011, a woman’s remains were found inside an iron coffin in Queens, New York. The female remains were so well preserved, they initially were believed to be fairly recent, until forensics determined the remains actually dated to the early 19th century. Who was she? How did she die? Why was she buried in an iron coffin? Investigators, including CDC’s Dr. Kevin Karem, explore these questions in the latest episode.
Don’t miss a new episode of PBS’ Secrets of the Dead, tonight at 10PM ET featuring CDC’s Dr. Kevin Karem. http://ow.ly/EQDb30m55kx

🔎Guess the Parasite:
This parasite causes a condition in humans known as Pediculosis. The infestation it causes can be found on the body, or on the head and face. The female of this species is approximately 3-4mm long. Its legs are adapted for clinging to a host’s hair and it lays its eggs on hair shafts, which are held tightly by a cementlike substance, making them difficult to remove. Infestations caused by this parasite are spread mostly by close person-to-person contact. Dogs, cats, and other pets do not play a role in the transmission. This parasite moves by crawling; it cannot hop or fly. Both over-the-counter and prescription medications are available for treatment.
#GuessTheParasite

🔎Guess the Parasite:
This #parasitic #disease can occur if you come into contact with freshwater that is home to snails carrying the parasite. Once the parasite penetrates the skin, it begins to migrate through host tissue and develop into adult worms inside the blood vessels. Symptoms of this parasitic illness occur as a result of the body’s reaction to the egg production by the female worms. Within days, you may develop a rash or itchy skin. Fever, chills, cough, and muscle aches can follow within 1-2 months. After years with the infection, the parasite can damage the liver, intestine, lungs, and bladder.
For the answer and to learn more about this parasite, visit https://bit.ly/2FqSUCt
#GuessTheParasite

🔎Guess the Parasite:
This #parasite can cause problems that could ruin your warm-weather fun. Many species of this #parasite infect humans and a wide range of animals, but two of them are most prevalent for causing illness in humans. Both the parasite and the disease are commonly known by the same name.
This parasite can be spread in several different ways, but water (drinking water and recreational water) is the most common way it’s spread. In fact, it’s a leading cause of waterborne disease among humans in the U.S. Many outbreaks in the U.S. have occurred in waterparks, community swimming pools, and day care centers. Infection with this parasite can cause simple infections to severe, life-threatening threatening illness.
And just why is this parasite so tough? It’s protected by an outer shell that allows it to survive outside the body for long periods of time and makes it very tolerant to chlorine disinfection.
#guesstheparasite

This parasite is the third most common round worm found in humans. The infection is caused by ingesting the parasite eggs. This can happen when hands or fingers that have contaminated dirt on them are put in the mouth or by consuming vegetables or fruits that have not been carefully cooked, washed or peeled. Cervical cancer claims the lives of a quarter of a million women every year with almost nine out of ten deaths occurring in developing countries. Cervical cancer is caused by human papillomavirus (HPV), a virus that can cause cancers in the mouth, throat, and reproductive tract, as well as genital warts. Safe and effective vaccines can prevent infection with certain types of HPV and protect against cervical cancer and other conditions. In this photo a nine-year old girl and her grandmother are being interviewed in Svay Rieng province about their knowledge on HPV vaccine.

🔎Guess the Parasite:
This #parasite species are #liver #fluke parasites that humans can get by eating raw or undercooked fish, crabs, or crayfish from areas in Asia and Europe where the parasite is found. This parasite requires a snail as an intermediate host.
Liver flukes infect the liver, gallbladder, and bile duct in humans. While most infected people do not show any symptoms, infections that last a long time can result in severe symptoms and serious illness. Untreated, infections may persist for up to 25–30 years, the lifespan of the parasite. Symptoms of this disease are similar to those of #schistosomiasis.
The eggs of this parasite are practically indistinguishable from those of #Clonorchis.
Adequately freezing or cooking fish will kill the parasite.
#guesstheparasite

🔎Guess the Parasite:
This #parasite causes a disease that infects red blood cells and is spread a certain tick: the Ixodes scapularis.
In the U.S., tickborne diseases are most common in particular regions and seasons; this disease mainly occurs in parts of the Northeast and upper Midwest and usually peaks during the warm months.
Once this parasite infects a human, there is little, if any subsequent transmission to humans. Humans are, for all practical purposes, dead-end hosts and there is probably little, if any, subsequent transmission that occurs from ticks feeding on infected persons. However, human to human transmission is well recognized to occur through blood transfusions.
In the U.S. this parasite is the agent most frequently identified (Northeast and Midwest), and can occur in individuals who’ve had their spleens removed.
#GuessTheParasite

Thanks to support from The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) and partners, AIDS-related deaths have declined by nearly 50 percent globally since their peak. As PEPFAR celebrates its 15th anniversary, up to 13 PEPFAR-supported countries could achieve epidemic control by 2020, creating the roadmap for the more than 50 countries that PEPFAR supports. Epidemic control will be achieved only by ensuring access to HIV services for all populations, including the most vulnerable and at-risk.
CDC works in more than 50 countries, with PEPFAR support, using the latest science and the best available data to direct U.S. resources where the HIV/AIDS epidemic is the largest, the need is highest, and dollars are most efficiently used.
Thanks to the compassion and generosity of the American people, PEPFAR has made lasting impact that has brought us ever closer to a world without AIDS.

In May 2003, the U.S. government launched The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) in response to what was a growing epidemic. Through the compassion and generosity of the American people—and outstanding partnerships—PEPFAR has accelerated global progress toward controlling and ultimately ending the AIDS epidemic as we know it. Fifteen years later, PEPFAR has altered the course of the global HIV/AIDS epidemic—saving millions of lives around the world, improving the lives of countless others, and preventing millions of infections along the way.
This year, as PEPFAR marks “15 Years of Saving Lives through American Generosity and Partnerships,” the year-long #PEPFAR15

This parasite is found in Africa. Its vectors are flies from two species of the genus Chrysops: C. silacea and C. dimidiata. Infected flies introduce third-stage fliarial larvae onto the skin of the human host, where they penetrate into the bite wound.

Today is World Hand Hygiene Day! Thorough handwashing is a great way to prevent many infections, including #trachoma, which is the world’s leading cause of preventable infectious blindness. However, for some, it's not as easily preventable. Trachoma, which spreads in areas that lack adequate access to water and sanitation, affects the most marginalized communities in the world. Globally, almost 8 million people are visually impaired by trachoma; 500 million are at risk of blindness from the disease throughout 57 endemic countries. Learn more about some of CDC's activities to prevent, detect, and treat the disease: http://ow.ly/7Q3K30jQ7tv

We are getting a lot of questions about how people who believe they have been exposed to COVID-19 should go about getting tested.
If a person has questions about being tested for COVID-19, they should call their healthcare provider to make arrangements for testing. It is important to call your healthcare provider's office before going in to let them know you may have COVID-19. This will help the healthcare provider's office take steps to keep others from getting infected or exposed to COVID-19.
Once the provider has contacted ADPH and a person is tested, the specimen should be sent from the provider to our State Lab, the Bureau of Clinical Laboratories (BCL) in Montgomery. Confirmatory testing is done by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in Atlanta.
For any persons not meeting ADPH’s criteria for testing but physicians still want to test them, they have been asked to please work with commercial labs of their choice.

Why is Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH) not sending persons in need of COVID-19 testing to county health departments for testing?
ADPH recommends persons do not show up at county health departments or healthcare providers without first contacting them. This will help reduce the risk of spreading respiratory infections. Evaluation and testing is recommended to be conducted by trained staff using appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) in negative pressure rooms. ADPH has identified county health departments with operational negative pressure rooms and is prepared to shift trained staff to these locations if necessary. PPE supplies are very limited, but ADPH is working to secure and distribute these supplies. This is a rapidly evolving situation. We will continue updating our website at go.usa.gov/xdg8r with the latest information.

Stroke is the fifth leading cause of death in the United States and is a major cause of serious disability for adults. You can help prevent stroke by making healthy choices. Read more at go.usa.gov/xdxgr.

State agencies are closed Monday, February 17, in observance of the birthdays of George Washington and Thomas Jefferson. The central office and all county health departments will resume regular operating hours on Tuesday, February 18. Have a safe and healthy weekend!

Today is National Donor Day. Did you know that 95% of adults support organ donation, but only 58% are actually signed up as donors? Anyone, regardless of age or medical condition can be a donor. Learn more facts and find out how to register to be a donor: go.usa.gov/xdRYG.
Share your love, not the flu! Simple steps like getting your flu shot and washing your hands regularly can reduce your chances of getting the flu. Learn more at go.usa.gov/xdN9G.
We can't help you with love. But for information on maintaining your septic tank, visit go.usa.gov/xd9M6.

High blood pressure is sometimes called the "silent killer" because it usually has no noticeable warning signs or symptoms until other serious problems arise. Because there are no symptoms, checking your blood pressure is the only way to know for sure whether it is too high. Learn more at: go.usa.gov/xdXnM.

Name calling, cyber stalking, harassment, threatening violence, & manipulation are forms of emotional abuse that many youth experience in dating relationships. February is Teen Dating Violence Awareness Month. If you are a teenager involved in a romantic relationship be sure and read about these warning signs: go.usa.gov/xVsUh.

Today is Wear Red Day. There are many things that can affect your risk for heart disease and stroke, including blood pressure, cholesterol, your level of physical activity, and whether or not you smoke. Learn about these factors and more at go.usa.gov/xnAHh.

February 7 is National Black HIV/AIDS Awareness Day. This year’s theme, “We’re in This Together,” promotes working collectively to stop HIV stigma and encourage HIV prevention, testing, and treatment in black communities. Find free, confidential HIV testing near you and get tested together: www.cdc.gov/doingit
It’s American Heart Month and tomorrow, February 7, is National Wear Red Day. Be sure and add some red to your outfit to show support for heart health. Learn more at: go.usa.gov/xnAY6

Alabama Public Health
31 January at 12:01 ·
Congratulations to Brison Williams and Saya Bell, winners of the 2020 "Share Your Smile with Alabama" photo contest!

Did you know if you have diabetes, you’re twice as likely to have heart disease than someone who doesn’t have diabetes? But, there is a lot you can do to lower your risk for heart problems. And those actions will make it easier to manage diabetes, too. Read more: go.usa.gov/xdKYn

February is American Heart Month. Heart disease is the leading cause of death in the United States. By living a healthy lifestyle, you can help keep your blood pressure, cholesterol, and blood sugar levels normal and lower your risk for heart disease and heart attack. Learn more at: go.usa.gov/xdZjd

The American College Health Association is providing key points for campuses to aid in their response to 2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV). See these and other resources at bit.ly/2vEN2kQ.

The U.S. Surgeon General has released a new report on smoking cessation. This report makes it clear that one of the most important actions people can take to improve their health is to quit smoking. This is true regardless of your age or how long you've been smoking. The Alabama Tobacco Quitline is a free telephone and online coaching service for any Alabamian who is ready to quit. Find out more at go.usa.gov/xNJWF.

Travelers who have recently visited Wuhan, China, and feel sick with fever, cough, or difficulty breathing should visit go.usa.gov/xdg8r for information on what steps to take next.

There is currently no vaccine to prevent 2019-nCoV infection. The best way to prevent infection is to avoid being exposed to this virus. However, as a reminder, CDC recommends the following everyday preventive actions to help prevent the spread of respiratory viruses: go.usa.gov/xd26d

2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) has been confirmed in the U.S. Get updates and resources specific to Alabama from ADPH at go.usa.gov/xdg8r. Find the latest CDC updates and resources at go.usa.gov/xdg8j.
Today is the 75th anniversary of the start of using community water fluoridation. Fluoridated water has helped keep teeth healthy and strong. Learn more: http://bit.ly/2PvlxR0

There are many things you can do to protect your brain as you age such as managing chronic health problems like diabetes, high blood pressure, and high cholesterol. Here are some more tips to help you stay active and healthier physically and mentally as you get older: go.usa.gov/xdYuU

As the temperatures continue to stay cold, more and more people will be relying on their favorite heat source to keep warm and comfortable. Whether that means a gas furnace, space heater, fireplace, or some combination, we want you to be safe this winter so we put together these quick heating safety tips for you: go.usa.gov/xdYxk

Are you thinking about getting pregnant soon? Is reaching a
healthy weight one of your new year’s resolutions? What’s best for you is also best for your baby! Talk with your doctor about ways to reach and maintain a healthy weight before you get pregnant. Read more about how to have a healthy pregnancy: go.usa.gov/xdY35

Spending time outdoors this winter? Ticks that bite people can come out on warm winter days which can be common in the south. Protect yourself: Use insect repellents, do tick checks, and take showers after being outside. bit.ly/Avoid_Ticks

State agencies are closed Monday, January 20, in observance of the birthdays of Martin Luther King, Jr. and Robert E. Lee. The central office and all county health departments will resume regular operating hours on Tuesday, January 21. Have a safe and healthy weekend!
Do you know the signs and symptoms of a stroke? F.A.S.T. is an easy acronym to help you remember them and perhaps save a life: go.usa.gov/xdxgr

You can’t see radon. And you can’t smell it or taste it. But it may be a problem in your home. Radon is estimated to cause many thousands of deaths each year. That’s because when you breathe air containing radon, you can get lung cancer. Testing your home is inexpensive and easy. Learn more at go.usa.gov/xdcDp

Did you know there’s no way to prevent glaucoma? That’s why eye exams are so important. Eye doctors can check for glaucoma as part of a comprehensive dilated eye exam. Read what is involved in getting a dilated eye exam and how it can be the best thing for your health: go.usa.gov/xd38f
January is Cervical Cancer Awareness Month. ADPH wants to remind Alabamians that cervical cancer is over 90% preventable. Read the full news release to learn more: go.usa.gov/xdqX4

Diabetes Self-Management Education and Support (DSMES) services help people with diabetes learn how to take the best care of themselves. Ask your doctor for a referral to DSMES services to help you manage your diabetes. For a list of DSMES sites in Alabama visit: go.usa.gov/xP6PH

Could you spot a victim of trafficking in a crowd? Probably not because victims may not look any different than anyone else you see every day. Recognizing key indicators of human trafficking is the first step in identifying victims and can help save a life. Here are some common signs to help recognize human trafficking: go.usa.gov/xpJJR

About one in every 33 babies is born with a birth defect. Not all birth defects can be prevented. But a woman can take steps to increase her own chance of having a baby with the best health possible. Learn how you can get ready for pregnancy and help give your baby a healthy start in life: go.usa.gov/xpJYc

The FOCUS Rally scheduled for January 31 in Andalusia will feature speakers and breakout session on topics including vaping, underage drinking, depression, suicide prevention, and more. Registration is now open to students in grades 7-12 and their adult chaperones. Learn more and register today at thefocusprogram.com/focus-rallies.

Scale Back Alabama is looking for local coordinators! They rely on local businesses, churches, gyms and other community organizations to serve as official weigh-in sites. Watch this video to learn how you can help your fellow Alabamians get a healthy start in 2020.

3 January at 13:42 ·
Becoming a Scale Back Alabama coordinator is easy! Watch this short video to learn how. Ready to sign up to be a coordinator? Send an email to info@scalebackalabama.com.

Each year, more than 11,000 women in the United States get cervical cancer. You can lower your risk for cervical cancer by getting screened regularly, starting at age 21. Find out about screening tests, options, and the HPV vaccine: go.usa.gov/xny6r

Glaucoma is often called "the sneak thief of sight" because it has no symptoms until significant vision loss has occurred. Half of people with glaucoma don’t know they have it. Get a healthy start this year by learning about glaucoma and taking steps to reduce your risk of vision loss: http://bit.ly/2Qm5TJq

January is National Slavery and Human Trafficking Prevention Month. In addition to being a violent crime, human trafficking is a public health concern that impacts individuals, families, and entire communities across generations. Check out ten ways you can help end human trafficking: go.usa.gov/xpMXU

State agencies are closed Wednesday, January 1, in observance of New Year's Day. The central office and all county health departments will resume regular operating hours on Thursday, January 2. Here's to a safe and healthy 2020!

Thinking of losing weight in 2020? The benefits of maintaining a healthy weight go far beyond improved energy and smaller clothing sizes. By losing weight or maintaining a healthy weight, you are also likely to enjoy a higher quality-of-life too. Check out some success stories that participants have recently shared with us and submit your own: scalebackalabama.com/success-stories.
On average, smokers die 10 years earlier than nonsmokers. If you smoke and are ready to quit, The Alabama Quitline can help: go.usa.gov/xRV47.

State agencies are closed Tuesday, December 24 and Wednesday, December 25, in observance of Christmas. The central office and all county health departments will resume regular operating hours on Thursday, December 26. Have a safe and healthy holiday!

Your house is covered in tinsel and poinsettias. Your table is full of rich food. These things bring people great joy, but they can lead to severe health issues for your pets. Watch this video for tips on keeping pets safe, and get more information at bit.ly/2M5EFEp.

Keep Your Dogs and Cats Safe From Holiday Hazards
Planning on traveling to visit loved ones or maybe taking a holiday vacation? Follow these travel tips for a healthy and safe holiday travel season: go.usa.gov/xpGQ2

Mental health issues can affect almost anyone, especially around the holidays. If you’re in need of help, visit mh.alabama.gov/hot-warm-lines for information on numbers to call. Learn the best way to speak to people with mental health or substance abuse issues at stopjudging.org.

The Online License Renewal period for 2020 is open. Any health care facility that does not renew its license by December 31, 2019 or renew its license and pay the accrued late fees by January 31, 2020, is no longer licensed. Learn more or renew your licence at go.usa.gov/xP9FD.
Doing some Christmas shopping this weekend? December is Safe Toys & Gifts Month. For tips on buying safe, age-appropriate toys for kids, visit go.usa.gov/xpp3n.

Want to quit smoking? There's an app for that! Download the quitSTART app for free. It helps you to quit smoking with tailored tips, inspiration, and challenges. Find out more by visiting: https://smokefree.gov/tools-tips/apps/quitstart

Registration for the Scale Back Alabama 2020 challenge is now open! Visit: scalebackalabama.com/join/ for more information on how to register online. Note: You can no longer register using the Scale Back Alabama mobile app.

ADPH and Alabama Department of Mental Health launch a statewide campaign, "Stop Judging, Start Healing," aimed at changing the way we speak about individuals with mental health illness, substance and opioid use disorders, HIV and Hepatitis C. End the cycle of stigma.
YOUTUBE.COM
ADPH Opioid Use Disorder

There are many reasons to get a flu vaccine. It can reduce your risk of flu and its potentially serious complications. It also can reduce the severity of your illness, even if you still get sick. However, flu vaccination isn’t just about keeping you healthy; it’s also about helping to protect everyone around you who may be vulnerable to becoming very sick from flu.Visit go.usa.gov/xn3MJ to learn more.

Holiday stress and unhealthy holiday foods can affect your health. Take some time out of the hustle and bustle to consider these 7 healthy habits that help prevent chronic diseases like type 2 diabetes, cancer, and heart disease: go.usa.gov/xpm4r

Hand-washing can become a lifelong healthy habit if you start teaching it at an early age. Give kids frequent reminders of how and when to wash hands. For steps on how to teach children to wash their hands visit: go.usa.gov/xV9Td

It’s National Influenza Vaccination Week (NIVW)! NIVW highlights the importance of continuing flu vaccination through the holiday season and beyond. Make sure you get a flu vaccine to protect yourself and your loved ones this flu season. For more information visit: go.usa.gov/xnXdu

Keeping hands clean is one of the most important steps we can take to avoid getting sick and spreading germs to others. Many diseases and conditions are spread by not washing hands with soap and clean, running water. CDC recommends cleaning hands in a specific way to avoid getting sick and spreading germs to others. Read more at: go.usa.gov/xVQuD

State agencies are closed Thursday and Friday, November 28 and 29, in observance of Thanksgiving. The central office and all county health departments will resume regular operating hours on Monday, December 2. Have a safe and healthy Thanksgiving weekend!

Did you know that Thanksgiving is also National Family Health History Day? While you are at family gatherings be sure and talk to your family about their health histories. Knowing about your family health history of a disease can motivate you to take steps to lower your chances of getting the disease. You can create a family health history online by clicking this link: go.usa.gov/xpcxa

Sugar Shock Fact: If you have type 2 diabetes, you may not need insulin. According to the CDC, only 14% of adults use insulin alone, 13% use insulin and oral medication, 57% take oral medication only, and 16% control blood sugar with diet and exercise alone. Do you want to learn more about diabetes education and support classes? A diabetes self-management class may be for you. To find a program near you click on a county by using this interactive map: go.usa.gov/xpRcJ

Grinch knows how easy it is to share his smile with us.. do you? Share Your Smile with Alabama Photo Contest, sponsored by ADPH's Oral Health Office, is open until November 30. Two 3rd graders, 1 boy and 1 girl, will be selected as winners. Full rules and details are available at go.usa.gov/xE5xv.

Quitting smoking isn’t easy. It takes time & a plan. You don’t have to stop smoking in one day. Start with day one. Tomorrow, November 21, is the Great American Smokeout. Let it be your day one to start your journey toward a smoke-free life.
