Saturday, November 23, is International Survivors of Suicide Loss Day. Each year, the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention supports hundreds of large and small Survivor Day events around the world, in which suicide loss survivors come together to find connection, understanding and hope through their shared experience. There are several events planned in Alabama. To find an event near you click here: bit.ly/37n1kF8

November is National Home Care and Hospice Month. Ninety percent of Americans want to age in place, and home care is the preferred method of health care delivery among the disabled, elderly, and chronically ill. Find out more about ADPH Home, Health, and Community Services: go.usa.gov/xU56f

November is American Diabetes Month and it is time for another Sugar Shock Fact: Sugar doesn't cause diabetes. The key is moderation and management. Consuming too much sugar (sugary foods and drinks) can make people put on weight, which make a person's chance of getting type 2 diabetes greater. Could you have prediabetes? Take the test: go.usa.gov/xyFv3

It is Antibiotic Awareness Week. Don’t ask for antibiotics for viruses, like those that cause cold and flu. Instead, ask your healthcare professional or pharmacist how to feel better. For a list of what antibiotics can or cannot treat go to: bit.ly/2Q2HgOO

November is National Alzheimer's Disease Awareness Month. This video reveals the burden of Alzheimer's and dementia on individuals and caregivers. Share the facts and join the fight.

Have you shared your smile yet? The deadline to enter the Share Your Smile with Alabama Photo Contest, sponsored by ADPH's Oral Health Office, is approaching fast! Diabetes doesn't treat men and women the same. Diabetes increases the risk of heart disease by about four times in women but only two times in men. If you're a woman with diabetes, find out more about what you can do to stay on track and be your healthiest: go.usa.gov/xpB6G

Your skin is your body's largest organ, so it's important to take good care of it. November is National Healthy Skin Month. If you notice anything suspicious on your skin, or if you have a question about skin care, see a board-certified dermatologist. In the meantime, here are 10 skin care secrets for healthier looking skin: bit.ly/32LsB0g\

ADPH's Bureau of Family Health Services works to provide continued improvement in the health, safety, and well-being of pregnant women, infants, children, including children with special health care needs, and their families. Please help us improve our services by taking a short survey that will help identify the most important maternal and child health needs for the state. Deadline is November 15. November is American Diabetes Month and it's time for a Sugar Shock Fact. Did you know that even if no one in your family has diabetes, you can still get it? Genes don't determine for sure, whether you'll get diabetes or not; they only influence the likelihood to the disease.The role of genetic factors varies among types of diabetes. In type 2, for example, lifestyle factors appear to be more influential than genetics. go.usa.gov/xU6PT

State agencies are closed Monday, November 11, in observance of Veterans Day. The central office and all county health departments will resume regular operating hours on Tuesday, November 12. Have a safe and healthy holiday and thank you to all the Veterans.

This Saturday,11/9, is National Diabetes Heart Connection Day. Did you know people with type 2 diabetes have more than two times the risk for developing heart disease? Please help save a life and share this post to spread the word about the connection between diabetes and heart disease.

Making the DIABETES HEART Connection

November is National Home Care and Hospice Month. Receiving home care is a safer alternative for most. Your chances of infection are much lower compared to stays in hospitals and nursing homes. For more information about Alabama Department of Public Health's Home Care Services visit: go.usa.gov/xU56f

Alabama Department of Public Health's Oral Health Office is proud to announce its 3rd annual Share Your Smile with Alabama Photo Contest! Two 3rd graders, 1 boy and 1 girl, will be selected as winners. Deadline to enter is November 30. Full rules and details are available at go.usa.gov/xE5xv.

15 million people in the U.S. are living with COPD. People often assume being short of breath is a normal part of getting older, but it’s not. Learn the signs and symptoms of COPD and see if you are at risk: bit.ly/32V1nFp

Sugar Shock Monday Fact: No matter how thin you are, you can still get diabetes. Diabetes isn't related to how you look, it comes from insulin resistance, which causes high blood sugar. Right now, 30 million people in the U.S. have diabetes. Of that, 12% of people with diabetes are "normal weight". Could you have prediabetes? Take this online test: go.usa.gov/xyFv3

Fall celebrations like Halloween and Harvest Day are fun times for children, who can dress up in costumes, enjoy parties, and eat yummy treats. These celebrations also provide a chance to give out healthy snacks, get physical activity, and focus on safety. Check out these tips to help make the festivities fun and safe for trick-or-treaters and party guests. go.usa.gov/xpYGj

When should you get a flu vaccine? You should get vaccinated before flu viruses begins spreading in your community, since it takes about two weeks after vaccination for antibodies to develop in the body and provide protection against flu. Make plans to get vaccinated early in fall, before flu season begins. CDC recommends that people get a flu vaccine by the end of October, if possible. For more information including who should get a flu shot visit go.usa.gov/xpYkZ.

Dr. Dee Jones, Alabama State Public Health Vet, and his sidekick Lilly can be scheduled to come to your school to present basic principles of animal safety and welfare. Contact dee.jones@adph.state.al.us to schedule something today!

Alcohol is the most commonly used substance of abuse among young people in America. There are increased risks and a range of negative consequences related to underage drinking including car crashes, suicides, injuries and murders. Read more at: go.usa.gov/xpCsz

October is Domestic Violence Awareness Month. Employment-related abuse prevents the victim from earning money by:
* Preventing victim from going to work
* Sabotaging a victim's employment
* Interfering with a victim's work performance through harassing activities, such as frequent phone calls or unannounced visits
* Demanding that the victim quits her/his job
* Preventing the victim from looking for jobs or attending job interviews
Learn more in NCADV's "Quick Guide: Economic and Financial Abuse" http://ow.ly/MrR150wKYNd
#DVFacts #DV101

Did you know children’s hands and toys can pick up household dust or exterior soil contaminated by lead? Be sure to move children’s outdoor play areas away from bare soil and the sides of your home. Wet mop floors and wet wipe surfaces indoors often to reduce the risk of lead exposure! #NLPPW2019 #leadfreekids https://www.epa.gov/lead/protect-your-family-exposures-lead

Keeping your hands clean is the number one way to prevent the spread of infection. Wash your hands with soap and water or use hand sanitizer often. For more information about keeping your hands clean visit bit.ly/33IZU5e.

Substance use negatively affects U.S. industry through lost productivity, workplace accidents and injuries, employee absenteeism, low morale, and increased illness. U.S. companies lose billions of dollars a year because of employees' alcohol and drug use and related problems. Encourage people with alcohol and drug problems to seek help because working drug free is everyone's responsibility! go.usa.gov/xQBxF

Research has identified periodontal (gum) disease as a risk factor for heart and lung disease, diabetes, premature, low birth weight babies and a number of other conditions. No one can be truly healthy unless he or she is free from the burden of oral diseases and conditions. go.usa.gov/xVfCV #brushyourteeth #nationaldentalhygienemonth

Vaccines are everybody’s responsibility. Each of us has an important role to play in eliminating the spread of vaccine preventable diseases. Learn more at go.usa.gov/xVwFa

Today is National Latino AIDS Awareness Day. Stigma, fear, and discrimination may affect the lives of some Hispanics/Latinos and can be barriers to seeking HIV testing or treatment. Living with HIV or not…we’re in this together. We all have a role to play. Help stop HIV stigma. For more information on HIV and treatment: go.usa.gov/xn9Mw

We are closed Monday, October 14, in observance of Columbus Day. Alabama Department of Public Health and all county health departments will resume regular operating hours on Tuesday, October 15. Have a safe and healthy weekend!

Everyone experiences depression and anxiety from time to time. However, when feelings of anxiety or depression are overwhelming & prevent you from doing everyday activities, there is hope. Learn more about treatment options: bit.ly/1HnG92I
#MentalIllnessAwarenessWeek

Today is #WorldMentalHealthDay! Taking care of your mental health is just as important to your overall well being as your physical health. Find out more about different mental health conditions, symptoms and treatments by clicking on this link: bit.ly/2MydxwY

This week is #MentalIllnessAwarenessWeek! Today let's talk about Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). PTSD can occur at any age and is directly associated with exposure to trauma. For more information on PTSD causes, symptoms and diagnosis go to bit.ly/30TUna1.

This week is #MentalIllnessAwarenessWeek! Today let's talk about Obsessive Compulsive Disorder. Although people with OCD may know their thoughts and behavior don't make sense, they are often unable to stop them. Learn more about OCD symptoms, causes and treatment at bit.ly/2nu3Uai

October is National Bullying Prevention Month. Bullying can affect everyone—those who are bullied, those who bully, and those who witness bullying. Bullying is linked to many negative outcomes including impacts on mental health, substance use, and suicide. The good news is that bullying is preventable. Find out more: go.usa.gov/xQ3DJ
Going on now! Our annual Walk-In Flu Clinic October 3 and October 4. Hours are 8 AM - 4 PM. Come see us and knock out the flu!

What is the safest way for your baby to sleep? Babies sleep safest when they sleep alone on their back in an uncluttered crib or other safe sleep surface.There are about 3,500 sleep-related deaths among US babies each year. Parents and caregivers can help create a safe sleep area for babies by taking the following steps: go.usa.gov/xVwHN

2 October 2019 at 09:34 ·
ADPH has confirmed the state's first death from vaping-associated illness. Read our full news release at go.usa.gov/xVAUa.

October is Domestic Violence Awareness Month. One in four women in the United States experiences violence from an intimate partner. Intimate partner violence includes domestic abuse, sexual assault, verbal and emotional abuse, coercion, and stalking. Violence and abuse can cause physical and emotional problems that last long after the abuse. If you’ve experienced violence or abuse, it is never your fault, and you can get help. go.usa.gov/xPKDA

Today is Walk and Bike to School Day and October is International Walk to School Month. Walking and bicycling to school enables children to incorporate the regular physical activity they need each day while also forming healthy habits that can last a lifetime. Regular physical activity helps children build strong bones, muscles and joints, and it decreases the risk of obesity. Learn more at go.usa.gov/xQ8BD
We will hold our annual Walk-In Flu Clinic October 3 and October 4. Hours are 8 AM - 4 PM. Make plans to get your shot and beat the flu bug!!

ADPH recommends that all consumers consider refraining from the use of electronic cigarette and vape products until national and state investigations into vaping-related deaths and illnesses are complete. Read our full press release at go.usa.gov/xVfjh.

September 28 is World Rabies Day. Rabies is a deadly viral disease that can spread through bites or scratches from an infected animal. Rabies is preventable if proper treatment is given before symptoms occur, but is fatal once symptoms are present. Learn more about vaccination and other prevention methods at go.usa.gov/xVfCQ.

Today is National Gay Men's HIV/AIDS Awareness Day. People who don’t know they have HIV cannot get the medicine they need to stay healthy and prevent transmitting HIV to their partners. Therefore, they may transmit the infection to others without knowing it. Free testing and services are often available. Here is a list of organizations and clinics that provide HIV testing in Alabama: go.usa.gov/xnsVF

You know it's time to quit! Here's 50 good reasons to stop smoking today.
UNITYPOINT.ORG
50 Reasons to Stop Smoking TODAY

Today is National Women's Health and Fitness Day. Physical activity can help you maintain a healthy weight, lower cholesterol and blood pressure all of which can help decrease your risk of developing heart disease. Find out more at go.usa.gov/xnAHh

September is National Cholesterol Education Month, a good time to get your blood cholesterol checked and take steps to lower it if it is high. High cholesterol usually doesn’t have any symptoms. As a result, many people do not know that their cholesterol levels are too high. For more information about good and bad cholesterol and how it can affect your heart check out go.usa.gov/xVdZA
Scale Back Alabama 2020 is right around the corner! Put these important dates on your calendar, and keep an eye on scalebackalabama.com for details.

Today is Falls Prevention Awareness Day. Falls are the most common cause of injury among older adults, but most falls can be prevented. You have the power to reduce your risk and protect your older loved ones from a serious fall. Stay safe by following these tips! go.usa.gov/xRJsE
VIMEO.COM
6 Steps to Prevent a Fall

Firing up the grill this weekend? Cooking meat to a safe internal temperature kills harmful germs that could make you sick. Be a #FoodSafety Hero by using a food thermometer to make sure your food is safe to eat. Learn more at go.usa.gov/xyuBe.

It's #SepticSmartWeek! Today's #SepticSmart tip: remember that anything you put down the drain will impact your septic system. Go easy with the harsh chemicals, cleaners and detergents. Learn more on maintaining an effective septic system at epa.gov/septic.

For each suicide, it is estimated that at least 6 other people are intimately affected. The National Suicide Prevention Lifeline is a national network of local crisis centers that provides free and confidential emotional support to people in suicidal crisis or emotional distress 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. #BeThe1ToHelp go.usa.gov/xPqAy

September is Childhood #Obesity Awareness Month. Many factors can have an impact on childhood obesity, including eating and physical activity behaviors, genetics, metabolism, family environment, community and social factors. Here are ways parents and the community can help prevent and support healthy growth in children: go.usa.gov/xVmM4

September is National Preparedness Month. We've got tips on preparing for everything from #hurricanes to #earthquakes, plus planning for special needs, newborns and more. See our tips at go.usa.gov/xVE8B. #BeReady #PreparedNotScared

Today, September 18, is National HIV/AIDS and Aging Awareness Day. The prevalence of HIV among older adults is reaching staggering rates. About 1 in 4 adults in the United States who are living with HIV infection are aged 50 or older. With advanced treatment options, HIV positive individuals are living longer lives. It is important to "Know Your Status, Manage Your Health, and Live Your Best Life." For more information visit go.usa.gov/xVBxR
We will hold our annual Walk-In Flu Clinic October 3 and October 4. Hours are 8 AM - 4 PM. Make plans to get your shot and beat the flu bug!!

Every day across America, parents and caregivers drive young children to and from school, daycare, the store, and around town in car seats and boosters. Yet nearly half of all car seats are installed incorrectly, which means your child may not be traveling as safely as possible.Learn more about the type of car seat your child should be in, and how to use it the right way: go.usa.gov/xPc2e

It's #SepticSmartWeek! Today's #SepticSmart tip: remember to have your septic tank regularly inspected. Not only does it protect your health, it can also save you lots of money on unexpected repairs. Learn more on maintaining an effective septic system at epa.gov/septic.
September is National Brain Injury Awareness Month.Looking for info on sports concussion? CDC HEADS UP can prepare everyone to help keep kids safe this fall! https://www.cdc.gov/HEADSUP.

Today is #WorldSuicidePreventionDay. If you’re concerned about yourself or someone else, please call the Lifeline at 1-800-273-8255. They are available 24/7, and it's free and confidential. Learn more at alabamapublichealth.gov/suicide. #SuicidePreventionWeek #BeThere

September is National #SickleCellAwareness Month. Sickle Cell disease is a genetic condition in which "sickle" shaped red blood cells stick together and block blood and oxygen from reaching all parts of the body, leading to health issues such as pain, anemia, infection, and strokes. Learn more at go.usa.gov/xV5PX.

September is National Food Safety Education Month! Germs can grow almost anywhere in your kitchen. Be a Food Safety Hero by washing all surfaces that come into contact with food thoroughly with hot, soapy water. https://go.usa.gov/xyuBe

September is National Fruit and Veggies Month. It's a time for everyone to enjoy all the fruits and veggies that you know and love – fresh, frozen, canned, dried and 100% juice – that can taste great and are proven to support your health and happiness! Looking for great recipes and fun ways to add fruit and veggies to your diet? We got you covered! go.usa.gov/xRuYS #haveaplant

September is Childhood Cancer Awareness Month. Did you know many childhood cancers have higher survival rates when they are diagnosed early? Unfortunately, kids' cancers are sometimes overlooked or misdiagnosed because early symptoms are mistakenly attributed to common injuries or illnesses. Help raise awareness by sharing these early warning signs of childhood cancer. go.usa.gov/xV8R5

Suicide rates among teens and young adults have reached their highest point in nearly two decades. A few simple steps can help suicide-proof your home and possibly save a teen's life. go.usa.gov/xV8Df
Other than your doctor, how do you get information regarding health issues? Please take this survey which takes less than a minute and it is anonymous. We appreciate your help. bit.ly/2lvOO2A

September is National Preparedness Month. Did you know most homeowners’ and renters’ insurance does not cover flood damage? Learn more about flood insurance at FloodSmart.gov #FloodSmart #PreparedNotScared
Our office is closed Monday, September 2, in observance of Labor Day. We will resume regular operating hours on Tuesday, September 3. Have a safe and healthy holiday!

Knowing what to serve and eat can sometimes be a challenge especially for people with diabetes. While eating healthy foods is important for everyone, it's essential for people with diabetes. For great recipes and tips on planning meals visit go.usa.gov/xnKeM
Alabama Department of Public Health encourages food service owners and managers to consider requiring hepatitis A vaccine for all food workers. Read the full press release at go.usa.gov/xVDXY.

DEADLINE EXTENDED TO SEPTEMBER 15! Knowing what health issues are most important to Alabamians will help ADPH serve all communities better in the future. Please take a moment to fill out a short survey about the health issues and health challenges facing your local community. Be sure and share with your family and friends. go.usa.gov/xmS9g

SepticTank Owners: Keep cars and heavy vehicles parked away from the drain field and tank. Maintain plants and vegetation near the system to ensure roots do not block drains. Learn more ways to be a good septic owner and maintain your tank: go.usa.gov/xQrmS. It can be costly to repair or replace it!

Women, Infants and Children (WIC) is a supplemental nutrition program for pregnant women, breastfeeding women, women who had a baby within the last six months, infants, and children under the age of five. One must meet income requirements and have a nutritional risk that proper nutrition could help to improve. How do you know if you qualify?go.usa.gov/xVTrd

In honor of National Tooth Fairy Day we want to remind you that your overall health depends on your oral health. Brushing, flossing, and regular dental checkups are key to maintaining good dental health. Need information on locating a dentist? Public health clinics, Medicaid providers, ALLKids providers, and other dental provider lists are available: go.usa.gov/xV4tg

Planning is underway for #ScaleBackAlabama 2020. This free statewide 10-week weight-loss challenge will start in January! Be sure to visit our website: scalebackalabama.com in December for more information. In the meantime, follow us on social media to receive updates.

The process for entering into a legal marriage in Alabama will change starting August 29. Persons wanting to marry will need to access a new marriage certificate form online at alabamapublichealth.gov/vitalrecords/marriage-certificates.html. Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH) website includes instructions for completing and filing the new form, as well as answers to some FAQs about the marriage law. Read ADPH full news release: go.usa.gov/xVgbA.
August is #NationalBreastfeedingMonth. ADPH's Perinatal program offers a wide range of educational and support resources for mothers who are breastfeeding their infant. Find them at go.usa.gov/xUwyX.

On-time vaccination throughout childhood is essential because it helps provide immunity before children are exposed to potentially life-threatening diseases. See more information for parents here: go.usa.gov/xyPFY

August 17 is National Love My Feet Day. Our feet are our primary mode of transportation. They quietly and faithfully help us stand, swim, run, walk, play sports, jog, skip and dance. It is important that we take good care of our feet. If you have diabetes, here’s a way to keep standing on your own two feet: go.usa.gov/xVC5Q

The 17th Annual FOCUS Rally, an annual event for students in grades 7-12, is being held in Tuscaloosa on September 10, and Talladega on September 18. Topics include vaping, bullying, suicide, and more. Registration is now open at thefocusprogram.com/focus-rallies.

Today is National Relaxation Day and it is an important day as we all need a break from the fast-paced and often hectic lifestyles we live. Taking time to recuperate and rejuvenate our tired minds and bodies may help prevent many health risks. Here are some great relaxation tips: mayocl.in/2Z80z1s

Change your numbers. Change your life. You have the power to lower your blood pressure. And, when you do, you'll have more time for all the people, places, and things you love most. Commit to a plan. Need help? go.usa.gov/xPyed

Do you need a copy of a birth, marriage, death, or divorce certificate? Customers can obtain most vital records from the Center for Health Statistics through their county health department in 30 minutes or less. Records may also be obtained through the mail in about 7-10 days and you can also order online: go.usa.gov/xVcMj

Recent changes in Alabama law will prohibit the sale of alternative nicotine products, including vape products, to anyone under the age of 19. The changes also prohibit the advertisement of vaping as a healthy alternative to smoking, and will prevent vape shops from opening within 1,000 feet of schools and daycare centers. Learn more about the changes at go.usa.gov/xPAMx.

With nearly 60,000 coaches of recreational sports in Alabama, it is important to train and educate all coaches, including volunteers, about the warning signs of youth sports injury. The Coach Safety Act, Alabama Act 2018-0496, spells out the training requirements for volunteer coaches. Read our full news release on the Act at go.usa.gov/xyhaX.
Kids Eat Right Month is a great time for families to learn how to shop smarter, cook healthy and eat right! Check out these tips and activity ideas: https://sm.eatright.org/KERMpk #KERmonth

Some places in Alabama could reach a heat index of 105 degrees today! Stay cool and drink lots of water. Heat stroke can occur when a person's temp rises quickly and they are unable to sweat and cool down. Death or disability can follow. Learn the signs at go.usa.gov/xNe6j.

Diabetes, even if it is well managed, can make it harder for your immune system to fight infections. You may be at greater risk of more serious problems from an illness compared to people without diabetes. See why it’s important to stay up to date on vaccines: go.usa.gov/xyPFD

Today is National Fresh Breath Day! Will you be having onion or garlic tonight with your dinner? Do yourself (and those close to you) a favor - brush and floss those odors away after you eat! (It's good for your health, too - learn more: go.usa.gov/xyJae.)

The WIC Program of Alabama recognizes August as Breastfeeding Awareness Month. This month is about the importance of support from health professionals, employers, public health, families and communities to empower parents for successful #breastfeeding. For useful tips on getting breastfeeding support visit go.usa.gov/xyuuC

We're just over one week away from our August 15 deadline - have you had a chance to take our survey about the health issues and challenges in your local community? Knowing what health issues are most important to Alabamians will help ADPH serve all communities better in the future. Please take a moment to fill out our short survey at go.usa.gov/xmS9g. If you have already, we thank you for your time!

Even though many serious vaccine-preventable diseases are uncommon in the United States, some are common in other parts of the world. Even if your family does not travel internationally, you could come into contact with international travelers anywhere in your community. Are your vaccinations up to date? https://go.usa.gov/xyAaJ

The Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH) is pleased to welcome Shannon Williams as our new District Outreach Coordinator for the Southeastern District (Coffee, Houston, and Pike counties). Shannon will be working with health care providers to support and improve community health outcomes for citizens with diabetes and cardiovascular diseases. For more information call (334) 393-5512.

Today marks the start of National Breastfeeding Month and World Breastfeeding Week! Breastfeeding is a natural and beneficial source of nutrition and provides the healthiest start for an infant. Find resources, including Mother's Milk Depot locations, at go.usa.gov/xRPAR

The 17th Annual FOCUS Rally, an annual event for students in grades 7-12, is being held in Tuscaloosa on September 10, and Talladega on September 18. Topics include vaping, opiate epidemic, bullying, suicide, and more. Learn more at go.usa.gov/xyFhG.

More than 1 in 3 adults in the U.S. have prediabetes, and 90% don’t even know they have it. Could you be one of them? Take charge of your health. Take this prediabetes risk test today and share results with your health care provider. go.usa.gov/xyFfw
Proper use of child safety seats & seat belts can prevent death, injury in crashes. Are you using them the right way? http://go.usa.gov/KKJw #ChildSafety
Sunday, July 28, is World Hepatitis Day. Learn more about prevention and see if you are at risk go.usa.gov/5FbT

Septic Tank Owners: Did You Know?
You should have your #SepticTank inspected yearly and pumped every 3-5 years by a licensed technician. It keeps you and others healthy, saves you money, and protects your property value and the environment. Contact us! More information: go.usa.gov/xQrmS. Go to www.aowb.state.al.us for a list of licensed technicians.

Planning a trip to one of Alabama's coastal beaches? Be sure to visit the Coastal Alabama Beach Monitoring Program: adem.alabama.gov/programs/coastal/beachMonitoring.cnt for details on routine sample testing results that assess water quality. Additionally, the beach flag warning system: gulfshores.com/beach-water-activities/beaches/beach-flag-warning-system and weather forecast of coastal areas: weather.gov/mob are useful tools to keep swimmers educated in preparation for beach trips.

Did a meal make you sick? ADPH uses information from foodborne illness complaints to better identify and investigate illness and food establishments. If you got sick after eating at a restaurant or a catered event, please fill out our Foodborne Illness Complaint Form: go.usa.gov/xPjjy.

Fresh fruits and vegetables make a great-looking, great-tasting meal. Plus, the health benefits pile up the more you pile on your plate - from providing vitamins and minerals to reducing the risk of many diseases. For more ideas on ways to add fruits and veggies to your diet: go.usa.gov/xRFCv

It's National Youth Sports Week! Training courses are available for unpaid/volunteer coaches working with youth 14 and under to reduce the likelihood of a child being injured. Learn more at go.usa.gov/xyyzh.

This week is National Youth Sports Week!. Being a teenager can be stressful. Regular exercise through sports can help boost moods and reduce stress. Staying connected with coaches or teammates can provide emotional support.

According to the American Kennel Club, nearly 1,000 house fires each year are accidentally started by pets. As today is Pet Fire Safety Day, it's a good time to review tips on preventing your pets from starting fires: bit.ly/2um3SRT. ADPH's Injury Prevention Branch offers tips on keeping the whole family, including pets, safe in the event of a house fire: go.usa.gov/xUkvk
Did you know that just one water-filled can or bottle in your yard can be a hatching site for thousands of mosquitoes? Get tips on getting keeping mosquitoes away from your home at go.usa.gov/xyTYT.

Alabama Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS) mails a survey to randomly selected new moms asking about their lives before, during and shortly after their pregnancies. By sharing, they can help us understand why some babies are born healthy and others are not. All new moms should keep an eye out for a PRAMS survey packet in their mailbox 2-4 months after delivery. Visit www.alabamapublichealth.gov/prams for more information.

The Houston County Health Department provides free HIV Testing. For more information, please call us at 334-678-2800 or visit our website at:

Ready
25 June 2019 at 12:18 ·
Summer storms aren’t the only hazard to watch out for this season! As you head outdoors, stay safe by knowing these signs of heat exhaustion & how to respond.
Signs of heat exhaustion:
Paleness, muscle cramps, fainting, nausea and vomiting
Actions: Lie down in air conditioning, loosen or remove clothing, take sips of a cool sports drink that has salt and sugar
☀️ 🌡️
Signs of heat stroke: Dizziness, confusion, hot and dry skin with no sweat, rapid pulse
Actions: Call 911 and cool down the person with whatever possible until medical help arrives.
—-
More: Ready.gov/Heat

Lightning Safety Awareness Week is observed June 23 - 29
National Lightning Safety Awareness week was started in 2001 to call attention to this underrated killer. Since then, U.S. lightning fatalities have dropped from about 50 per year to about 30. This reduction in fatalities is largely due to greater awareness of the lightning danger, and people seeking safety when thunderstorms threaten.

There are several scams that have surfaced again that you need to be aware of. If you have elderly family or friends, make sure to reinforce ways for them to not compromise their personal information.
The first scam involves small businesses that take credit card orders over the phone such as pizza restaurants. The scammers will run into the business and ask to make an emergency phone call. They will call a predesignated number, enter a forwarding code and leave. All calls from customers to the establishment are now rerouted to the scammers posing as the legitimate business personnel. They will take the order and credit card information, and the card has now been compromised.

With most people spending more time outdoors in late spring and summer, the Alabama Department of Public Health reminds people of all ages to protect their exposed skin from the sun’s ultraviolet (UV) rays and practice sun safety.
Continued skin damage over time increases a person’s risk of developing skin cancer, and UV rays can also damage eyes, which increases the risk of cataracts. Unprotected skin exposure, either from the sun or artificial sources like tanning beds, can cause irreversible damage in as little as 15 minutes.
It is very important to not only protect your skin but also be aware of any changes. A change in your skin is the most common sign of skin cancer. Remember, not… More

Alabama families may qualify for the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children, better known as WIC. If you are a woman who is pregnant, who had a baby within the past six months, who is breastfeeding or who is the parent or guardian of a child up to age 5, you are encouraged to apply for WIC at your local county health department or WIC agency.
Participants in the program receive free nutrition education and breastfeeding peer counseling support. In addition, participants have the option to receive up to three months of food benefits at a time for each qualified family member. Currently, Alabama WIC is transitioning from paper food instruments to electronic…

Protecting your parents from financial exploitation:
Financial exploitation or abuse of older adults occurs when a person’s resources are used by another for personal profit or gain, or actions that deprive an older person of the benefits entitled to them. No one is immune. This sort of theft can happen to anyone regardless of social standing and education levels.
Financial abuse can come from all corners. Some businesses prey on older adults and use unfair, deceptive, and abusive practices. That said, not all of the abusers are strangers. Many times financial exploitation is committed by a person that your loved one knows and trusts.
Read the rest of this article and other information on the Active Daily Living website, https://sarcoa.dailylivingadvice.com

Safe Boating is today’s topic for Summer Safety Week.
Practice boating safety to keep yourself or a loved one from becoming the next boating casualty. Use the lessons you’ve already learned from driving a car when you are piloting a boat: watch where you’re going, don’t drink if you’re the designated boat pilot, buckle up and wear your life jacket.

A stroke occurs when the brain’s blood supply is blocked by a blood clot or damaged vessel. Without a constant supply of oxygen from the bloodstream, brain cells struggle to remain active and are lost at a rate of approximately 1.9 million per minute.
To recognize the signs of stroke, use the acronym FAST:
Face. Ask the person to smile. If the person is experiencing a stroke, one side of the mouth may droop.
Arms. Ask the person to raise both arms. Stroke will often cause one arm to drift downward.
Speech. Ask the person to repeat a sentence. Stroke may cause speech to be slurred.
Time. If you see signs of a possible stroke, immediately call 911.

Testicular Cancer Awareness Month is observed in April to bring awareness to the most common type of cancer in men ages 15-35 years.
Ten Symptoms of Testicular Cancer:
1. Painless lump in the testicle
2. Swelling of the testicle or scrotum
3. Shrinking of a testicle
4. Scrotal heaviness
5. Groin ache
6. A build up of fluid in the scrotum
7. Testicular or scrotum pain
8. Enlargement or tenderness of the breasts
9. Lower back pain
10. Enlarged or swollen lymph nodes

Will you be selected? Every month around 125 new mothers in Alabama are randomly selected from birth certificate records to participate in the Alabama Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System's (PRAMS) survey. Alabama #PRAMS is a survey that asks new moms about their lives before, during and shortly after their pregnancies. By sharing, you can help us understand why some babies are born healthy and others are not. As a thank you for participating, we'll send your choice of diapers, a manicure set, an insulated bag, or a PRAMS onesie! New moms, keep an eye out for a PRAMS survey packet in your mailbox 2-4 months after delivery - you may get selected! According to the National Kidney Foundation, 1 in 3 American adults is at risk for kidney disease. What puts you at risk for kidney disease? Major risk factors include diabetes, high blood pressure, a family history of kidney failure and being age 60 or older.
Kidney disease often has no symptoms, and it can go undetected until very advanced. But a simple urine test can tell you if you have kidney disease. Remember, it's important to get tested because early detection and treatment can slow or prevent the progression of kidney disease.

Nearly 80 percent of cardiac events can be prevented, cardiovascular diseases continue to be a woman’s greatest health threat.
If you have any of these signs, call 9-1-1 and get to a hospital right away.
1. Uncomfortable pressure, squeezing, fullness or pain in the center of your chest. It lasts more than a few minutes or goes away and comes back.
2. Pain or discomfort in one or both arms, the back, neck, jaw or stomach.
3. Shortness of breath with or without chest discomfort.
4. Other signs such as breaking out in a cold sweat, nausea or lightheadedness.
5. As with men, women’s most common heart attack symptom is chest pain or discomfort. But women are somewhat more likely than men to experience some of the other common symptoms, particularly shortness of breath, nausea/vomiting and back or jaw pain.

A 4-month-old stray puppy that had recently been taken in by Dothan city and Houston County Animal Control has been confirmed to have rabies. The puppy was one of a litter of four that was treated and held for the required observation period before adoption.
The puppy began showing abnormal neurological signs soon after being transferred to a local rescue group, and was taken to a local veterinarian for treatment. The animal died shortly after and was tested for rabies by the Alabama Department of Public Health. Rabies is rare in domestic animals because of vaccination requirements, but very young, stray animals often are a greater risk of having rabies because they have not been…

About 1 in 10 teens who have been on a date have also been physically abused by a boyfriend or girlfriend in the last year. Teen Dating Violence Awareness Month is a national effort to raise awareness and protect teens from violence.
According to the CDC, Teen Dating Violence is defined as the physical, sexual, psychological, or emotional aggression within a dating relationship, including stalking. It can occur in person or electronically and might occur between a current or former dating partner. Several different words are used to describe teen dating violence. Below are just a few:
Teen Dating Violence
Relationship abuse
Intimate partner violence
Relationship violence
Dating abuse
Domestic abuse
Domestic violence

Good afternoon partners!
National Weather Service
With our afternoon forecast update today, we have not made any major changes to the previous forecast and the email from yesterday afternoon. We are still actively monitoring a strong cold front that will move through fairly quickly from Tuesday morning to late Tuesday evening.
We continue to have only rain in our forecast for the entire area. Rain should overspread from west to east starting around 7AM EST/6AM CST in the west and 11AM EST in the east. Rain will end in the afternoon and evening (see attached graphic). There could still be a few flurries in southeast Alabama as the rain is ending.
Temperatures will quickly drop through the night with lows in the lower 20s to around 30 (right around bus stop time) with wind chills in the upper teens to lower 20s. See the graphics for more detail. There could also be a few slick spots overnight especially on bridges and overpasses.
We do not expect any widespread or significant impacts with this event. As always, give us a call if you have any questions!

Dothan Warming Station Opening Tuesday Night, January 29th - Volunteers & Supplies are Needed
The First Baptist Church Dothan, 300 West Main St. will open a Warming Station in the Family Life Center directly behind the Church on Tuesday night at 7 p.m., January 29th. There will be no check-ins past 9 p.m. Cots will be spread out and a warm place provided for the night. Soup, snacks, coffee and drinks will also be provided.

Remember, a warming station in Dothan opens when temperatures are 28 degrees or lower.

Missed your window to sign up for Part A and/or Part B during your Initial Enrollment Period? You may be able to sign up now, during the General Enrollment Period, but don’t wait—General Enrollment closes on March 31. Learn more about enrollment periods at https://www.medicare.gov/sign-up-change-plans/how-do-i-get-parts-a-b/part-a-part-b-sign-up-periods

According to the CDC, older adults & people with severe chronic medical conditions like heart, lung or kidney disease seem to be at higher risk for more serious #COVID19 illness. More information on ways to reduce your risk of exposure to #coronavirus ➡ https://www.medicare.gov/medicare-coronavirus.

Are you getting enough sleep? Adults age 65+ need at least 7 hours of good sleep a night to function well, both mentally and physically. Coming up short? Here are some tips for a better night’s sleep: https://www.cdc.gov/chronicdisease/resources/infographic/sleep.htm #SleepAwarenessMonth

Scammers will do anything to get your Medicare Number. Guard your card like it’s a credit card. Only share your Medicare Number with people you trust, like your doctor or pharmacist. Medicare.gov/fraud.

• Limit close contact with others

Celebrate National Nutrition Month—create a healthy eating plan and find physical activities that fit your lifestyle. https://go.cms.gov/39hO2KE

Need to sign up for Part D (also known as Medicare prescription drug coverage)? These 6 tips can help you choose Medicare drug coverage that works for you: https://go.cms.gov/3bwbrtt
#HeartMonth Reminder: Keep your heart healthy with Medicare-covered cardiovascular disease screenings https://go.cms.gov/31FfHSG.

With today’s hectic schedules, it can be hard to find time to prepare healthy meals. MyPlate offers tips on how to make small changes to improve your diet and find healthy food choices. https://go.cms.gov/31EebQT #WellnessWednesday
Are you new to Medicare? Before you choose your coverage, learn about the different parts of Medicare and 3 steps to help you get started. https://go.cms.gov/37fMRJV

Medicare Advantage Plans, sometimes called “Part C” or “MA Plans,” are a type of Medicare health plan offered by a private company that contracts with Medicare to give you your Part A and Part B benefits. Most Medicare Advantage Plans also offer prescription drug coverage. https://go.cms.gov/2Sfb66M
Is your medical item or service covered by Medicare? There’s a quick way to check! Download our “What’s Covered” app: https://go.cms.gov/39qSvdM

Heart disease is the No. 1 killer in women. Yet, only 1 in 5 American women believe that heart disease is her greatest health threat. What can you do? Start by knowing your cholesterol and blood pressure numbers. Eating a healthy diet and being physically active reduce your risk, too. https://go.cms.gov/2Hbstil #HeartMonth

Does #Medicare seem like alphabet soup? Get to know your Medicare ABCD’s, starting with Part A. Medicare Part A (Hospital Insurance) covers inpatient hospital stays, care in a skilled nursing facility, hospice care, and some home health care. https://go.cms.gov/3buPkUe

#DYK that nearly half of African American adults have some form of cardiovascular disease? See how a ❤-healthy lifestyle can help to keep our hearts beating strong. https://go.cms.gov/2Sr6pp2 #HeartMonth #OurHearts
Trying to choose between Original Medicare and a Medicare Advantage Plan? Consider these 7 things to make the best choice for you: https://go.cms.gov/2SdEiLd
Show some love this Valentine’s Day—“say yes” to registering as an organ, eye, and tissue donor. https://go.cms.gov/2SAtkyq

Have a ❤-healthy #ValentinesDay. Take steps to help prevent heart disease. Start by scheduling an appointment with your doctor to discuss your risks and how to lower them. Medicare covers a cardiovascular disease screening every 5 years at no cost to you. https://go.cms.gov/2UnaLjQ

Special Enrollment Periods let you make changes to your Medicare Advantage and Medicare prescription drug coverage when certain events happen in your life, like if you move or lose other insurance coverage. Rules about when you can make changes and the type of changes you can make are different for each Special Enrollment Period. Find more information at https://go.cms.gov/2GQGWjF.
#WellnessWednesday Tip: Be sweet to your ❤ this #HeartMonth & check in on your heart health. There's a lot you can do to prevent heart disease. Learn more: https://go.cms.gov/31TVw3x.
Sign up for Medicare with the Social Security Administration online application—it takes less than 10 minutes to complete. https://go.cms.gov/395NZkE

Protect your Medicare card just like your credit cards. Only give your Medicare Number to doctors, pharmacists, other health care providers, your insurer, or people you trust to work with Medicare on your behalf. https://go.cms.gov/39aBYdP

Heart disease claims the life of 1 in 3 women—for some, that woman is their grandmother, mother, sister, wife, or friend. But, ❤ disease doesn’t have to be a losing battle. #GoRed for the important women in your life. Encourage them to get screened for cardiovascular disease—it’s covered by Medicare. https://go.cms.gov/2RUb0kG #WearRedDay 👗👚👠
Make time for your health. Have you scheduled your yearly wellness visit yet? https://go.cms.gov/37RWu2A
Don’t want to wait 3 months for your Medicare Summary Notice (MSN) to come in the mail? Sign up to get electronic MSNs (eMSNs) every month. https://go.cms.gov/2GRZdwR
Physician Compare helps you find and compare physicians and other clinicians enrolled in Medicare so that you can make informed decisions about your health care. https://go.cms.gov/37Ufz47

Fraudsters are out to get your Medicare Number. If an unknown caller says they’re from Medicare, hang up! Medicare will never call you unexpectedly. Learn more ways to prevent fraud at Medicare.gov/fraud.

When you're first eligible for Medicare, you have a 7-month Initial Enrollment Period to sign up for Part A and/or Part B. But if you missed your chance to sign up, you can enroll now, during the General Enrollment Period. General Enrollment ends on March 31. Learn more about sign-up periods at https://go.cms.gov/2FLKDqi

If you need to replace your Medicare card because it’s damaged or lost, just sign in to your Medicare account to print an official copy. If you don’t have a Medicare account yet, visit MyMedicare.gov to create one.

Review and compare dates and services on your Medicare Summary Notices (MSNs) to make sure services listed and details are correct. If you suspect fraud, report it to 1-800-MEDICARE. https://go.cms.gov/30iFwre
January is glaucoma awareness month, the perfect time to check and see if you’re at high risk for glaucoma. Medicare covers a glaucoma test once every 12 months if you are. https://go.cms.gov/2uFu4Kd

If you’re eligible for Medicare, you may be wondering if you need to sign up now. If you’re over 65 and have employer coverage, in most cases, you don't need to do anything until you (or your spouse) retire or you lose employer coverage. If you didn’t enroll when you were first eligible, the size of your employer determines whether you have to pay a penalty if you enroll later. Learn more at https://go.cms.gov/2tQnQa5

Don’t want to wait to get paper copies of your Medicare Summary Notices (MSNs)? By signing up for eMSNs you’ll get an email every month with a secure link to your MSN online, instead of waiting 3 months for a paper copy. https://go.cms.gov/2ThVGiY

If you get a bill from Medicare for your premiums, you may now be able to pay online with a credit or debit card. It’s fast and secure. Learn more: https://www.medicare.gov/blog/make-medicare-premium-payment-online-2019

"Everybody can be great...because anybody can serve.” —Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.
Find a volunteer opportunity near you: https://go.cms.gov/2QZiIcL #MLKDay
If you’re enrolled in the QMB Program, find out what to do if you get a bill for Medicare-covered items or services (including deductibles, coinsurance, and copayments). https://go.cms.gov/2QELBe0
It’s not too late to get your flu shot. Make an appointment now—it’s your best protection from influenza, and Medicare covers it: https://go.cms.gov/39REmqQ #FightFlu

Over 12,000 women in the U.S. are diagnosed with cervical cancer every year, but with regular screening tests, cervical cancer is the easiest female cancer to prevent. Learn how Medicare covers screenings: https://go.cms.gov/37QNBWm
Medicare offers many preventive services to help you be healthier and detect disease earlier (when it is most treatable). Go here for a full list of preventive services: https://go.cms.gov/2QB2oim

When you're first eligible for Medicare, you have a 7-month Initial Enrollment Period to sign up for Part A and/or Part B starting 3 months before the month you turn 65 and ending 3 months after the month you turn 65. https://go.cms.gov/2R2bVxK
Do you have Medicare along with other health insurance? If so, you may be wondering “who pays first?” Learn how Medicare coordinates with your other coverage at https://go.cms.gov/2tEhnio.

If you’re among the many seniors who head for warmer places during the winter, check to see if your Medicare coverage will go with you. Original Medicare works in all 50 states, but Medicare usually doesn’t cover health care when you’re traveling outside the U.S. Other types of coverage may only apply to your local area. Learn more: https://go.cms.gov/2QXiIbZ

Are you due for a Tdap booster shot to prevent tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis (also called whooping cough)? Contact your Medicare prescription drug plan for more information about your specific coverage. https://www.medicare.gov/coverage/tdap-shots

Did you miss your Initial Enrollment Period last year? You can sign up for Medicare Part A and/or Part B during the General Enrollment Period, which runs from January 1 – March 31. https://www.medicare.gov/sign-up-change-plans/how-do-i-get-parts-a-b/part-a-part-b-sign-up-periods
If you resolved to live a little healthier in 2020, Medicare can help. Take advantage of your free preventive benefits including your yearly wellness visit. https://go.cms.gov/34yr92d
Turning 65 in 2020? Follow these 3 steps to gather information so you can make informed decisions about your #Medicare: https://go.cms.gov/2r826Wa

#Medicare is here to help you make 2020 a year of living healthier. Start by logging into your MyMedicare.gov account. You can track your preventive services and get a 2-year calendar of the Medicare-covered tests and screenings for which you’re eligible. #NewYear2020
2020 will be here soon! Wishing everyone a safe, happy & healthy New Year!

By now, you should have your new Medicare card—with your new Medicare Number. Bring your card to your next doctor’s appointment, to make sure they have your new number in their system. Doing so will help us process your claims. https://go.cms.gov/2Eyx10M
Family caregivers can find community resources nearby by visiting the Eldercare Locator: https://go.cms.gov/2RSJcxA

Are you planning to switch from a Marketplace plan when you become eligible for Medicare? To avoid a gap in coverage, don’t end your Marketplace plan before your Medicare coverage begins. Learn more about canceling your Marketplace plan at https://go.cms.gov/38FOKBn

See how to get Medicare information in an accessible format that works best for your needs: https://go.cms.gov/34UQi8l

Wishing you and yours a Happy Thanksgiving.

Some plans change, some plans remain the same. Now’s the time to look and see if and how your plan has changed for 2020. Use our new Plan Finder to compare plans: https://go.cms.gov/338hfUd #MedicareOE #WaybackWednesday

Want a family member or caregiver to be able to call Medicare on your behalf? Fill out and submit form CMS-10106 online using your MyMedicare.gov account, or download it here to mail a hard copy to us: Medicare.gov/forms-help-resources/medicare-forms
During Open Enrollment, be skeptical of special discounts or freebies that sound too good to be true. https://go.cms.gov/2KFg7RF

Medicare’s redesigned Plan Finder lets you filter plan results by the extra benefits that are important to you, like dental, vision, hearing, transportation and fitness benefits. Compare plans here: https://go.cms.gov/343T5eV. #MedicareOE

Rolling over your current Medicare plan may be the easy thing to do, but it could cost you more next year. Part D plans vary greatly in co-pays, formularies and other ways. Comparing plans really pays. https://go.cms.gov/32pEnxs #MedicareOE

Maybe you travel a lot, or spend part of the year in a different state. If you do, now’s the time to check if your plan will travel with you or if you may want to change plans. https://go.cms.gov/2rponP9 #MedicareOE

Feel confident that you’ve made the best choice for your particular needs? Don’t just look for savings, but for things like if your doctor is still in-network and if your prescriptions are on the plan’s formulary. https://go.cms.gov/2riAM7i #MedicareOE

Lung cancer is the #1 cause of cancer death in the U.S. Every year, nearly 218,000 people are diagnosed with lung cancer and more than 150,000 die from this disease. The best way to prevent lung cancer is to quit smoking and stop using tobacco products. Find out how Medicare can help: https://go.cms.gov/2PWYSyF #GreatAmericanSmokeout
This week is Antibiotic Awareness Week. Check out our blog to make sure you’re using antibiotics the right way: https://go.cms.gov/2KDKMyU #AntibioticResistance

Some people like to compare plans online using the Plan Finder, some prefer to talk it over at 1-800-MEDICARE, and some would rather meet face-to-face with a local SHIP counselor. Whatever your method, find your best plan your best way. https://go.cms.gov/2NptAik #MedicareOE

Costs change. Coverage changes. Your health changes. Use Medicare’s Open Enrollment period to see if you could lower your prescription costs, get extra benefits, or find a plan that works better for your health needs https://go.cms.gov/2CoXfSA. #MedicareOE

Plans can change yearly, and so can your health or prescription needs. Compare the 2020 version of your current plan with other options to see what’s best for you: https://go.cms.gov/34ZdYIn. #MedicareOE

Don’t let your friends and family miss out on their chance to compare coverage options during #MedicareOE. Spread the word—let them know they have until Dec. 7 to make changes for next year. https://go.cms.gov/34CyvlR

It’s a good idea to review your current Medicare coverage and compare it to other choices for the year ahead. You may find a plan that will save you on prescription costs or better meet your health care needs. What could you find? Use the new Plan Finder and see: https://go.cms.gov/2PZTYB5. #MedicareOE
While you’re comparing plans during #MedicareOE, remember there’s no such thing as early bird discounts or limited time offers for enrolling in any plan. https://go.cms.gov/2NP78hx

Caring for a friend or loved one isn’t always easy. But there’s help for caregivers too: https://go.cms.gov/2pEOXTX. #NationalFamilyCaregiverMonth

Is your current plan still your best choice for 2020, or could you do better? Plans change every year, and so can your health, life, and financial situation. Compare plans now—you may find a better plan for 2020: https://go.cms.gov/32o1TdV. #MedicareOE
Today we honor and thank all members of the armed forces past and present for protecting our nation and defending our freedom. Thank you! #VeteransDay

Hard to believe, but Open Enrollment is half over. You have about 4 weeks left to review your current coverage and compare it to your other options. See if you can find lower prescription costs, extra benefits. Start here: https://go.cms.gov/2PtLbqK. #MedicareOE

Have Medicare but facing challenges paying for health care? One of these 4 kinds of Medicare Savings Programs may be able to help you pay your Medicare premiums and other costs: https://go.cms.gov/32VnL1v

Are your lungs trying to tell you something? If you're struggling for air, listen to your lungs—it could be #COPD. With early diagnosis and treatment, COPD can be managed so you can breathe better. https://go.cms.gov/36eEMpn

It’s that time of year—watch football, rake the leaves, and pick a Medicare health or drug plan. The new Medicare Plan Finder makes it easy to compare plans based on quality, convenience, and cost, so you can choose a plan that best meets your needs. Check out the Plan Finder at https://go.cms.gov/2JAfs3H.

Time to ask yourself this all-important question: “What’s the best plan for ME next year?” Perhaps it’s Original Medicare with a prescription drug plan. Or a Medicare Advantage Plan with extra benefits. Explore your options at https://go.cms.gov/2qaErDx. #MedicareOE

There are several ways to get help comparing plans during #MedicareOE. Medicare is here for you 24/7 by phone at 1-800 MEDICARE. Or you can make an appointment with your local State Health Insurance Assistance Program (SHIP) office. Or use Medicare’s new Plan Finder at https://go.cms.gov/2NnPTUt.

Now’s the time to review and compare your Medicare plan options for 2020. See if you can find lower costs, better coverage, or just make sure your current plan is still the best way to go. https://go.cms.gov/2pqOYuu #MedicareOE

Your health needs can change from year to year—so do Medicare plan costs and coverage. Use the annual Medicare Open Enrollment period to compare Medicare Advantage Plans (Part C) and Medicare drug coverage (Part D) offerings to find what’s best for you. Start at https://go.cms.gov/322i4NY #MedicareOE

Seeing more doctors or taking more prescriptions than you did a year ago? Just as your health needs can change from year to year, so do Medicare plans. Compare your choices now to see if you can save money on prescriptions or get extra benefits. Start here: https://go.cms.gov/2NtmmZH #MedicareOE

Compare plans while you can during #MedicareOE. Otherwise, you could miss out on finding extra benefits like vision, dental and hearing, or lower prescription costs. Plans change each year. Check out your options here: https://go.cms.gov/31FgvFv

Guard your Medicare card! Scammers never stop looking for ways to con you—even during #MedicareOE. Don’t give them the chance. Never give out your Medicare Number over the phone to unknown or unexpected callers. https://go.cms.gov/364o6ke
Plans change every year, comparing Plans during Open Enrollment means you could save on prescriptions or get extra benefits. Medicare.gov/plan-compare #MedicareOE

Whether you have questions for yourself, or you’re acting as a caregiver, State Health Insurance Assistance Programs (SHIPs) offer local, personalized counseling and assistance to people with #Medicare and their families. Find a list of contacts in your state: https://go.cms.gov/2BGaAFI #MedicareOE

It’s picking season—pumpkins, apples, Halloween candy… and a #Medicare health or drug plan. Even if your plan hasn’t changed, there could be another plan that works better for you. Find out today: https://go.cms.gov/2PifErF #MedicareOE
Today is National #TakeBackDay—a perfect time to get rid of unused and unwanted prescription drugs. Find your nearest collection site at https://go.cms.gov/2N6B74f

It’s Medicare Open Enrollment—time to look at all your 2020 plan choices and choose what’s best for you. However, be wary of offers that sound too good to be true. And never give your Medicare Number to anyone except your doctor or people you know should have it. More fraud tips: https://go.cms.gov/2Wb0tC3 #MedicareOE

We’ve added an abuse alert icon on Nursing Home Compare so you can tell if a nursing home has been cited for issues related to abuse or neglect. Ensuring quality of care in nursing homes is another example of how we’re committed to empowering you to make health care decisions that are right for you and your loved ones. Check out our blog for more information, https://go.cms.gov/2N5tqve.

Medicare plans change yearly. Even if you’re happy with your current plan, look at the 2020 version for changes, and compare it to your other options to see how your plan stacks up. https://go.cms.gov/2pG8ymd #MedicareOE

If you make less than $18,735 ($25,365 for married couples), you may qualify for the “Extra Help” program. It could reduce your prescription costs to no more than $3.40 for generics and $8.50 for brand-name drugs. Apply online at http://go.cms.gov/helpwithRx #MedicareOE

If you’re shopping for Medicare health and drug plans during Open Enrollment, Medicare.gov is your one-stop shop. Start by exploring plan choices with our redesigned Plan Finder: Medicare.gov/plan-compare #MedicareOE

Make World Osteoporosis Day a day you show your bones some ❤. Talk to your doctor about how to keep your bones healthy and strong 💪. With Medicare Part B, you’re covered for a bone mass measurement that can help to see if you’re at risk for broken bones. https://go.cms.gov/2VxAHaN
It’s #MedicareOE—time to see if you can find lower premiums, extra benefits, or a plan that better fits your health needs. Review your coverage choices at Medicare.gov/plan-compare.

Over 200,000 women are diagnosed with breast cancer each year, making it one of the most common cancers in women. Women between the ages of 50-74 should have a mammogram every year and Medicare covers mammograms at no cost. https://go.cms.gov/2M25Y2A #BreastCancerAwareness #NationalMammographyDay

What mix of Medicare benefits and costs works best with your needs and budget? Now’s the time to review plan choices for 2020 —like Prescription Drug Plans and Medicare Advantage Plans—to see what’s right for you: https://go.cms.gov/2AZaetB #MedicareOE

Medicare drug plans can change in many ways from year to year. Compare plans for premiums, generic vs. brand name drug co-pays, and always check the plan formulary to make sure the prescription drugs you take are covered. https://go.cms.gov/312kBHq #MedicareOE

It’s Day One of Open Enrollment. This is your chance to review and compare your current Medicare coverage with other plan choices for 2020. You could save money, get extra benefits, or both. Plans change, and your health care needs may have changed, too. Start comparing now: https://go.cms.gov/32oOPpO #MedicareOE

Medicare Open Enrollment starts tomorrow! It’s your opportunity to compare 2020 plans and choose what’s best for you. Take a quick look at your coverage choices on pages 5 and 6 of your 2020 “Medicare & You” handbook to see the “big picture”: https://go.cms.gov/31PwxO1 #MedicareOE

We’ve just updated the Medicare Plan Finder with 2020 star ratings for Medicare health and drug plans, just in time for Open Enrollment. Star ratings help you compare the quality of health and drug plans being offered. Although Medicare Open Enrollment doesn’t start until Tuesday, Oct. 15, you can see star ratings now: https://go.cms.gov/2nGQ98i

Concerned that you or a loved one may suffer from depression? Ask your doctor about getting a depression screening—Part B covers one per year, and you pay nothing if your doctor accepts assignment from Medicare. https://go.cms.gov/2pUcAr9 #WorldMentalHealthDay
Most people become eligible for Medicare in the month they turn 65. Learn more now about your Medicare plan options, how and when to apply: https://go.cms.gov/2Izl913
Need a Medicare form? You can find it at https://go.cms.gov/2oYp6FF. We can also get you a form in accessible formats like Braille and large print.
#DYK if you need to replace a lost or damaged Medicare card, you can print a new card from your Medicare account? If you don’t have an account, visit MyMedicare.gov.
Scammers will do anything to get your Medicare Number. Guard your card like it’s a credit card. Only share it with people you trust, like your doctor or pharmacist. Medicare.gov/fraud.

Medicare covers a full range of preventive services to help keep you healthy. You’ll pay nothing for many of them when you get them from a qualified doctor or other health care provider who accepts assignment. https://go.cms.gov/2lR8YVr

You usually don't pay a monthly premium for Medicare Part A (Hospital Insurance) coverage if you or your spouse paid Medicare taxes for a certain amount of time while working. This is sometimes called "premium-free Part A." https://go.cms.gov/2lU5Vfc

Medicare’s redesigned Plan Finder makes it easier than ever to shop for plans and feel confident in your choice. Give it a test drive before Open Enrollment begins on Oct. 15: Medicare.gov/plan-compare #MedicareOE

By now, you should have your new Medicare card—with your new Medicare Number. Bring your card to your next doctor’s appointment, to make sure they have your new number in their system. Doing so will help us process your claims. https://go.cms.gov/2mX7BEI

Someone new in the U.S. is diagnosed with a blood cancer approximately every 3 minutes. That means around 14,000 patients will get this diagnosis during September, which is Blood Cancer Awareness Month. Find ways you can help #FightBloodCancer at https://go.cms.gov/2mqiXRh

Stay one step ahead of the flu–get your flu shot. Flu viruses change quickly, and new vaccines come out each year, so it’s important to get a flu shot EACH year. The flu shot is free for people with Medicare, once per flu season. https://go.cms.gov/2kzXULJ
Fraudsters are out to get your Medicare Number. Don’t give them that chance! Guard your card. Visit Medicare.gov/fraud to learn more.
Happy #FirstDayofFall! 🍁🍂Make the most of your #Medicare preventive benefits this season: https://go.cms.gov/2l2Wnhp

When it comes to enrolling in Medicare, timeliness pays. Be sure to sign up during your 7-month Initial Enrollment Period—that starts 3 months before the month you turn 65, includes your birthday month, and ends 3 months after the month you turn 65. If you miss this window, you may have to pay a Part B late enrollment penalty. Here’s how to get started:
https://go.cms.gov/2kocIgm

If someone offers you "free" genetic testing or “free” orthotic braces and then requests your Medicare Number, just say no! If your personal information is compromised, it may be used in other fraud schemes. If you suspect you’ve been a victim of Medicare fraud, report it to us at 1-800-MEDICARE. https://go.cms.gov/2kmPp6D

Be proactive about your health during #HealthyAgingMonth: eat healthily, aim for 30 minutes of exercise a day, and take advantage of your Medicare preventive services. Here’s what Medicare covers: https://go.cms.gov/2kCy8Xi

The symptoms of ovarian cancer may be hard to recognize. Watch for changes including pelvic or abdominal pain, frequency of urination and bloating. Learn more about spotting signs of ovarian cancer: https://go.cms.gov/2lRgWgO

#DYK 1 in 8 men will get prostate cancer? Early detection can save lives. Medicare covers prostate cancer screenings for men over 50. Spread the word during #PCAM19: https://go.cms.gov/2lZJ15w #EndProstateCancer

If a caller says they’re from Medicare and asks for your Medicare number, it’s probably a scam. Don’t give out your card number. To learn how you can help prevent Medicare fraud visit Medicare.gov/fraud.

Scammers are at it again, this time offering people with Medicare "free" screenings or cheek swabs for genetic testing as a way to get your Medicare information for identity theft or fraudulent billing purposes. Learn more: https://go.cms.gov/2MpjG1D

Change up your daily routine! Exercise and physical activity fall into 4 basic categories—endurance, strength, balance, and flexibility. Doing all 4 will give you more benefits, reduce boredom, and cut your risk of injury. https://go.cms.gov/34AGW1F #Go4LifeMonth #WednesdayWisdom

September is #PainAwarenessMonth. Medicare covers various services to help you manage your pain safely and effectively. Before you take opioids, talk to your doctor about all of your pain treatment options, including physical and occupational therapy, exercise, and taking non-prescription drugs. For more information, visit https://go.cms.gov/2k7EuNU.

Download our “What’s covered” app—it’s FREE on the App Store (https://go.cms.gov/34ywiIY) and Google Play (https://go.cms.gov/34yvGDa). The “What’s covered” app makes it easy to see what items and services Medicare Part A and/or Part B covers, how to get covered benefits & basic cost information.
Today we honor and thank all grandparents for the time, attention, wisdom and caring you give to your families and communities. Happy #GrandparentsDay!

If you’re in a Medicare Advantage Plan (like an HMO or PPO) with prescription drug coverage or in a Medicare Prescription Drug Plan, use that Plan ID card whenever you need care or prescriptions. However, you should carry your Medicare card too — you may be asked to show it so that your doctor can make sure they have your new number in their system. https://go.cms.gov/2ZlAT26
Fraudsters are out to get your Medicare Number. If a caller says they’re from Medicare, hang up! Medicare will never call you unexpectedly. Learn more ways to prevent fraud at Medicare.gov/fraud.

Check out this short video to see how we’re making shopping for healthcare plans easier with our newly redesigned #PlanFinder: https://go.cms.gov/2zxV79z
YOUTUBE.COM
Introducing the New Medicare Plan Finder

It’s back-to-school time—do you know the ABCD’s of Medicare? Whether you’re getting started with Medicare or just need a refresher, this video briefly describes the different parts of Medicare: https://go.cms.gov/2PA1cwW
A MyMedicare account lets you access your Medicare information easily and securely. See claims statements faster, too: https://www.mymedicare.gov/signup.

If you’re in the path of #HurricaneDorian, learn about evacuation routes in your area & how to get your care and prescription drugs if you or a loved one is displaced. More ways to prepare → https://go.cms.gov/2zCmn6J

By now, you should have your new Medicare card—with your new Medicare Number. Bring your card to your next doctor’s appointment so they have your new number in their system. Doing so will help us process your claims. https://go.cms.gov/2ZmU7Uu

If you don’t get Medicare automatically, you’ll need to sign up through the Social Security Administration. This step-by-step guide walks you through the process of applying online: https://go.cms.gov/2wf90Iw.

Our modernized and redesigned Medicare #PlanFinder makes it easier for you to compare coverage option and shop for health and prescription drug plans. Try it out today! https://www.medicare.gov/plan-compare/
It’s a new school year—the perfect time to get to know Medicare from A to D. https://go.cms.gov/2HlZWas

Do you know the best ways to protect yourself and your grandchildren from summer’s strong sun and heat? Start with sunscreen, hats, and sunglasses. Take breaks to hydrate and spend time in the shade. https://go.cms.gov/2Z8eQv5
Are you about to turn 65? Now’s the time to learn about Medicare plan options, and how and when to apply: https://go.cms.gov/2ZaZm5y

Stay safe during storm power outages:
-keep refrigerators closed
-disconnect electronics to avoid power surge damage
-have alternate plans for refrigerating medicines & keeping power-dependent medical devices charged
Learn more at https://go.cms.gov/2LZ81WX.
Have you created your official Medicare account yet? It’s a secure way to access your personal Medicare-related information online any time. https://go.cms.gov/30hCB15
If you currently have health insurance through a Marketplace plan and will soon be eligible for Medicare, find out what you need to do, and when, to change coverage: https://go.cms.gov/2OwECjC

Summer often brings power blackouts. Be ready with:
-fresh batteries in all flashlights,
-a supply of nonperishable food and water,
-fully-charged electronics,
-full gas tanks
More tips: https://go.cms.gov/2LZ81WX

What did you collect in your younger days? Stamps, sports cards, seashells, dolls, or other treasure? Still collecting those or something else? Are you encouraging your grandchildren to start a collection? #ThrowbackThursday
If you don’t get #Medicare automatically, you can sign up online through Social Security Administration. It takes less than 10 minutes to complete the application. https://go.cms.gov/2OWhbp5

#DYK that there’s a vaccine to help prevent pneumonia, but only 67% of adults 65+ have ever gotten it. It’s covered by Medicare Part B, so stick it to pneumonia and get vaccinated. https://go.cms.gov/2Kr7Lwj
Even if you currently have employer coverage, you still may need to make some important Medicare enrollment decisions. Learn more: https://go.cms.gov/2ZO4gX0

Plan out your health coverage before you travel abroad. #Medicare won’t pay for health care services or supplies you get outside the U.S., except in rare cases. If you have a Medigap policy, check to see if it includes coverage outside the U.S. https://go.cms.gov/2Kk3J8F
Fruit salads, hamburgers on the grill, homemade ice pops—what were your favorite summer foods from childhood? #ThrowbackThursday
Today we honor the brave men and women who fought to defend our freedom and risked their lives to serve our country. Thank you for your service and sacrifice. #PurpleHeartDay
MyMedicare gives you access to your personalized information at any time. Use it to check information about your coverage, enrollment status, Medicare claims, and more. MyMedicare.gov

Medicare Part A (Hospital Insurance) covers inpatient hospital stays, care in a skilled nursing facility, hospice care, and some home health care. In most cases, people should enroll in Part A when they turn 65, even if they have health insurance from an employer. Learn more: https://go.cms.gov/2KhZbzU

State Health Insurance Assistance Programs (SHIPs) offer free, in depth, one-on-one insurance counseling and assistance to people with Medicare, their families, and caregivers. Counseling may be in-person or over the phone. https://go.cms.gov/2KawSTY
Years before you got your first car, how did you get around the neighborhood? Bike? Skates? For #ThrowbackThursday, share your best memory of your first wheels. #TBT

Want to access and print your Medicare card? Create a MyMedicare account and view your card online, any time.
https://www.mymedicare.gov/signup

My, how we've grown! Medicare turns 54 today—time to look back on some milestones, and look forward to how #Medicare can help you be healthier this year. Had your Yearly “Wellness” visit yet? Up-to-date on your preventive screenings? Learn more: https://go.cms.gov/2Gyaym2

Watch our latest video this #ADA Anniversary to hear first-hand from people with disabilities and how they overcome challenges in accessing the care they need. #ThankstotheADA #ADA29 https://go.cms.gov/2K7rW24

Navigating Health Care with a Disability: Our Stories, a Focus on People with Disabilities

If you were born between 1945 and 1965, talk with your doctor about getting screened for Hepatitis C, a leading cause of liver cancer. For #WorldHepatitisDay, read our blog to learn more about Hepatitis and the screenings Medicare covers: https://go.cms.gov/2xZzNsQ

If you’re facing difficulties paying for healthcare costs, there may be ways you can save money on your Medicare premiums and other costs even if you don’t qualify for Medicaid. Learn more about our Medicare Savings Programs here, https://go.cms.gov/2JHmkfT.

#DYK the ☀ UV rays can damage unprotected skin in as little as 15 minutes? Make sure you and your grandkids are wearing at least SPF 15 sunscreen with UVA and UVB protection. Find more sun safety tips here: https://go.cms.gov/2JI2zoo
Do you plan on spending time with the grandkids on the water this summer? Make sure you know all the latest water safety tips from the CDC : https://go.cms.gov/2JPhbnG
With a MyMedicare account, sit back and relax knowing that your Medicare claims, card and other info is all in one secure place. https://go.cms.gov/30M9ORX

Share your story with us about how your #healthcare information is shared–from the doctor to patient, doctor to doctor, or plan to plan. We want to know how the sharing, or lack of sharing, has impacted you. Email your story to MyHealthEData@cms.hhs.gov. #ItsMyMedicalRecord
Wouldn’t you prefer to chase your grandkids than paperwork? Create a MyMedicare account to access your claims, Medicare card, and more in one secure place. https://go.cms.gov/2LSWzeb
Fire hydrants, squirt guns, fishing holes, even water balloons—we had our ways to cool off and have some fun. “Air conditioning”—what’s that? #ThrowbackThursday #TBT

#DYK Original Medicare only covers you in the U.S. and its territories, except in rare cases? Most Medicare Advantage plans also don’t travel. Check your plan for details before you go, and consider buying travel health coverage if you need it. Learn more: https://go.cms.gov/2GdBIyy.

Is it really covered by Medicare? Or is it a scam? Stay one step ahead of Medicare scammers by joining AARP Programs on Facebook Live on July 16 & 18 at 7 p.m. EST for a two-part webinar. You’ll learn about the most common Medicare scams, so you can help keep yourself and your family members safe from them. https://www.facebook.com/events/501660520574459/
Just getting started with Medicare? Here are 5 things you should do in your first year. https://go.cms.gov/2XNMBgf
If you’re enrolled in the QMB Program, find out what to do if you get a bill for Medicare-covered items or services (including deductibles, coinsurance, and copayments). https://go.cms.gov/2NIBdm8

Need to know if Medicare covers a medical item or service? Then download our "What's Covered" app available for free on the App Store https://go.cms.gov/30lLbva and Google Play https://go.cms.gov/2YFO8qf.

#DYK there are 4 types of exercise you can do to be fit—strength, endurance, balance, and flexibility? Doing some of each regularly helps you to be healthier and makes exercise more interesting: https://go.cms.gov/2KYS1zn #WellnessWednesday

You can enroll for Medicare during the 3 months before you turn 65, the month you turn 65, and the 3 months after you turn 65. We call this your Initial Enrollment Period. If you don’t enroll when you’re first eligible, you may have to pay a Part B late enrollment penalty. https://go.cms.gov/2Jv6wf4

Practicing preventive care is a simple but effective way to manage your health. Preventive services can find health problems early, when treatment works best. Take advantage of preventive services covered by Medicare to maintain a healthy lifestyle. https://go.cms.gov/2XzV7UY
