SHIPs answer questions about Medicare and assist people in obtaining healthcare and prescription drug coverage, and programs designed to help people with limited incomes pay for their health care.
SHIPs also help people compare Medicare Supplemental (Medigap) insurance policies and explain how these and other supplemental insurance options -- such as insurance plans for retirees -- work with Medicare.

Traveling abroad this summer? Check your health coverage first. Our blog tells you several ways you can get coverage outside the U.S.: https://go.cms.gov/2Jl2INl

Track your monthly claims and costs faster by signing up to get your Medicare Summary Notices (MSNs) electronically. Why wait 3 months for a paper copy, when you can view your eMSNs every month? https://go.cms.gov/2Nbw7i3

Many people who have the HIV virus don’t know it. Many others aren’t sure how to prevent getting or transmitting HIV. Talk with your doctor and see if you should get screened. Medicare covers screenings once per year if you meet certain conditions: https://go.cms.gov/2L9tafr #NationalHIVTestingDay

Most people become eligible for Medicare when they turn 65. But #DYK you can enroll as early as 3 months before the month you turn 65 and up to 3 months after the month you turn 65? https://go.cms.gov/31OffkK

Enjoying time outdoors with the grandkids this summer? Avoid tick and mosquito bites by using bug spray, long sleeves, long pants, socks, and wide-brimmed hats. https://go.cms.gov/2yCA3Ry
Happy #FirstDayofSummer! If you’re enjoying time outside this summer, remember to pack your sunscreen, hat and water. More tips for a #HealthySummer: https://go.cms.gov/2FfglfL ☀⛱🌊

With a MyMedicare account, all your Medicare claims, card and other info is all in one secure place. https://go.cms.gov/2WMxBPh

Do you have clouded vision, double vision, see “ghost images,” or feel like there’s a film over your eyes? If so, you may have cataracts, and you’re not alone: more than half of us do by the time we turn 80. Learn more: https://go.cms.gov/2Xzkli5. #CataractAwarenessMonth
#MensHealthMonth is the perfect time to talk with your doctor about preventive screenings for prostate and colorectal cancer. https://go.cms.gov/2I88ySV #MensHealthWeek

Not sure if Medicare will cover your medical test or service? Our “What’s Covered” app delivers accurate cost and coverage information right to your mobile device. Download our FREE app from the App Store https://go.cms.gov/2Z6WB5h and Google Play https://go.cms.gov/2Z1Xe01.
With a MyMedicare account, you can access your Medicare information easily and securely. See claims statements faster, too. https://go.cms.gov/2IdWGxx

For more information, including how to report fraud, visit https://go.cms.gov/2MpjG1D.

Tomorrow is National #TakeBackDay—a perfect reminder to get rid of unused and unwanted prescription drugs. Find your nearest collection site: https://go.cms.gov/2vgajWH
A MyMedicare account puts your claims statements & Medicare card all in one secure, easy, organized place. https://www.mymedicare.gov/signup
April is Financial Literacy Month, a great time to get your personal finances on track. The Federal Trade Commission has a few tips to help you get started: https://go.cms.gov/2HmGdcM

There are many things you can do online with your #mySocialSecurity account, like sign up for Medicare, change your address, and check benefit information. Don’t have an account yet? It’s easy to create one: https://go.cms.gov/2Ppj3Tz #NationalSocialSecurityMonth

Social Security Administration
23 April 2019 at 04:15 ·
You can apply online for Medicare even if you are not ready to retire. Use our online application to sign up for Medicare. It takes less than 10 minutes. In most cases, once you submit your application electronically, you're done! There are no forms to sign and usually no required documentation. Social Security will process your application and contact you if we need more information. Otherwise, you'll receive your Medicare card in the mail. Learn more here: http://ow.ly/nBke50kf5nV

Spring is the perfect time to renew your commitment to better health and practice preventive care. Taking advantage of Medicare-covered preventive services is an important step in maintaining a healthy lifestyle. https://go.cms.gov/2PaXIxj

Gardening is work, but it's also a great workout! If you have a green thumb, here are some tips to help keep you safe and healthy while doing what you enjoy: https://go.cms.gov/2PcgC6N #NationalGardenMonth

With a MyMedicare account, you have no worries. All your Medicare claims, card and other information is all in one secure place. https://go.cms.gov/2OWmhhm

Medicare Fraud Alert: Scammers are offering supposedly “free” orthotic braces, and sending medical equipment you do not need while billing Medicare in your name. Protect yourself from fraud—If you receive a call from someone offering you a free brace that will be billed to Medicare, hang up immediately. For more information, including how to report these scams, visit https://go.cms.gov/2P14Ax4.

If you were the first of your siblings to have Medicare, help your brothers and sisters who are newbies. Share these 5 things to do in their first year of coverage: https://go.cms.gov/2YZ3I0H #NationalSiblingsDay
Turning 65 this year? Use our eligibility and premium calculator to get an estimate of when you’re eligible for Medicare and your premium amount. https://go.cms.gov/2UqJJcD

Why stand in line at your local Social Security Administration office if you don’t have to? Check out the many services you can access online, including enrolling in Medicare: https://go.cms.gov/2KlQdEW. #NationalSocialSecurityMonth
Want to know if your medical item or service covered by Medicare? Download our “What’s Covered” app to check: https://go.cms.gov/2FJ77c6

Do you know the minimum SPF needed to protect yourself from the sun’s harmful rays? Or how long you should wash your hands to kill germs? Take the CDC’s Health IQ test to find out: https://go.cms.gov/2FJRwJy. #NPHW
Wouldn’t you prefer to chase your grandkids than paperwork? Create a MyMedicare account and access your claims, Medicare card, and more in one secure place. https://www.mymedicare.gov/signup

For many of us, spring means allergy season. If you're one of the millions of people who have seasonal allergies, learn more about ways to reduce your exposure to allergy triggers: https://go.cms.gov/2Oy5i4F
Scammers don’t take holidays—including April Fools’ Day. Beware of any caller asking for your Medicare number or other information. More ways to prevent fraud: medicare.gov/fraud.
“All my Medicare info in one secure place. I created a MyMedicare account for fast access to claims and more.” https://www.mymedicare.gov/signup

New Medicare Part D opioid safety policies are an effort to reduce prescription opioid misuse while preserving medically necessary access to these medications. These new policies are not “one size fits all,” and don’t apply to Medicare residents of long-term care facilities, beneficiaries in hospice, palliative, or end-of-life care, and beneficiaries being treated for active cancer-related pain. https://go.cms.gov/2CKnGCS

Use our What’s Covered app for accurate, easy-to-understand Medicare coverage information right at the point of service, in any setting you use your smartphone, without using data or needing WiFi. https://go.cms.gov/2FBAcqd

Have Medicare but facing challenges with paying for health care? Learn about 4 Medicare Savings Programs that may be able to help you pay your Medicare premiums and other costs: https://go.cms.gov/2CN3foX.

9 out of 10 Americans most at risk for type 2 diabetes don’t know it. On #DiabetesAlertDay, take 60 seconds to find out if you’re one of them. Whatever your score, learn more about diabetes and how Medicare can help you stay healthier. https://go.cms.gov/2U7Fphh

Often, colorectal cancer shows no early signs or symptoms. The best way to prevent colorectal cancer is to get screened regularly starting at age 50. Medicare covers colorectal cancer screenings. Learn more: https://go.cms.gov/2OrdK5A.

#DYK kidney disease kills more people than breast or prostate cancer each year? #KidneyMonth is a good time to talk to your doctor about being tested for diabetes and high blood pressure, the main causes of kidney disease. https://go.cms.gov/2HEaaUn
We’ve just updated our What’s Covered mobile app (also available in Spanish). Download it from the App Store or Google Play by searching for “Que esta cubierto” or “Medicare”.
Stay healthy and live longer: start this spring by practicing preventive care. https://go.cms.gov/2HJcj1n #FirstDayofSpring 🌷
Your MyMedicare account lets you see your Medicare claims as soon as they’re processed. No need to wait 3 months for a paper copy to come in the mail. It’s easy to sign up: https://go.cms.gov/2HGrIPF

Be prepared for poison emergencies, like taking medication incorrectly. During Poison Prevention Week save and share the life-saving Poison Help Line number: 1-800-222-1222. #PPW2019 #MakeTheRightCall
Happy St. Patrick’s Day! 🍀
Want to know what’s going on with your Medicare? Get the latest official information from Medicare sent directly to your email inbox. https://go.cms.gov/2HcUnww

Safety checks & drug management programs are just some of the ways that Medicare, Medicare drug plans & pharmacies are working together to make sure you’re getting the pain relief treatment you need while keeping you safe. For more details on what this means for people who have existing opioid prescriptions or receive new ones, refer to the following fact sheet: https://go.cms.gov/2Hz2bIu

High blood pressure and diabetes are leading causes of kidney disease. So, if you have these conditions, manage them well by eating a healthy diet, getting regular exercise, and managing stress. https://go.cms.gov/2Ho2aXE #WorldKidneyDay

Missed your window to sign up for Part A and Part B during your Initial Enrollment Period? You may be able to sign up now during the General Enrollment Period, but don’t wait—it closes on March 31. Read more about who’s eligible to apply during the General Enrollment Period. https://go.cms.gov/2HsqO9o

Adults age 65+ need at least 7 hours of good sleep a night to function well, both mentally and physically. Are you coming up short? Here are some tips for a better night’s sleep: https://go.cms.gov/2HdaFFx #SleepAwarenessMonth

Whether at the doctor’s office, waiting room, hospital, or home, our “What’s Covered” app lets you easily see whether Medicare covers the service you need and related costs. https://go.cms.gov/2HrKLxh
Celebrate National Nutrition Month—create a healthy eating plan and find physical activities that fit your lifestyle. https://go.cms.gov/2NFIi39
Your MyMedicare account gives you fast, secure access to your Medicare card, claims information, and more. https://www.mymedicare.gov/signup

“What’s Covered” lets you easily see on your smartphone Medicare coverage information, how and when to get covered benefits, & basic cost information, all without needing to use data or WiFi. Download the app: https://go.cms.gov/2H0fRMR

You may want to sign up for Medicare Part A and/or Part B during the General Enrollment Period (January 1–March 31 each year) if you didn’t enroll during your initial enrollment period, and if you aren’t eligible for a Special Enrollment Period. Learn more: https://go.cms.gov/2GLfdTz

With Medicare’s Hospital Compare Tool, see updated star ratings and compare a hospital’s performance against national averages for many procedures and treatments, patient experiences, complications, and more. Try it here: https://go.cms.gov/2NAndqX
#HeartMonth Reminder: Keep your ❤ healthy with Medicare-covered cardiovascular disease screenings. https://go.cms.gov/2GXMp9H
Our “What’s Covered” app lets you easily use your smartphone to see Medicare coverage information, how and when to get covered benefits & basic cost information. https://go.cms.gov/2GLFwc1

It’s National #HeartMonth, a great time to pay more attention to your heart’s health. Medicare can help, starting with a yearly wellness visit that includes a blood pressure check to see if your heart is beating within the normal range. https://go.cms.gov/2ViO5yg
While new Medicare cards include more secure numbers, you should continue to guard your new Medicare card to prevent healthcare fraud. go.medicare.gov/newcard

Does Medicare seem like alphabet soup? Get to know your Medicare ABCD’s, starting with Part A. Medicare Part A (Hospital Insurance) covers inpatient hospital stays, care in a skilled nursing facility, hospice care, and some home health care. https://go.cms.gov/2DSG4cw
It’s easy to get your Medicare Summary Notice to show up in your email inbox instead of your mailbox: https://go.cms.gov/2Gz7fNe

Although love songs say otherwise, a 💔 can’t kill you—but heart disease can. Check out our blog about cardiovascular disease screenings —they’re covered by Medicare. https://go.cms.gov/2MZXzvx

During a Special Enrollment Period, you can make changes to your Medicare Advantage and Medicare prescription drug coverage when certain events happen in your life, like if you move or lose other insurance coverage. Find more information here: https://go.cms.gov/2Bv49W9

If you’re in a Medicare Advantage Plan (like an HMO or PPO) or a Medicare Prescription Drug Plan, keep using that Plan ID card whenever you need care or prescriptions. However, you should carry your new Medicare card too — you may be asked to show it. go.medicare.gov/newcard

Is your medical item or service covered by Medicare? Now there’s a quick way to check! Download our “What’s Covered” app: https://go.cms.gov/2GaJP0r

Protect your new Medicare card—only give your new Medicare Number to doctors, pharmacists, other health care providers, your insurer, or people you trust to work with Medicare on your behalf. Medicare will never call you uninvited to ask for your Medicare Number or other personal information. Medicare.gov/fraud

New Medicare card mailing is complete. If you didn't get your new card, sign in to your MyMedicare.gov account to get your new Medicare Number or print your card. Don’t have a MyMedicare.gov account? Create one easily at https://www.mymedicare.gov/.

Need to know if Medicare covers your medical test or service? Wherever you are—in the doctor’s office, the hospital, or on the go— you can use our “What’s Covered” app on your mobile device to get the answers you need quickly. https://go.cms.gov/2MDuqG4 #eMedicare #WhatsCoveredApp

Now that you have your new Medicare card, destroy your old Medicare card. Didn’t get your new Medicare card? Create a MyMedicare.gov account (or log in) to see your new Medicare Number or print your new card. https://www.mymedicare.gov/ #NewMedicareCard

When you're first eligible for Medicare, you have a 7-month Initial Enrollment Period to sign up for Part A and/or Part B. But, if you missed your chance to sign up, you may be able to enroll now during the General Enrollment Period. General Enrollment ends on March 31. Learn more: https://go.cms.gov/2HBX5wH.

Not sure if Medicare will cover your medical test or service? Use Medicare’s free “What’s Covered” app to get accurate cost and coverage information right on your mobile device. Download our FREE app today! https://go.cms.gov/2SaHlof #eMedicare #WhatsCoveredApp

Didn’t get your new Medicare card in the mail? Sign into your MyMedicare.gov account to view your number or print your new card. Remember – you can use your current Medicare card to get health care services until Jan. 1, 2020.
January is glaucoma awareness month, a perfect time to check and see if you’re at high risk for glaucoma. Medicare covers a glaucoma test once every 12 months if you are. https://go.cms.gov/2RydAOF
#DYK that ⅓ of resolutions don’t last longer than a month? Here are some tips to keep you motivated and committed to your healthy living goals: https://go.cms.gov/2Mg3MTM

New Medicare card mailing is now complete. Didn’t get your new Medicare card in the mail? You can sign in to your MyMedicare.gov account to get your new Medicare Number or print your card. Don’t have a MyMedicare.gov account? Create one today at https://www.mymedicare.gov/.

"Everybody can be great...because anybody can serve.” -Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.
Find out how you can serve on MLK Day and beyond: https://go.cms.gov/2Dib6LP #MLKDay

Scam artists may try to get personal information (like your current Medicare Number) by contacting you about your new Medicare card. Hang up on fraudsters and report suspected fraud to us at 1-800-MEDICARE. Medicare.gov/newcard

We’ve finished mailing new Medicare cards. If you didn't get your new card, sign in to your MyMedicare.gov account to get your new Medicare number or print your official card. Don’t have a MyMedicare.gov account? Create one today at https://www.mymedicare.gov/.

Every year, more than 12,000 women in the U.S. are diagnosed with cervical cancer, but with regular screening tests, cervical cancer is the easiest female cancer to prevent. Medicare covers screenings: https://go.cms.gov/2soGEt9. #CervicalCancerAwarenessMonth
It’s not too late to get your flu shot. Make an appointment now—a flu shot is your best protection from influenza, and it’s covered by Medicare. https://go.cms.gov/2CoHwST #FightFlu
Get wise to scams relating to the new Medicare card. Medicare will never call you unrequested and ask for personal information about your new Medicare card. Learn more at Medicare.gov/newcard

We’ve just made it easier for you to estimate and compare out-of-pocket costs side-by-side for different Medicare coverage combinations. Read how the coverage choices you make can affect your costs: https://go.cms.gov/2R7l9M4
Do you have Medicare along with other health insurance? If so, you may be wondering “who pays first?” See how Medicare coordinates with your other coverage: https://go.cms.gov/2St1TW8.
Turning 65 in 2019? Follow these 6 steps to gather information so you can make informed decisions about your Medicare: https://go.cms.gov/2BZU03w

Missed your Initial Enrollment Period for Medicare? You may be able to sign up for Medicare Part A and Medicare Part B during the General Enrollment Period, which runs from January 1 – March 31. https://go.cms.gov/2SwnWev
If you resolved to live a little healthier in 2019, Medicare can help. Take advantage of your free preventive benefits including your yearly wellness visit. https://go.cms.gov/2RrHJyo

Are you due for a Tdap booster shot to prevent tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis (also called whooping cough)? Contact your Medicare prescription drug plan for more information about your specific coverage. https://go.cms.gov/2Tj1xkK
Out with the old, in with the new...Medicare card that is! Once you receive your new Medicare card in the mail, destroy your old card and begin using the new card. Medicare.gov/newcard

Medicare is here to help you make 2019 a year of living healthier. Start by logging into your MyMedicare.gov account. You can track your preventive services and get a 2-year calendar of the Medicare-covered tests and screenings for which you’re eligible.
2019 will be here soon! Wishing everyone a safe and happy New Year!

Are you planning to switch from a Marketplace plan when you become eligible for Medicare? To avoid a gap in coverage, don’t end your Marketplace plan before your Medicare coverage begins. Learn more about canceling your Marketplace plan at https://go.cms.gov/2SdJ09l.
10 things to know about your new Medicare card: go.medicare.gov/newcard
New to Medicare? See how Medicare coverage combinations may impact your costs: Medicare.gov/oopc.
Sending warm wishes for a happy holiday season!
Brighten the holidays by making your health a priority. Here are 12 ways to keep you and your loved ones safe and healthy—and ready to enjoy the holidays. https://go.cms.gov/2Gz39VZ.
Medicare is not affected by the partial government shutdown.
Ready for winter weather? The CDC has tips for making sure you’re prepared to stay safe and healthy this winter. #FirstDayofWinter https://go.cms.gov/2UQrGJn
Did you get your new Medicare card in the mail? If so, make sure to destroy your old card to protect yourself from identity theft. https://go.cms.gov/2QyKmii

Reviewing your Medicare Summary Notices (MSNs) helps us cut down on fraud. Always check the service dates and charges for accuracy. If you spot any errors, report them to us at 1-800-MEDICARE. Learn more: https://go.cms.gov/2QxvpwO

Planning to travel abroad this winter? In general, Medicare won’t pay for health care services or supplies you get when you travel outside the U.S., but that doesn’t mean you have to travel abroad without coverage. Learn more: https://go.cms.gov/2Lq64PS.
Over 65 and still working? Learn more about whether you should get Part A and Part B and what happens when your employment or coverage ends: https://go.cms.gov/2SNEr5E.

#DYK in order to have your Medicare Prescription Drug Plan premium deducted automatically from your monthly Social Security payment, you need to contact your Medicare Part D drug plan? It takes about 3 months for your deductions to start. For more information, visit https://go.cms.gov/2QGUjtg.
We can all help reduce Medicare fraud by keeping a close watch on who we give our Medicare Number to, and regularly checking Medicare Summary Notices for errors. https://go.cms.gov/2rqcOnA

Do you or someone you know need information on long-term care (LTC)? You can use the LTC PathFinder to find local services, see what costs are paid for by Medicare, and locate helpful resources. http://longtermcare.gov/
There’s no need for you to activate or register your new Medicare card or Medicare Number. Once you get your new Medicare card in the mail, you’re all set to use it right away. Medicare.gov/newcard

Whether or not you changed plans during Open Enrollment, no need to wait to schedule your preventive and screening services. https://go.cms.gov/2Utu8oW

Today is the LAST day to compare your Medicare plan choices and make changes for 2019. Review your coverage options here: https://go.cms.gov/2QzhPZ3. #MedicareOE
Today we remember the lives that were lost on December 7, 1941 — "A date which will live in infamy." #PearlHarborRemembranceDay

Only 2 days left in Medicare Open Enrollment. Take a minute to review your health care coverage and to make sure your plan works for you. If you’re thinking about making any changes, now’s the time to act. https://go.cms.gov/2UaYU5F #MedicareOE

Looking for unbiased help finding coverage that best fits your health needs and budget? Make an appointment at your nearest State Health Insurance Assistance Program (SHIP) office. They know the ins and outs of comparing Medicare plans. Find your nearest SHIP at shiptacenter.org. #MedicareOE

You already know you have choices in how you get your Medicare hospital, medical, and prescription drug coverage, but did you know you can get help online? Answer 5 simple questions about your health care needs and we’ll give you personalized Medicare coverage recommendations. https://go.cms.gov/2E9ssfj #MedicareOE

Based on your basic health status and ZIP code, the Out-of-Pocket Cost Estimator can help you estimate your annual out-of-pocket spending for Original Medicare vs. Medicare Advantage, including plan deductibles and prescription drug copayments. https://go.cms.gov/2RwpvZx #MedicareOE

Have you compared plans yet? You might be able to lower some costs or find a plan that better suits your needs. Many people do. Even if you like your current plan, check to see if the costs or coverage are changing. https://go.cms.gov/2BNN2zn #MedicareOE

Feel confident that the choices you make for 2019 coverage are right for you. Not sure where to begin? These 5 questions are a good starting point to help you find the coverage that fits your needs and budget best. https://go.cms.gov/2DKJuPS
Use the Plan Finder to see a list of plans tailored to you. We’ve added a simplified log in option through your MyMedicare.gov account, for a more personalized experience. https://go.cms.gov/2Ky9oI4

Don’t wait—only 1 week left to compare your Medicare Advantage (Part C) and prescription drug (Part D) plan coverage choices for 2019. https://go.cms.gov/2BxSA16 #MedicareOE

There are many difficult decisions to make with a terminal illness, like whether hospice is right for you or your loved one. If you need to find hospices that serve your area, visit Medicare.gov/hospicecompare/ to compare them based on the quality of care they give. https://go.cms.gov/2Qio5o4

“Help with Your Medicare Choices” uses 5 simple questions to help you understand what to consider when thinking about Medicare coverage. During Open Enrollment, visit https://go.cms.gov/2KzAwX8 for personalized coverage recommendations.

Help protect your identity. Once you get your new Medicare card by mail, destroy your old card right away. And be wary of people asking for your Medicare Number, personal information, or to pay a fee for your new card. Medicare.gov/newcard. https://go.cms.gov/2nTvwCo

During Open Enrollment, be skeptical of special discounts or freebies that sound too good to be true. https://go.cms.gov/2SbNDQU #MedicareOE

#CyberMonday isn’t just for finding holiday gift deals online. It’s also a great time to shop for your 2019 Medicare coverage. Use the Plan Finder to shop for Part C and Part D plans by price, quality, and coverage: https://go.cms.gov/2QkoqXc.

Would you like for a family member or caregiver to be able to call Medicare on your behalf? Fill out and submit form CMS-10106 online using your MyMedicare.gov account, or download it here to mail a hard copy to us: https://go.cms.gov/2FFq816. #NationalFamilyCaregiversMonth

Some people like to compare plans online using the Plan Finder, some prefer to talk it over at 1-800-MEDICARE, and some would rather meet face-to-face with a local SHIP counselor. Whatever your preference, find your best plan your best way. https://go.cms.gov/2AaJxlO
Have questions about prescription drug coverage, or wondering how Medicare Advantage Plans are different from Original Medicare? It’s all here: https://www.medicare.gov/medicare-and-you

Comparing plans isn’t just about price. Quality and performance matter, too. Medicare’s Plan Finder tool shows you the star ratings of health and prescription drug plans on a scale of one star (poor) to five stars (excellent) to help you make your best choice for 2019. https://go.cms.gov/2AaJxlO
Not sure if Original Medicare or Medicare Advantage is right for you? Answer 5 quick questions to see which coverage fits your needs. https://www.medicare.gov/medicarecoverageoptions/
Compare your current plan to all of your options for 2019; you may find you are able to pay less, get extra benefits, or both. https://go.cms.gov/2AaJxlO

Are your lungs trying to tell you something? If you're struggling for air, listen to your lungs—it could be COPD. With early diagnosis and treatment, COPD can be managed so you can breathe better. https://go.cms.gov/2AMh6ee
Medicare won’t call you uninvited and ask for personal or private information for you to get your new Medicare Number or card. Hang up on scammers! Medicare.gov/newcard

We’ve created an easy way for you to estimate and compare out-of-pocket costs side-by-side for various Medicare coverage combinations. Read more about how the coverage choices you make can affect your costs: https://go.cms.gov/2PHoLTB.

Once you get your new Medicare card in the mail, you can use it right away. Your doctors, other health care providers and facilities know it’s coming, so carry it with you when you need care. Your Medicare coverage and benefits will stay the same. Medicare.gov/newcard

It’s Week 3 of Open Enrollment—a good time to see if your prescription drugs are on your drug plan’s formulary (the list of covered generic and brand name drugs and costs). Formularies change, so be sure to check your plan’s formulary, even if you don't expect to change drug plans for 2019. https://go.cms.gov/2AaJxlO

Do you travel a lot, or live in more than one state during the year? If so, keep those factors in mind when you compare your plan choices for 2019. The Medicare Coverage Options tool can help you figure out if getting Original Medicare, a Medicare Advantage plan, or adding a Medigap policy may be right for you: https://go.cms.gov/2OwZN9v.
Thanks, Ron D., for sharing your #ThursdayThoughts with us about the Medicare Plan Finder! https://go.cms.gov/2AaJxlO

Don’t trick yourself out of finding lower costs, extra benefits, or both. Review your Medicare coverage options for 2019, and get personalized recommendations for the type of Medicare coverage that might work best for you. https://go.cms.gov/2OwZN9v #Halloween

Many people turn to the Plan Finder to help them find and compare health and drug plans available in their area, especially during Open Enrollment. Whether you have questions for yourself, or you’re acting as a caregiver, State Health Insurance Assistance Programs (SHIPs) offer local, personalized counseling and assistance to people with Medicare and their families. Find a list of contacts in your state: https://go.cms.gov/2P4MdtM.

The Medicare Plan Finder’s 2019 health & drug plan cost info will help make reviewing your options during Open Enrollment as easy as possible. Do a general search by entering your ZIP code. For a more personalized experience, log in using your MyMedicare account. Medicare.gov/find-a-plan

Make World Osteoporosis Day a day you show your bones some ❤. Talk to your doctor about how to keep your bones healthy and strong. With Medicare Part B, you’re covered for a bone mass measurement that can help to see if you’re at risk for broken bones. https://go.cms.gov/2yPxRD5

Getting a mammogram is the best way to find breast cancer early. All women between the ages of 50–74 should have a mammogram every 2 years—and Medicare covers mammograms at no cost. https://go.cms.gov/2yEolCO #NationalMammographyDay

Today, Seema Verma, Administrator of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, visited SpiriTrust Lutheran to discuss important updates about Medicare Open Enrollment and the tools we’ve added and updated this year to help seniors make the coverage choice that is right for them. https://www.medicare.gov/find-a-plan/questions/home.aspx

Have you had the same Medicare plan for a while? Medicare Open Enrollment is your chance to see what’s new, and see if you can find a plan that has lower premiums and extra benefits. https://go.cms.gov/2AaJxlO
Keep your Medicare card out of the hands of fraudsters. As soon as your new card arrives, destroy your old Medicare card. Learn more at Medicare.gov/newcard.

Open Enrollment is your time to take stock of how your life and health have changed this year, and how your current plan stacks up against all your options for 2019. Find what’s best for you: https://go.cms.gov/2AaJxlO

Medicare Open Enrollment is officially open! Knowing your coverage choices makes it easier to decide how you want to get your Medicare coverage. By answering 5 simple questions about your health care needs and preferences, you can get personalized recommendations for the type of Medicare coverage that might work best for you. Learn more: https://go.cms.gov/2RQ3jKc

Medicare Open Enrollment starts tomorrow! It’s your opportunity to compare 2019 plans and choose what’s best for you. Take a quick look at your coverage choices on pages 5 and 6 of your 2019 “Medicare & You” handbook to see the “big picture”: https://go.cms.gov/2C6DWOU

To check when card mailing begins in your state and to see what your new card will look like, visit Medicare.gov/newcard. If you’re still waiting for your card to arrive, don’t worry—you can still use your old card until your new card arrives by mail.

Know the do’s and don’ts of staying safe during storm power outages. Three tips to stay safe:
• Keep freezers/refrigerators closed.
• Turn off/disconnect appliances/electronics to avoid power surge damage.
• Have alternate plans for refrigerating medicines or using power-dependent medical devices.
Get more power outage tips: https://www.ready.gov/power-outages

Dads pride themselves on their puns and jokes. Seems like the more they can make your eyes roll, the happier they are. One thing that’s no joke—every dad’s health. June is #MensHealthMonth, make sure the dads you know with Medicare get a Yearly Wellness Visit: https://go.cms.gov/2K12j4Q Happy Father's Day!
Hey fellas, many health conditions can be prevented or detected early with regular health screenings. Make prevention a priority during #MensHealthWeek https://go.cms.gov/2l4bT9b #MensHealthMonth

Have you heard the latest? Everyone with Medicare is getting a new Medicare card with a unique Medicare Number, instead of your Social Security Number. https://go.cms.gov/2JMopIc
YOUTUBE.COM
New Medicare Cards are Arriving in Millions of Mailboxes
Do you know what the colors red, white, and blue represent on the American flag? #FlagDay Facts: https://go.cms.gov/2l54beL

Did you know your new Medicare Number is a unique combination of numbers and letters? The letters S, L, O, I, B, and Z are never used. For more information about the new Medicare cards, visit Medicare.gov/newcard

Do you have clouded vision, double vision, see ghost images, or have a sense of a “film” over your eyes? You might have cataracts—and you’re not alone—by age 80, more than half of us do. Medicare may cover your cataracts surgery: https://go.cms.gov/2l0teQh

Your new Medicare card hasn’t arrived yet? Don’t worry—you can still use your old Medicare card until you get the new one by mail. Visit Medicare.gov/newcard to check the status of your new card and see what it will look like.

As we age, our risk for various diseases rises. Guys: let Men’s Health Month be your reminder not to put off screenings. Learn more about the screenings Medicare covers and how often you should take advantage of them: https://go.cms.gov/2kNcHiF

Don’t get scammed! Medicare will NEVER call you uninvited and ask for personal information to get your new Medicare Number. Hang up if someone asks for your information, for money, or threatens to cancel your health benefits. For more information about the new Medicare card and how to avoid scam artists, visit Medicare.gov/newcard.

On this day in 1933, the first drive-in movie theater opened in Camden, NJ. Admission: A quarter per car to see the British comedy, Wives Beware. Share your first drive-in movie memory. #DriveInMovieDay #WaybackWednesday

Did you know you can get the Medicare & You Handbook and many other Medicare publications and forms electronically? Today is World Environment Day. Open a MyMedicare.gov account—it’s easy, secure and 🌏 friendly.

SHIP National Technical Assistance Center
5 June 2018 at 08:00 ·
If you're eligible for #Medicare when you turn 65, you have a 7-month Initial Enrollment Period to sign up for Part A and/or Part B. (3 months before you turn 65, the month you turn 65, and ending 3 months after you turn 65.) Your local #SHIP program can help you choose the best coverage.

Wondering when you’ll get your new Medicare card? Mailing takes time. Your card may arrive at a different time than your friend’s or neighbor’s. Get updates when mailings will start in your state— visit Medicare.gov/newcard and sign up for email.

It’s National Cancer Survivors Day—celebrate the survivors in your life and encourage all those you love to get screened. More cancers are survivable today, and regular screenings can help detect cancer early, when it is most treatable. Medicare covers many cancer screenings: https://go.cms.gov/2kyHGid

Did you know we’re mailing new Medicare cards with a unique new Medicare Number, instead of your Social Security Number, to everyone with Medicare? Your Medicare benefits and coverage will stay the same—only the cards will change. Learn more at Medicare.gov/newcard.

How are you getting your exercise in today? Why not head outdoors and #FindYourTrail! You can leave the trail better than you found it by picking up trash or volunteering for a trail work project. #NationalTrailsDay

National Donut Day is a good time to learn how the Medicare prescription drug coverage gap, otherwise known as the “donut hole,” has been gradually closing for several years. By 2020, you’ll pay no more than 25% for covered brand-name and generic drugs: https://go.cms.gov/2kDQ3ZQ

If someone calls and says you need to give them your personal information or money to get your new Medicare card, hang up! It’s a scam. Medicare will never call uninvited and ask for personal information or money for you to get your new Medicare card. Medicare.gov/newcard

Smoking tobacco can cause many health problems, including heart disease, respiratory diseases, and lung cancer (the leading cause of cancer death in the U.S.) Quitting can reduce your risk of getting these diseases. Quit smoking today—Medicare is here to help. https://go.cms.gov/2L70Mal #WNTD2018

#DYK adults over 65 should get about 2.5 hours of moderate physical activity per week? That's 30 minutes, 5 days a week. Learn more and find tips that will get you moving: https://go.cms.gov/2siWrKe #NSHFD

If you already knew all 3 of these statements are true, we salute your Memorial Day knowledge. Learn more about the history of Memorial Day here: https://go.cms.gov/2s0JWlv
[Animation of a true/false quiz: Used to be known as Decoration Day = True. Honors those who died while serving in the U.S. military = True. Became a national holiday in 1971 = True. | Memorial Day: May 28]

You’re never too old (or too young) to enrich your life and your community. Snap a selfie, or have someone take your picture participating in activities that improve your mental and physical well-being. Then, post your image to your timeline using the hashtag #OAM18.

We’re mailing new Medicare cards to everyone with Medicare. Your new Medicare card no longer uses your Social Security Number, but has a Medicare Number that’s unique to you. These new cards will better safeguard your important health information. https://youtu.be/rAK9d8SlCII
YOUTUBE.COM
New Medicare Cards are Arriving in Millions of Mailboxes

If you have high blood pressure, you can help control it with medicine and lifestyle changes, like lowering your salt intake and exercising regularly. May is National High Blood Pressure Education Month. Find out more about how to fight high blood pressure and get checked today. https://go.cms.gov/2kds1F2

Only give your new Medicare Number to people you trust to work with Medicare on your behalf, like doctors, pharmacists, other health care providers, and your insurers. For more information on the new Medicare cards, visit Medicare.gov/newcard

Hepatitis is an inflammation of the liver caused by a virus. It’s also contagious. Fortunately, Medicare can help keep you protected from the most common types of viral hepatitis strains—Hepatitis A, B and C. Read our blog for more information:
https://go.cms.gov/2s20tpz
Once your new Medicare card arrives by mail, destroy your old card to prevent identity theft, and start using your new one right away. https://go.cms.gov/2rZhpNj

Every 40 seconds, stroke strikes another victim. Lower your risk by managing your blood pressure and taking advantage of Medicare-covered cardiovascular disease screenings that can help detect conditions that may lead to a stroke. https://go.cms.gov/2rZ6JyY

Medicare is mailing new Medicare cards to all people with Medicare. Your new Medicare card will have a new Medicare Number that’s unique to you, instead of your Social Security Number. Visit Medicare.gov/newcard to see when cards are being mailed to your state.
Today we honor the men and women who bravely serve, or have served, in all branches of the U.S. military. Thank you for your service and sacrifice.

What should women in their 50s do to be their healthiest now and for the years to come? Get 30 minutes of exercise daily, eat a healthy diet, and get 7-8 hours of sleep per night. See all the healthy steps during National Women’s Health Week: https://go.cms.gov/2GdtdAO #NWHW

According to the CDC, regular physical activity can decrease arthritis pain and improve function by about 40%. Walking, swimming, and biking are all great ways to get active during Arthritis Awareness Month. https://go.cms.gov/2KhVM28
Fraudsters are smart, but you’re smarter. Protect yourself—destroy your old Medicare card as soon as your new card arrives in the mail. Medicare.gov/newcard.

Healthy looks good at every age! You’re never too young or too old to take steps to be as healthy as possible. If you’re just aging into Medicare, check out these healthy tips for women in their 60s: https://go.cms.gov/2KhVBnF #NWHW

It’s National Women’s Health Week—time to focus on ways to stay your healthiest. In your 70s? You won’t have the same health needs that you did 10 or even 5 years ago. Get the list of recommended checkups, screenings, and vaccinations: https://go.cms.gov/2KZkZQ8 #NWHW

What do women in their 20s and 80s have in common? Like all other age groups, they should be getting 30 minutes of physical activity every day. During Women’s Health Week, see the other healthy steps recommended for your age: https://go.cms.gov/2wva0Lm #NWHW
Moms: For all you do and all you are—thank you! Happy Mother’s Day.

Don’t get scammed! If someone calls asking for your new Medicare card Number, hang up! Medicare will never call you unrequested and ask for personal information for you to get your new card. Visit Medicare.gov/newcard for more information.

Sitting around in our rocking chairs all day? Not so much. Today’s older Americans are engaged in work, volunteer activities, and much, much more. And Medicare is here to help them stay healthy, so they can stay engaged at every age. https://go.cms.gov/2FPxUQR

National Osteoporosis Awareness and Prevention Month is a good time to learn what to do to help prevent osteoporosis. Help keep your bones strong by eating a calcium-rich diet, doing more weight-bearing exercises, and getting a bone mass measurement (bone density). 💪 https://go.cms.gov/2rrBP11

Looking for information about long-term care for yourself or someone you know? Use the LTC PathFinder to find local services, see what costs are paid for by Medicare, and find helpful resources. https://go.cms.gov/2KFcY2K
To find out when your new Medicare card will get to you and to see what it will look like, visit Medicare.gov/newcard. Remember, you can still use your old Medicare card until your new card arrives.

Since 1997, more than 46,000 volunteers have helped the Senior Medicare Patrol program. Interested in the SMP program and want to learn how to help prevent and detect health care fraud? Visit https://go.cms.gov/2vYylJ2

Watch out for scams relating to the new Medicare cards. We’ll never call you unrequested and ask you to give us personal or private information to get your new Medicare card. Learn more at Medicare.gov/NewCard
May the force of good health be with you on Star Wars Day and every day. Medicare preventive benefits you should use, your healthiest you will stay: https://go.cms.gov/2JGJ50F

New Medicare card mailing has started in certain states and will continue over the next few months nationwide. Your new card includes a new number, unique to you, instead of your Social Security Number. While the card looks different — your Medicare benefits and coverage will stay the same. https://go.cms.gov/2Kx2HFX

Practicing preventive care is a simple way to manage your health. Preventive services can find health problems early, when treatment works best. Taking advantage of these services is a crucial step in maintaining a healthy lifestyle. https://go.cms.gov/2r9H9WY

You count on Medicare to help you protect your health. We’re helping to protect your identity, too—with a new Medicare card that no longer has your Social Security Number on it. Learn more at Medicare.gov/NewCard
Tomorrow is National #TakeBackDay, a perfect time for you to get rid of unused and unwanted prescription drugs. Find your nearest collection site: https://takebackday.dea.gov/

This month Social Security Administration is alerting many people with Medicare that they may be eligible for Medicare Savings Programs (MSPs). MSPs make Medicare more affordable for 9 million Americans. More info: https://go.cms.gov/2Fe2yDb

Why stand in line at your local Social Security office if you don’t have to? Social Security Administration lets you access many services online, like enrolling in Medicare and getting a replacement Medicare card: https://www.ssa.gov/onlineservices/ #NSSM18

Be wary of anyone who contacts you about your #NewMedicareCard. We’ll never ask for personal or private information for you to get your new Medicare Number or card. Medicare.gov/NewCard

Did you know that 36% of all volunteers in America are 55 and older? They’re not just volunteering because they have more free time; they enjoy helping others and like having a greater sense of purpose. Do you volunteer?

Your physical health is important. During Financial Literacy Month, don’t forget to focus on your fiscal health, too. The Federal Trade Commission offers a treasure trove of free consumer information on topics like managing debt to saving more to knowing your consumer rights. https://go.cms.gov/2HmGdcM

Show the 🌏 earth a little ❤ today—go paperless! Skip the mail—sign up to get your “Medicare & You” Handbook and Medicare Summary Notices electronically. It’s easy, secure, and a great way to celebrate Earth Day. http://blog.medicare.gov/2018/04/22/earth-day-2/
Want to know when your new Medicare card will mail? Visit Medicare.gov/NewCard and sign up for email to get updates on when mailings start in your state.

Scam artists may try to get personal information (like your current Medicare Number) by calling or emailing you about your new Medicare card. If someone asks you for your information, for money, or if they threaten to cancel your health benefits if you don’t share your personal information, hang up and call us at 1-800-MEDICARE. Medicare.gov/newcard
Spring—the perfect time to commit to better health and practice preventive care. Take advantage of Medicare-covered preventive services to maintain a healthy lifestyle. https://go.cms.gov/2JQgPJJ
Gardening is work, but it's also a great workout! If you have a green thumb, here are some tips to help keep you safe and healthy while doing what you enjoy: https://go.cms.gov/2Ho8Oh3
Don’t forget! Submit your 2017 tax return by tomorrow, April 17 to avoid penalties and interest. https://www.irs.gov/

Coming soon: Your new Medicare Card. Your new card will have a new Medicare Number unique to you, instead of your Social Security Number. If you moved recently and need to update your official mailing address, visit: http://ssa.gov/myaccount

With your “my Social Security” account, you can sign up for Medicare, request a replacement Medicare card, change your address, check benefit information, and more. Don’t yet have an account? It’s easy to create one at https://www.ssa.gov/myaccount/ #NSSM18
For #ThrowbackThursday, share this quote if you think Elvis had the right idea!

If someone calls you unexpectedly saying they “work with” or represent Medicare and need your card number or other personal information, hang up! Medicare will only call you if you’ve called and left a message or if a representative said that someone will call you back. Protect yourself from scams: https://medicare.gov/fraud.

If you were the first of your siblings to have Medicare, help your brothers and sisters who are newbies. Share these 5 things to do in their first year of coverage: https://go.cms.gov/2JtAM9c #NationalSiblingsDay
What a great way to celebrate National Library Week. From education to job resources to lifelong learning, your library provides access to valuable programming and services – no matter your age!

Take time during National Public Health Week to thank those who work every day to make us all healthier. Do your part to stay healthy by using your Medicare preventive benefits. https://go.cms.gov/2Gw290F #NPHW
Turning 65 this year? Use our eligibility and premium calculator to estimate when you’re eligible for Medicare and your premium amount. https://go.cms.gov/2uHPo1q

Your new Medicare card will automatically come to you. You don’t need to do anything as long as your address is up-to-date. If you need to update your address, log in to your my Social Security account or visit your local Social Security Administration office. https://www.ssa.gov/myaccount/
For many of us, spring means allergy season. If you have seasonal allergies, learn how to reduce your exposure to allergy triggers: https://medlineplus.gov/hayfever.html

National Public Health Week is a great time to learn about the many preventive screenings and services Medicare covers to help you stay your healthy best. See the complete list at https://go.cms.gov/2Jf36fl

New Medicare cards have started to mail. Your new Medicare card will include a new number unique to you, instead of your current Social Security-based number to help protect you from fraud. Cards are mailing now to people new to Medicare. If you want to know when new cards start mailing to your area, visit Medicare.gov/NewCard, and sign up to get email alerts from Medicare. Check out our latest blog for more information about new cards with new Medicare Numbers. https://go.cms.gov/2Guuc4A

Scammers don’t take holidays—including April Fools’ Day. Don’t give out your Medicare card number or other personal information to someone unless you’ve given them permission in advance. More ways to prevent fraud: medicare.gov/fraud
National Nutrition Month may be coming to an end, but you can eat healthy all year long by adding these 8 healthy eating goals to your diet. https://go.cms.gov/2G8cALH

Medicare will automatically mail your new Medicare card to the address you have on file with Social Security Administration. There’s nothing you need to do! If you moved recently and need to update your official mailing address, visit: https://www.ssa.gov/myaccount/ #NewMedicareCard

The General Enrollment Period to sign up for Medicare is Jan 1 - March 31 for coverage starting July 1. Read more about the specific conditions you must meet to apply during the General Enrollment Period: https://www.medicare.gov/sign-up-change-plans/get-parts-a-and-b/when-sign-up-parts-a-and-b/when-sign-up-parts-a-and-b.html

Stick to your healthy living goals by becoming more physically active while having fun. Here are some tips to start being more active today: https://go.cms.gov/2I4Vrij

9 out of 10 Americans most at risk for type 2 diabetes don’t know it. On Diabetes Alert Day, take 60 seconds to find out if you’re one of them. Whatever your score, learn more about diabetes and how Medicare can help you stay healthier. https://go.cms.gov/2ujXsFg

Start the spring season off on the right foot—step up your walking and other healthy exercise. Have diabetes? Medicare covers a foot exam and foot care to help keep you going strong: https://go.cms.gov/2G95S8h
March is National Kidney Month, so ❤ your kidneys and get smart about kidney disease and kidney health. http://go.cms.gov/2FSmVXW

Are you getting enough sleep? Adults age 65+ need at least 7 hours of good sleep at night to function well—mentally and physically—yet many of us are coming up short. Here are some tips for a better night’s sleep:
http://go.cms.gov/2HIHYwz
Most people become eligible for Medicare when they turn 65. But #DYK you can enroll as early as three months before your 65th birthday and up to three months after? http://go.cms.gov/2GJgmrQ

Because there are often no signs or symptoms of colorectal cancer, the best way to prevent colorectal cancer is to get screened regularly, starting at age 50. Medicare covers colorectal cancer screenings. Learn more: http://go.cms.gov/2GFbS5n

Missed your Initial Enrollment Period? You may still be able to sign up for Part A and/or Part B if you act soon. The General Enrollment Period runs from January 1 to March 31, for coverage starting July 1. http://go.cms.gov/2p0TQ6b

Celebrate National Nutrition Month by making good food choices and adding regular exercise to your lifestyle. Small changes can bring good rewards. Read more in our latest blog: http://go.cms.gov/2Dm8wB3

Alfredo Morabia
8 April at 20:03 ·
The May AJPH features occupational health and safety, an issue that is both timely and topical in the middle of the dreadful pandemic that is affecting the planet, but in particular workers, whose mission is to keep the economy and public health functioning.
In the podcast (https://am.ajph.link/POD_May2020) my guests are David Michaels (Former OSHA Assistant-Secretary), Peg Seminario (AFL-CIO) and John Howard (NIOSH DIrector). Their message is: Congress needs to quickly require OSHA to pass an infectious disease standard to protect health care and other workers exposed to Covid-19. A draft of the standard exists.
The issue is here: https://am.ajph.link/AJPH_current

APHA's Center for Climate, Health and Equity is pleased to announce the third book in the #ECOBookworms book club series--The Lorax by Dr. Seuss!
April celebrates both Earth Day and National Arbor Day, and time spent in nature is restorative always and especially right now. So let’s speak for the trees this month and read this Dr. Seuss classic together.
The Lorax's call to industry and consumers alike to conserve the earth’s precious and finite natural resources is timeless. Help plant the seed of an idea in your early climate optimist, readers age 4-8, to shape a healthier, greener future.
We hope you enjoy reading or revisiting this whimsical, yet powerful, tale. Don’t forget to share your thoughts and future book recommendations with us. Happy reading, and stay safe and healthy!
For more about ECOBookworms: https://www.apha.org/topics-and-issues/climate-change/eco-bookworms
#ClimateChangesHealth

You do this because you care, because you’re passionate about helping, because you know you can change things for the better. You work long hours — especially now — often putting the needs of others before your own. Because of you, communities are stronger, people live longer and families are happier and healthier. You don’t do it for the recognition — which is good, because people don’t always know what you do — but the fact that you’re there makes all the difference. You are public health, and we are thankful. This day, and each and every day, #ThankYouPublicHealth #NPHW #PublicHealthHeroes #whypublichealthmatters

Covering coughs and sneezes the right way can help prevent the spread of infectious diseases. Watch and share this short refresher. #CoverYourCough

With school closings announced and social distancing recommended to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus, many of us are looking for ways to fill our time at home as a family.
Numerous studies show the positive cognitive, social and emotional impact that reading to children has on their development. At APHA, we are committed to the health of our children, ourselves and our planet.
Sometimes it’s hard to know how to explore big topics with our children. Explaining why we’re all home together right now is the perfect example. But books are a great place to start.
For our book club, we select titles with a message of hope that illustrate opportunities for climate action. This month’s book is “The Earth Gives More.” Here are a few questions to get a conversation going with your early reader, too.

We're hearing a lot lately about how social distancing, self-monitoring and quarantine help contain disease. But what do those terms mean, and when do they apply?: APHA's Dr. Benjamin talks to @NPR: https://www.kcrw.com/news/shows/npr/npr-story/816490025
KCRW.COM
Self-Quarantine? Isolation? Social Distancing? What They Mean And When To Do Them | NPR

Thank you, House legislators, for passing new legislation that would provide workers impacted by the #COVID19 outbreak with two weeks of paid sick leave.
"Paid sick leave is a critical component to control the spread of the novel coronavirus in the U.S.," said APHA Executive Director Georges Benjamin, MD. "Workers must not have to choose between protecting their health, the health of their families and co-workers and losing their next paycheck."
Read our full statement online now.

Before there was National Public Health Week, there was National Negro Health Week. Learn the history in the newest AJPH podcast: https://am.ajph.link/POD_April2020
Alfredo Morabia
11 March at 20:06 ·
Check out the April issue. National Public Health Week is 25 this year but before there was National Negro Health Week (1915-1950). The issue and the podcast (https://am.ajph.link/POD_April2020) tell this story.
As every April, a special section is dedicated to the Public Health Dialogue, in which people of more Democratic vs more Republican values discuss public health issues such as racism, police violence, role of corporations or of hospital in prevention, and more.(https://am.ajph.link/AJPH_current). You won't find this elsewhere.

Did you know that our February ECO Bookworms book club pick, "The Pout-Pout Fish Cleans Up the Ocean," is part of a series? The rhyming children’s picture book by author Deborah Diesen and illustrator Dan Hanna follows the adventures of Pout-Pout Fish and his friends as they take responsibility for cleaning up their ocean.
Published by Farrar Straus Giroux, the book is among dozens by Diesen, who uses the lovable Mr. Fish to encourage problem solving, persistence, teamwork and so many other important life skills. Check out the other books in the Pout-Pout Fish series, and tell us how this book inspired your child or student on environmental health issues.
Look for our next ECO Bookworms book club pick on the second Tuesday of every month. And find out more here: https://www.apha.org/topics-and-issues/climate-change/eco-bookworms

APHA’s new ECO Bookworms club is off to a great start! As you read this month’s book selection with your kids or students, use these questions to guide your conversations.
Let us know how your young readers respond!
1. How did you feel when you saw the big, big mess in the ocean?
2. Have you seen litter in your community?
3. How does litter affect plants and animals and you?
4. What can you do to help your community stay beautiful?
Find out more about the book club and this month’s selection, "The Pout-Pout Fish Cleans Up the Ocean,” on the ECO Bookworms page.
https://www.apha.org/topics-and-issues/climate-change/eco-bookworms

Our February ECO Bookworms selection is “The Pout-Pout Fish Cleans Up the Ocean.”
Through this book, we celebrate our February themes of friendship and fellowship. When Mr. Fish discovers a big, big mess invading his pristine ocean home, he and his friends must come together to find out what caused it — and what they must do to protect it.
Author @DeborahDiesen reminds us that we all have a part to play when it comes to making our world a better place!
For more information on the book club, read the Q&A with its creator here: http://www.publichealthnewswire.org/?p=eco-bookworms-launch
Visit the ECO Bookworms web page here: https://www.apha.org/topics-and-issues/climate-change/eco-bookworms
And check back the second Tuesday of each month for a new featured book.

Calling all early climate optimists: APHA’s new ECO Bookworms book club officially launches next week!
Keep an eye out on the second Tuesday of every month as APHA’s Center for Climate, Health and Equity unveils a new selection. Our book choices will target readers 8 years old and younger, but we hope people of all ages will follow along and read.
As parents, caregivers, educators or anyone who cares for a young person, knowing how to talk about climate change can be difficult. We all want to nurture the next generation, to encourage a sense of hope and personal power.
Reading stories of climate change and our changing planet together is a great place to start. Let’s encourage young climate optimists by equipping ourselves with the right tools to begin the conversation. #ClimateChangesHealth #ECOBookworms
Tell us about your favorite environmental or climate change children’s book in the comments below.

Is a revolution taking place in sex ed? The latest AJPH podcast examines a Boston course for teenagers that uses pornography as a lead to prevent teen dating violence, promote healthy relationships and consent, and encourage critical thinking and healthy communication. Listen now! am.ajph.link/POD_February2020
Alfredo Morabia
8 January at 21:17 ·
“IS PORNOGRAPHY THE KEY TO THE SEX EDUCATION OF TEENAGERS?" (am.ajph.link/POD_February2020) The podcast focuses on one original experience that takes places in Boston which consists of developing a course for teenagers which uses as a lead to prevent teen dating violence, promote healthy relationships and consent, and encourage critical thinking and healthy communication. My interviewees are Emily Rothman, Professor at the Boston University School of Public Health; Jess Alder, Director of Start Strong (Boston Public Health Commission), and, collectively, several peer leaders of the course. This is one aspect of having promoting "pleasure" goals as opposed to disease or harm prevention in public health (am.ajph.link/AJPH_current)

More than 40M low-income Americans receive SNAP benefits for food and nutrition assistance. In its latest podcast, AJPH explores how the program works and whether it is useful.
https://www.facebook.com/alfredomorabia1/photos/a.214142592069721/1398323446984957/?type=3&theater
Alfredo Morabia
6 November 2019 at 21:11 ·
“FOOD INSECURITY IN AMERICA: IN DEFENSE OF SNAP”. Here http://am.ajph.link/POD_December2019. This month, we review the history, politics, and public health implications of the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, abbreviated as SNAP and formerly known as the food stamp program. With Joanna Simmons, who used food stamps herself, we see how the system works and whether it is useful. Then with Prof. Marion Nestle, we will review the history of SNAP, what he program has achieved, and whether it can be improved. Check it out!

The U.S. insurance system is at a crossroads. Will it continue to grow incrementally or are we on the brink of a profound transformation? Listen to our new podcast!
Alfredo Morabia
2 October 2019 at 20:00 ·
The November 2019 AJPH podcast is out here: https://am.ajph.link/POD_November2019. The US system of insurance is at a crossroads. Will it continue to grow incrementally or are we on the brink of a profound transformation in which all of the existing financing institutions are canceled and replaced by a single system? This complex machine was built progressively and underwent many social and political battles. The population coverage has improved in quantity and quality over time but remains a combination of sometimes contradictory systems and, importantly, it leaves out 30 million people without health insurance. My guests are Prof Jonathan Oberlander (University of North Carolina) and Dean Sherry Glied (New York University)

New from APHA's American Journal of Public Health!
Alfredo Morabia
4 September 2019 at 20:00 ·
AJPH OCTOBER 2019 PODCAST: “ SINCE 1619: LINGERING IMPRINT OF SLAVERY ON AMERICAN PUBLIC HEALTH” (ENGLISH) Here: http://am.ajph.link/POD_October2019
Since the first sale of African captives in 1619, North America has had about 250 years when slavery was legal and 150 years during which slavery was abolished. In this podcast I discuss whether this slavery past has left an imprint on public health in the United States. I also trace the mechanisms for which the impacts of this history can still be observed today. My guests are Thomas LaVeist, Dean of the Tulane School of Public Health, and Susan Reverby, historian of public health at Wellesley College, MA.
AJPH issue is here: http://am.ajph.link/AJPH_current

APHA's Dr. Georges Benjamin explains new CDC data showing rising death rates among young and middle-aged adults: “You can surmise that it’s most likely due to opioids,” he said, but added that causes of death would need to be further examined in order to determine that. The report, in some ways, “confirms the mortality findings that we’ve had for the last two years, where mortality overall has gone up,” he said. “It’s consistent with the increases in mortality that we’ve seen over the last couple years, in overall population mortality, which we know is due to opioids coupled with some flattened improvements in both cardiovascular health and cancer mortality.” https://denver.cbslocal.com/2019/07/24/death-rates-climbing-among-young-and-middle-age-us-adults/

This month I discuss here: http://am.ajph.link/POD_July2019 the role of science in assessing public health risks associated with industrial products, reviewing two cases prominently featured in the news recently: ovarian cancers linked to asbestos present in talc powder, and glyphosate contained in the herbicide Roundup associated with cancer and neurological troubles. I address the complex relationships between corporations and governmental agencies when consumers’ public health comes into question with Professor David Rosner, historian, Columbia University, Dr Howard Rodenberg, a former health officer in Kansas, and Professor Jonathan Samet, Dean at the Colorado school of Public Health.

Alfredo Morabia
8 May 2019 at 20:00 ·
"1969-2019, IS 'OUR BODIES, OURSELVES' HISTORY?" The pod is here: http://am.ajph.link/POD_June2019
"Our Bodies, Ourselves" was conceived in 1969 as a self‐help guide about health written by women for women. If you were at least teenagers in the sixties, you will be familiar with the book but younger people are less likely to have ever read it, perused it, or even seen it. So is "Our Bodies, Ourselves" history or does it still have a role to play in today’s world? My interviewees are Judy Norsigian, Sally Guttmacher, and members of the 2019 AJPH Student Think Tank Jay Balagna, Shanae Burch, Emily Dalton, Jeremy Wang, and Caitlin Williams.

10 April 2019 at 20:00 ·
This month AJPH podcast (here: http://am.ajph.link/POD_May2019) tackles a major crisis occurring in the governmental public health workforce, in state and local health departments. With JP Leider I review the massive wave of retirement that will slash a third of the workforce, with Karen DeSalvo I discuss what needs to be done to adapt the workforce to the current needs and challenges of public health 3.0, and with Katie Sellers we discuss how PH-WINS is conducted and what it tells us about the current interests and needs of the workforce.

As co-chair of the Congressional Public Health Caucus, I was happy to co-lead today’s resolution recognizing April 1-7, 2019, as National Public Health Week. I salute our public health organizations and professionals for all their efforts to help people pursue healthy behaviors, prevent illness and injury, and lower their health care costs. As we fight to keep Americans well and achieve health equity for all, our #PublicHealth system will be a crucial partner in our work. #NPHW

“PUBLIC HEALTH IN ACTION: REACHING OUT, COMMUNICATING, AND EMPOWERING”. The April pod is live here: http://am.ajph.link/POD_April2019. As you may know National Public Health Week (#NPHW) occurs every year during the first full week of April. The mission of Week is to showcase the importance of public health in our daily life and promote its strengthening. The theme for 2019 is “For science. For action. For health.” I have invited scientists and policymakers to talk about how they can base policy making on scientific evidence, how they can communicate the evidence to make it available for the public health actors, and, as a result, how they can proactively advance the health of the public.
Chinese pod here: http://am.ajph.link/ChinesePod_April2019

Alfredo Morabia
6 February 2019 at 21:00 ·
Listen to my new podcast: http://am.ajph.link/Pod_March2019. A multifaith team of guest editors, led by Ellen Idler, and comprising Anwar Khan, Jeff Levin, and Tyler VanderWeele, has assembled a set of articles illustrating how faith-based organizations have contributed to public health at the local, state, or global levels. I further discuss if the mission of public health is compatible with views expressed by some religious congregations that appear to contradict the fundamental principles of equity and health. My interviewees are Ellen Idler (Emory), Bill Foege (Emory), Rob, Pyne (St Norbert) , and Mimi Kiser (Emory).

Alfredo Morabia
19 December 2018 at 21:00 ·
AJPH JANUARY 2019: “PAIN MANAGEMENT: A CRISIS WITH NO END IN SIGHT”
The dramatic epidemic of opioid addiction and death by overdose has obscured the fact that millions of people suffer from pain, need to be treated, but are denied access to care. The two problems of pain management and opioid addiction are intricate and the situation has grown out of control, there is little or no evidence to support an alternative approach, and the possible solutions are years away from being even implemented. My interviewees are Richard Bonnie, Mark Rothstein, Mark Schumacher, and Daniel Carr.

U.S. health is threatened by increases in extreme weather, heat and vector-borne diseases linked to climate change, says Lancet Countdown: Tracking Progress on Health and Climate Change report: https://goo.gl/DQG2YX Co-published with APHA #LancetClimate18 #ClimateChangesHealth
The Lancet Countdown: Tracking Progress on Health and Climate Change report highlights concerning trends about how climate change is impacting our health right now. #Climatechangeshealth

The Lancet Countdown has launched its 2018 report, which highlights concerning trends in heat and heat waves, infectious disease, and declining food security. As climate change continues unabated, 51% of global cities expect it to seriously compromise their public health infrastructure. But there is still time for effective intervention and the nature and scale of the response to climate change will be the determining factor in shaping the health of nations for centuries to come. We're so excited for all the amazing connections that happen every year at the Annual Meeting! Check out one member's experience with last year's conference:
APHA International Health Section
25 October 2018 at 14:35 ·
📅Day 16 (October 25th)📅
Today's the last day to share information about past conferences from leadership. Today's spotlight is on Mary Anne. Check out what she has to say below!
1. What did you LOVE about a past APHA conference?
I was the ‘handler’ for a high-level guest speaker from Ecuador, Jaime Breilh, and it was a real joy. We did some sightseeing in Atlanta together and I learned a lot about his work and perspectives.
2. What did you LEARN by attending this conference?
The IH Luncheon speaker was a wonder of information and inspiration about current and past anti-nuclear war work in the US.
3. Why should others attend the conference?
This conference is a truly unique opportunity to network with others working in international health-related fields. I never fail to hear about someone with similar issues and concerns to my own. In addition, it’s a chance to do the same with US-based public health workers.
#apha #aphaconference #apha2018 #publichealth

INFLUENZA PANDEMIC: ARE WE PREPARED?
We have arrived at the 100 year anniversary of the deadly Great Influenza pandemic of 1918, often unfairly referred to in our collective memory as the Spanish Flu. Are we better prepared against the next deadly influenza epidemic? Opinions in public health diverge. My interviewees are Michael Greenberger (Center for Health and Homeland Security at the University of Maryland), Barbara Jester (Battelle contractor at CDC) and Mark Rothstein, Associate Editor of AJPH.

12 September 2018 at 20:17 ·
In this October podcast we discuss LUNG CANCER screening. It is currently recommended that specific categories of heavy smokers be screened for lung cancer using low dose cat scan. However, some occupational exposures also cause lung cancer, as asbestos and radiations. I interview Dr Steven Markowitz from the Worker Health Protection Program (Queens College, CUNY), Fred Carpenter, a participant of the program who screened positive for lung cancer, and Dr David Weissman, Director of the Respiratory Health Division, at NIOSH.

Check out these resources from Ready.gov and make sure you're ready for Hurricane #Florence.
Ready
8 September 2018 at 22:07 ·
With so many storms brewing across the world this weekend, it's critical to stay informed. Anyone in hurricane-prone areas should be alert, especially those in the East Coast for Tropical Storm #Florence, Hawaii for Hurricane #Olivia, and Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands for Typhoon #Mangkhut.
Follow NOAA NWS National Hurricane Center for latest updates on Florence and Olivia, and follow US National Weather Service Guam for Mangkhut.
Take time in the next couple days to get ready by:
✅ Signing up for local weather and emergency alerts.
✅ Stocking your emergency kit with enough food/water/medication to last at least 3 days.
✅ Reviewing your evacuation zones, routes, and shelter locations.
Share these tips and more with friends and family: ready.gov/hurricanes

Online now! Read the issue and then listen to the podcast, in which occupational health experts call on Congress to protect workers from COVID-19 by requiring OSHA to create an infectious disease standard.
Alfredo Morabia
8 April at 20:03 ·
The May AJPH features occupational health and safety, an issue that is both timely and topical in the middle of the dreadful pandemic that is affecting the planet, but in particular workers, whose mission is to keep the economy and public health functioning.
In the podcast (https://am.ajph.link/POD_May2020) my guests are David Michaels (Former OSHA Assistant-Secretary), Peg Seminario (AFL-CIO) and John Howard (NIOSH DIrector). Their message is: Congress needs to quickly require OSHA to pass an infectious disease standard to protect health care and other workers exposed to Covid-19. A draft of the standard exists.
The issue is here: https://am.ajph.link/AJPH_current

APHA's Center for Climate, Health and Equity is pleased to announce the third book in the #ECOBookworms book club series--The Lorax by Dr. Seuss!
April celebrates both Earth Day and National Arbor Day, and time spent in nature is restorative always and especially right now. So let’s speak for the trees this month and read this Dr. Seuss classic together.
The Lorax's call to industry and consumers alike to conserve the earth’s precious and finite natural resources is timeless. Help plant the seed of an idea in your early climate optimist, readers age 4-8, to shape a healthier, greener future.
We hope you enjoy reading or revisiting this whimsical, yet powerful, tale. Don’t forget to share your thoughts and future book recommendations with us. Happy reading, and stay safe and healthy!
For more about ECOBookworms: https://www.apha.org/topics-and-issues/climate-change/eco-bookworms
#ClimateChangesHealth

You do this because you care, because you’re passionate about helping, because you know you can change things for the better. You work long hours — especially now — often putting the needs of others before your own. Because of you, communities are stronger, people live longer and families are happier and healthier. You don’t do it for the recognition — which is good, because people don’t always know what you do — but the fact that you’re there makes all the difference. You are public health, and we are thankful. This day, and each and every day, #ThankYouPublicHealth #NPHW #PublicHealthHeroes #whypublichealthmatters

With school closings announced and social distancing recommended to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus, many of us are looking for ways to fill our time at home as a family.
Numerous studies show the positive cognitive, social and emotional impact that reading to children has on their development. At APHA, we are committed to the health of our children, ourselves and our planet.
Sometimes it’s hard to know how to explore big topics with our children. Explaining why we’re all home together right now is the perfect example. But books are a great place to start.
For our book club, we select titles with a message of hope that illustrate opportunities for climate action. This month’s book is “The Earth Gives More.” Here are a few questions to get a conversation going with your early reader, too.

We're hearing a lot lately about how social distancing, self-monitoring and quarantine help contain disease. But what do those terms mean, and when do they apply?: APHA's Dr. Benjamin talks to @NPR: https://www.kcrw.com/news/shows/npr/npr-story/816490025
KCRW.COM
Self-Quarantine? Isolation? Social Distancing? What They Mean And When To Do Them | NPR

Thank you, House legislators, for passing new legislation that would provide workers impacted by the #COVID19 outbreak with two weeks of paid sick leave.
"Paid sick leave is a critical component to control the spread of the novel coronavirus in the U.S.," said APHA Executive Director Georges Benjamin, MD. "Workers must not have to choose between protecting their health, the health of their families and co-workers and losing their next paycheck."
Read our full statement online now.

Did you know that our February ECO Bookworms book club pick, "The Pout-Pout Fish Cleans Up the Ocean," is part of a series? The rhyming children’s picture book by author Deborah Diesen and illustrator Dan Hanna follows the adventures of Pout-Pout Fish and his friends as they take responsibility for cleaning up their ocean.
Published by Farrar Straus Giroux, the book is among dozens by Diesen, who uses the lovable Mr. Fish to encourage problem solving, persistence, teamwork and so many other important life skills. Check out the other books in the Pout-Pout Fish series, and tell us how this book inspired your child or student on environmental health issues.
Look for our next ECO Bookworms book club pick on the second Tuesday of every month. And find out more here: https://www.apha.org/topics-and-issues/climate-change/eco-bookworms

APHA’s new ECO Bookworms club is off to a great start! As you read this month’s book selection with your kids or students, use these questions to guide your conversations.
Let us know how your young readers respond!
1. How did you feel when you saw the big, big mess in the ocean?
2. Have you seen litter in your community?
3. How does litter affect plants and animals and you?
4. What can you do to help your community stay beautiful?
Find out more about the book club and this month’s selection, "The Pout-Pout Fish Cleans Up the Ocean,” on the ECO Bookworms page.
